Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Vista Both Grand and Patriotic
LEAD: Liberty State Park, with its rows of American flags fluttering in the wind, has something very special to offer: an unrivaled view of lower Manhattan.
The vista of New York Harbor includes Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, which stands a mere 1,750 feet away and seems close enough to touch.


Early Opera Is the Latest Rage on Disks
LEAD: Contrary to grim prognostications, opera is alive and well as it approaches the end of its fourth century.
And while it is true that only relatively few modern works have attained repertory status, our generation has turned toward opera's first and second centuries with remarkable industry and concentration.


WHAT WE DON'T KNOW
LEAD: Please inform Christopher Hitchens that the Latin phrase domus parva magni poetae, which appeared in his article ''Why We Don't Know What We Don't Know'' (May 13), should be translated ''the small house - or home - of (not for) a great poet.''

Review and article dates are in parentheses.
Prices are current.

THE TROUBLE WITH HUBBLE
LEAD: In the ancient city of Babel, the descendants of Noah tried to build a tower so high it would reach the heavens.
In retaliation for their daring, the Book of Genesis tells us, God punished the builders, taking the language that had bound them together and fragmenting it into all the world's different tongues.


Women's Colleges Have Much to Offer
LEAD: To the Editor:


Lifestyle;   The Vanities, They Were Oh So Tepid
LEAD: The rich of New York are decamping for their summer capital on the South Shore of Long Island and other watering holes, signifying the end of what is quaintly called the spring social season, although the revels spill over into summer.
Some season.  ''Was there a season this year?'' asked Bill Blass, who knows better.


Forecast: Cloudy;   Bush Moves His Lips But Not His Troops
LEAD: BENEATH their public optimism about striking a deal to reduce the budget deficit, the negotiators from the White House and Congress are uneasy.
President Bush's surprising concession last week that higher taxes would be needed to cut the deficit got the budget talks started again.
But even the President's reversal of his ''no new taxes'' pledge will not translate quickly into an agreement on increased taxes and reduced spending.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;   Towering Changes
LEAD: ONCE a gracious avenue of low-profile, high-end stores in limestone-clad buildings, the Near North Side sector of Michigan Avenue - known as the Magnificent Mile - has been transformed over the last 15 years by huge mixed-use developments.


Ideas &amp; Trends;   Mathematicians Take the Measure Of the Insoluable
LEAD: WHEN physicists talk about large numbers, they speak of things like the number of years since the universe began - about 10,000,000,000 - or the number of atoms in the universe: 1 with 100 zeros after it.
But when mathematicians speak of large numbers, they come up with figures that leave the physicists' in the dust.


World Markets;   Waiting for the Other Shoe in Mexico
LEAD: The Mexican stock market has been one of the best performers in the world recently.
It is up 52.3 percent this year and is the top performer for the last two and one-half years in the Financial Times world market index.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The danger is we get caught up in it like it's a rock concert, like going to see Prince, where it's wonderful, but three days later you don't think about it anymore.
If we allow that to happen, it's a travesty.
If there's no connection between his struggle and ours, then the whole visit is really not the tribute to his life and work that it needs to be.

Borrowing Is Unreasonable Way to Bail Out Savings and Loans
LEAD: I was startled and dismayed by ''The Bailout: No Savagery Required,'' your June 22 editorial supporting Government borrowing as the appropriate way to deal with the bailout of bankrupt savings and loans institutions.
Borrowing may be politically expedient; it is, however, wrong, from both an economic and moral point of view.

140,000 Hulks, Every Year
LEAD: New York City remains a dumping ground for abandoned cars.

The city has new authority to deter the trashing and boost revenues in the process.
Why won't it seize the opportunity?

We Left the City, Didn't We?
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, it was a residential backwater where the windows of aging apartment buildings gave off row after row of soft yellow light on winter evenings.

The World;   Islamic Fundamentalism Is Winning Votes
LEAD: ELEVEN years after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was swept to power in the Iranian revolution, Islamic forces in Algeria, Egypt and Jordan have peacefully secured footholds on power at the ballot box.
Elsewhere, Islamic fundamentalists are seeking or consolidating power through the use of arms and intimidation.

Q and A
LEAD:
Joint Ownership of Co-op
Question: Several years ago my elderly aunt and her husband bought a co-op for cash.
He has since died but his name remains on the share certificates as part owner.
She has no will and the apartment is her only real asset.
I have urged her to make some arrangements to avoid problems in the event of her death or mental incapacity.

LEAD: Nine Vietnamese boat people arrived on Malaysia's southeastern coast in mid-June with a macabre cargo: several barrels containing the remains of 28 bodies and some United States Army dogtags.

Photo: Chaba Fadela performing at the club S.O.B. in Manhattan. (Jack Vartoogian)Review/Disco;   Arabic Funk Sound From Algeria
LEAD: Around the world, traditional music is meeting and transforming Western pop.
In Algeria, the result is rai, the Arabic funk that Cheb Sahraoui and his wife, Chaba Fadela, brought to S.O.B.'s on Wednesday and Thursday nights.
It is music in which the melody lines are unmistakably from the Arab world - fervently sung, intricately inflected - while the backup meshes traditional rhythms with Western dance beats and instruments.

When the Roses' marriage explodes, it becomes a dark, funny divorce to the death, a battle whose weapons include pate of dog.

Amazon Cruises
LEAD: To the Editor: Your reply to the lady from Rego Park (Q &amp; A, May 6) inquiring about Amazon river cruises was most informative but, unfortunately, failed to include the company that introduced cruising on the Amazon seven years ago and today operates more cruises there than any other line.


A Plague on Both Their Houses
LEAD: To the Editor:


Biennial Seeds Should Be Planted Now
LEAD: IT is time to sow seed.
As odd as this may sound at this time of year, this is the proper time to plant the seeds of biennials.
The plants have formed the odd-shaped cases that hold seed, called seedpods, and the seed is ripening inside.
If this ripe seed is sown promptly, the seed will sprout quickly, and the roots of young plants will have a chance to take hold by early fall.


Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
LEAD: 1)Get someone who understands international business and sports marketing. The World Cup is the biggest sporting event in the world, and corporate affiliations can be used to generate funds for the United States program. But the current soccer leadership cannot even decide on a mascot.
2) Dump Robert Gansler as coach.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


Managing;   Getting Mad, Then Getting Even
LEAD: It's not fun for anyone.
But more and more executives are bringing high-stakes lawsuits against their former employers, seeking large sums or high-ranking positions, employment lawyers and outplacement counselors say.
Statistics are scarce, but the number of such lawsuits is rising, counselors say, as companies impose layoffs and executives hear reports of large court verdicts.

All About/Yellow Pages;   Changing Shopping Habits Keep Those Fingers Walking
LEAD: Yellow Pages publishers are learning to behave less like utility companies and more like their advertising brethren on Madison Avenue.
In the six years since the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Yellow Pages have gone from dowdy and predicatable - almost like the white pages - to venturesome and competitive.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has restored the citizenship of three emigre dissidents punished on charges of anti-Soviet slander in the 1970's, the official press agency Tass reported today.
It said the decision was made by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after an inquiry.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
DAVE BARRY TURNS 40.
By Dave Barry. (Crown, $16.95.) This book will probably be a popular fortysomething birthday present, but it is more like the card that comes with the gift.
You know, one of those ''You're not getting older, you're just getting fatter and losing your hair'' cards.
In fact, reading ''Dave Barry Turns 40,'' a collection of columns by the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist at The Miami Herald, is like going through the humor section of a greeting card store, except there are more laughs here.

LEAD: It was on 42d Street yesterday that Brian Wilkerson stumbled upon the first 1990 census form he had ever seen.
Ignoring the sign above the Census Bureau's table that said he could ''Be Counted Here in 3 Minutes,'' he plopped down on the sidewalk to examine the form for nearly half an hour.

Headliners;   Whose Habitat?
LEAD: Environmentalists, ever wary of President Bush's insistence that he is really one of them, were delighted in mid-June when his Administration declared the spotted owl a threatened species.
The Government was expected to follow the move last week with a sweeping plan to control cutting in the old-growth forests that serve as the owl's habitat.


Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Finish planting.
Cultivate the ground lightly, weed and mulch to preserve soil moisture.
Spray roses once again to protect them from black spot and mildew diseases.
Use soil drench on primroses, yews and rhododendrons where black vine weevil adults are feeding.
Last call to plant biennial seed.


Federal Cash for Homeless: It's There but Tough to Get
LEAD: Mary Rose Gerdes, lithe and lovely at the age of 63, smiles nervously and says in a fragile voice that this is how she used to be: ''a bag of bones'' and a recovering alcoholic living in a ''perpetual rage cage.'' Is U.S.-Japan Pact a Fair Trade?
LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
A new trade agreement promises to bring Japan some of the greatest products of American culture: wide-open, overbuilt roads, discount shopping and maybe even some American merchandise.
Thursday's agreement commits the Japanese to vastly increase their spending on public works, revamp their retailing system and prosecute monopolistic abuses.

Headliners;   Japan's Princess Bride
LEAD: Kiko-san!

Hers;   Ladies' Compartment
LEAD: BEFORE TRAVELING through India recently, I had asked a friend, an old India hand, how it was for a woman alone. ''As long as you dress modestly, you should have few hassles in India,'' she said. ''I never experienced any real problems.'' I found India a puzzlement in almost every way, but most troubling was the huge cultural gap between the way I am perceived in New York City and the way I was perceived there.

LEAD: The United States can improve its soccer team for 1994 by declaring a state of war and drafting all exceptionally talented athletes in the college ranks.

Finally, hope for divine intervention.

Biennial Seeds Should Be Planted Now
LEAD: IT is time to sow seed.
As odd as this may sound at this time of year, this is the proper time to plant the seeds of biennials.
The plants have formed the odd-shaped cases that hold seed, called seedpods, and the seed is ripening inside.
If this ripe seed is sown promptly, the seed will sprout quickly, and the roots of young plants will have a chance to take hold by early fall.

1.
Flag Amendment: Vote on a proposed amendment to the United States Constitution to prohibit desecration of the American flag.

The Magic of the Manx
LEAD: Manx people say that the Isle of Man sits in the center of the Irish Sea because two giants, one Irish and one English, were feuding over a woman.
One night the English giant stole the woman away, and the Irish giant, whose name was Finn MacCoul, was so furious that he threw a handful of stone and mud after his enemy's retreating figure.

LEAD: President Bush's decision last week to limit offshore drilling demonstrates that hardly any politician can risk being seen as anti-environmental.
The reason for this is the growth of the environmental consciousness among the American people.

LEAD: Justice Thaddeus E. Owens yesterday testily explained for the ninth time the legal definition of riot to the jury deliberating the fate of the Bensonhurst defendant John S. Vento.

LEAD: According to Syracuse's athletic director, Jake Crouthamel, the school, which is a member of the Big East Conference in basketball, was one of eight football independents taking part in talks last week involving a possible expansion of the Metro Conference.

An Artist and His City: Titian in Venice

''The Rape of Europa'' has not made the trip from the Gardner Museum in Boston, nor have ''Diana and Actaeon'' and ''Diana and Callisto'' moved from the National Gallery in Edinburgh.

LEAD: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike.
We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use.

LEAD: THE Housatonic Museum of Art's collection numbers more than 500 works.

It's quite a gamut.

Repairing Wobbly Wooden Fences
LEAD: WOBBLY wooden fence posts should be repaired promptly before they cause other fence parts to loosen.
Posts that have been in the ground for less than five years usually wobble because of improper installation; ordinarily, tightening them is fairly easy.
In older fences, decay is more likely the culprit.

But it is the literal reality that is exploited by new devices that detect the work of drug traffickers and terrorists. ''The vapors of drugs or explosives get on everything,'' says David H. Fine. ''The equivalent is a foul smell.
If you kill a skunk on the highway, you can smell it on your car for days.


Calamities in Space
LEAD: NASA had a calamitous week.
First it discovered a fundamental flaw in the Hubble space telescope.
Then it had to ground its space shuttle fleet after a second shuttle sprang a mysterious hydrogen leak in pre-launch tests.
These events are a setback for astronomy, a warning for other big science projects and their backers in Congress and the White House, and an untimely black mark for the space agency.


Making Allowances
LEAD: Donald Trump was put on an allowance last week.
As part of a rescue deal from his bankers that enabled the 44-year-old developer to meet an interest payment on a junk bond issue and narrowly avert personal bankruptcy, Mr.
Trump was told that he cannot spend more than $450,000 a month on personal and household expenses for the rest of the year.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart last Sunday with an article about Quebec's economy misstated the Canadian province's gross domestic product in 1989.
It was $129 billion, not $120 billion.
A table with the article also misstated the percentage that Quebec contributes to Canada's gross domestic product.
It was 23.6 percent, not 22 percent.

Rating the Orient-Express
LEAD: FOR over a hundred years, the Orient Express, which ran from what is now Istanbul to Paris, was the world's most glamorous train - ''The King of the Rails.'' No other train possessed such an aura of romance, opulence and mystery.
The mention of its name still evokes adventure and intrigue.
It inspired six major films, 19 books and a fox trot, written in 1933.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.


Peoria Set to Welcome Its Freed Native Son
LEAD: Scott Heimdal, the 27-year-old American gold miner released Friday after two months in the captivity of Colombian guerrilla kidnappers, could be back in the United States as early as Tuesday, and his reception here promises to be a remarkable one: a homecoming for a man most Peorians have never met, in a town where he has not lived for years.

LEAD: A livery-cab driver was shot and killed during an apparent robbery while driving to work in Brooklyn, the police said.


Let's Stop Selling Cancer to Children
LEAD: Each day the merchants of nicotine lose more than five thousand customers who either die or quit.
To replace these lost consumers, the tobacco industry spends billions to hook kids on cigarettes - since they know that half of all adult smokers started smoking by age 13, and that a full one-quarter started by age 11.


Technology;   The 'Concept Car' Pushes Change
LEAD: This month, the Ford Motor Company will introduce the 1991 Capri, a sporty new car to be built in Australia around a Japanese Mazda drive train.
It will be aimed at the market made popular by Mazda's Miata.
But unlike the Miata, which was conceived quietly at the company's design studios in California, the Capri began life in 1982 in full view as a ''concept car.

LEAD: IN 1826, Lambert Hitchcock opened a chair factory in a little village in northwestern Connecticut that later came to be known as Hitchcocksville.
While the name didn't stick, the fortunes of the Hitchcock Chair Company and the people of the village have remained deeply intertwined.


Seattle's Succulent Clams
LEAD: INSTEAD of being called the Emerald City, for its abundance of parks and surrounding woods, Seattle might as easily and accurately be referred to as the clam city.
Not just for the abundance of the grayish- to white-shelled bivalves that snuggle into the substrate in Elliott Bay, Puget Sound and waters beyond, but because the clams turn up on the tables of restaurants and homes throughout the city.

LEAD: The offense, almost nonexistent in Italy, must develop fast wings and one or two center-forward strikers who are able to accept a pass and create a scoring opportunity.
Then when the players have been picked, they must be present in every single exhibition game, so that when the real games start, America will have a cohesive team that has been together.

Men's Style;   Cutting It Close
LEAD: A BART, A FLATTOP, A SPIKE OR A FADE - BY any name, it's a crew cut, heralding summer's arrival as surely as clipped lawns and Kool-Aid.
New-mown hair, it seems, is hip.
But that's not all.
Style makers will tell you it is also a bracing, low-upkeep alternative to last year's ubiquitous ponytail. ''Long hair is pretty much a thing of the past,'' says Todd Albright, who owns Total Look, a downtown Manhattan grooming salon.


Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   New Potatoes, With Broccoli and Corn
LEAD: This is the moment of the just-dug tiny new potatoes, which, like tomatoes in season, should be purchased frequently and eaten with gusto.
If you cannot find wonderfully sweet corn, it is better to use frozen ears than to suffer with the starchy kernels from old ones.
Some crusty Italian country bread completes the meal.

Repairing Wobbly Wooden Fences
LEAD: WOBBLY wooden fence posts should be repaired promptly before they cause other fence parts to loosen.
Posts that have been in the ground for less than five years usually wobble because of improper installation; ordinarily, tightening them is fairly easy.
In older fences, decay is more likely the culprit.

Tech Notes;   From Sikorsky, to Fly By
LEAD: It looks like a space ship and its job is to snoop.
The RPV Cypher (above) was designed by the Sikorsky helicopter subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation to be a pilotless surveillance drone.
About six feet in diameter and weighing 300 pounds, the vehicle can take off and land vertically and hover over targets.

Pastimes: Gardening;   Xeriscaping Kelps When the Water Supply is Low
LEAD: Xeriscaping, derived from the Greek ''xeros'' meaning dry, is a comprehensive approach to landscaping for water conservation.
It combines several basic principles including proper planning, land use, mulching, soil preparation, low-flow irrigation, maintenance practices and proper plant selection.

LEAD: 1) Forget about trying to establish a quality professional league in the soccer-hostile United States.

LEAD: So much for Meech Lake.

But the financial markets have felt nary a ripple.
For the week, the Canadian dollar - still supported by high interest rates - was up 1 percent at 1.1633 to the dollar.

LEAD: Tax revenue increases.
With those three words, President Bush last week ushered in feverish budget negotiations.
Proposals that were taboo on Monday - like taxes on Social Security benefits or cuts in Medicare - suddenly became possible on Tuesday.
Swinging into action, Congressional leaders promised to cut next year's budget deficit by $55 billion or more.

When an Opera Is Transformed Into a Dance
LEAD: Although operas throughout musical history have contained dance sequences, our own century has seen the emergence of the totally danced opera.
Such a transformation of an opera retains all its arias and choruses; the singers, however, are relegated to the orchestra pit or to the sides of the stage, and the dramatic action is entrusted to dancers.


WHAT'S NEW AT FRISBEE U.
LEAD: I found much to admire in the philosophy of education at Hampshire College (''What's New at Frisbee U.,'' by Chip Brown, June 10).
The Frisbee image is one well abandoned, but the more rigid curriculum is a change to be approached with caution.
America's colleges and universities are doing a fine job of shunting students into the myriad career tracks that have developed in our fin de siecle economy.

Town Houses
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Music;   Works From Quebec By Le Nouvel Ensemble
LEAD: Le Nouvel Ensemble Moderne, a contemporary music group from Montreal, celebrated its first anniversary, slightly belatedly, with a free concert last Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
The group was formed last May, and made an impressive New York debut earlier this season.

LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland decisively lost a test of strength with Lech Walesa this weekend, exposing his Government's precarious foundation of support and raising questions about whether his Cabinet could survive without changes.


A Sad Place in History
LEAD: Andy Hawkins of the Yankees became the first modern pitcher to lose a no-hit game with an eight-inning complete-game effort when Chicago scored four runs in the bottom of the eighth on two walks and three errors yesterday.

LEAD: FOR nearly 20 years, their rivalry had simmered in the memories of Merion and Muirfield, but now it's boiling again: the wisecracking grandson of a Mexican gravedigger who has ascended to golf's royalty with a goofy swing against the calculating conglomerate who is considered by most aficionados to be the best golfer in history.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Things over there got better and better.
Here they got worse and worse.
The reason I'm confident is that I've seen the worst.
No matter what comes now with the new money and the economic change, it's got to be better than what we had.''
- Waltraud Feichtinger of East Berlin.
[A6:2.]


Chrysler Raising Prices
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation will raise prices on most of its 1990 passenger cars on Monday.
The nation's No. 3 auto maker said suggested retail price increases start at $60 for Dodge Daytona cars, which will have a base price of $9,805, and most Chrysler LeBarons, which will rise to about $12,555.
The biggest increases are $160 on the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and Chrysler Imperial models, bringing their base prices to $21,020 and $25,655, respectively.

An Iranian Aide Discounts U.S.
LEAD: Iran's Interior Minister said today that the Government had no desire for better relations with the United States and insisted that Iran had done everything it could to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

Ronald J. Clearfield of Lower Burrell, Pa., was married yesterday at the Westin William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh to Reubin Simantov, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Mayer Simantov of Forest Hills, Queens.
Rabbi Morris Landes officiated.
The bride, 28 years old and a magna cum laude graduate of Yale University, is the director of programming at BBC/Lionheart Television, a distribution company in New York.


Capital Spending Cut by RJR
LEAD: Struggling with billions of dollars of debt after the largest leveraged buyout in history, RJR Nabisco Inc. has slashed capital spending this year as it seeks fresh loans to pay off old ones.


Mexico Acts to Sell Banks
LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico sent a measure to the nation's lawmakers last week to sell the state-owned banking industry, which was nationalized in 1982, and permit foreign ownership of up to 30 percent.


Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET COMMUNISTS CONVENING TODAY ON PARTY'S FUTURE
LEAD: The Communist Party of the Soviet Union, divided, demoralized and endangered by democracy, is convening Monday for its 28th congress, where the main issue will be not so much where the party will lead the country but whether it will lead the country at all.


On Your Own;   Go Fly A Kite For Competitive Fun
LEAD: RON REICH barked out instructions to his three teammates as Top of the Line went through its team precision routine.
The double lines of the stunt kites crossed, uncrossed and crossed again as the kites flew in formation, following each other through loops, figure-8's and square turns, and then instantaneously broke ranks, looped in different directions and reformed a new line with a new direction.

The anti-abortion measure approved in Louisiana has hurt New Orleans's bid for the 1992 Democratic convention, party officials say.

LEAD: On the day they began paying new taxes on services and products varying from telephone calls to toilet paper, thousands of angry New Jersey residents took part in a cross-state convoy to the State House.
There they chanted for the recall of Gov.
Jim Florio and threatened to vote out of office all legislators who approved the new taxes last month.

LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation into George Steinbrenner concentrates less on the Yankee owner's highly publicized payments to Howard Spira than on Steinbrenner's contentious relationship with his former player Dave Winfield.

LEAD: State lawmakers passed landmark legislation today allowing New Yorkers to designate surrogates to make health-care decisions - including decisions that could end life - if they become incompetent to do so themselves.

Coke's Chief in Europe To Head U.S. Division
LEAD: After a year heading the Coca-Cola Company's operations in the European Community, M. Douglas Ivester is becoming president of Coca-Cola USA.

Builders End Club in Japan
LEAD: Top executives of leading Japanese building companies have disbanded a social club in an effort to meet United States demands for an end to bid rigging in the construction industry, company spokesmen said today.
The 32-member club had met monthly since 1983 at breakfasts, golf competitions and other activities.


The Public Must Reject 2 Live Crew's Message;   Clearly Obscene
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Glorious Fourth
LEAD: This year there is special reason to celebrate on the Fourth of July.
The American polity has just passed an unusual test of wisdom and self-confidence.
Americans have shown, tolerably well, that we understand what this country is about: not flags, not jingoism, but freedom.


Yen Trader Is Punished
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said Friday that it had expelled and fined the last of four traders in Japanese yen futures who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the F.B.I. investigation of illegal trading at Chicago's two futures exchanges.


Attention, Claims Adjusters! Willis Is Back in 'Die Hard 2.'
''John,'' wails Holly McClane (Bonnie Bedelia), at the end of a second Christmastime showdown involving armed-to-the-teeth terrorists, helpless hostages and her husband (Bruce Willis) in the role of a one-man army, ''Why does this keep happening to us?'' The answer isn't hard to see.
John McClane is a streetwise police officer who isn't ashamed to look scared stiff when he feels that way.
He's a devoted family man with a great wisecracking sense of humor.
He's a crazily reckless fighter capable of making the most impossible feats look easy.
And he's a magnetic, cleverly drawn character, a hero neither villains nor audiences seem able to resist.
That, along with lean, edgy direction and a number of astonishing stunts, makes ''Die Hard 2'' the fastest, scariest action film of this trigger-happy summer.


Poor Win Right to Legal Aid To Fight Redistricting Plans
LEAD: A Federal district judge has issued a decision that will help poor people protect their voting rights by using legal aid lawyers to challenge redistricting plans adopted in the next few years.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House came to a grand finale on Saturday night with a performance of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' that most sumptuous of 19th-century ballets.
There were several surprises.
It was no surprise that Amanda McKerrow was a delicate Princess Aurora and that Julio Bocca was a vigorous and rather fiery Prince Desire.

Company News;   First Florida Trims Bid for Mid-State
LEAD: First Florida Banks Inc. lowered the price it is willing pay to take over Mid-State Federal Savings Bank because it believes that Mid-State's loan loss reserves are inadequate under Federal guidelines.
Under the new agreement, First Florida said it would pay $48 million, or $22.43 a share, down from $54.2 million, or $25.07.

LEAD: BECAUSE of the focusing defects found last week in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, virtually all the key instruments aboard will lose a major part of their capabilities and the most exciting scientific missions will have to be postponed until replacement instruments can be installed.

LEAD: Both the House and Senate have approved expansions of a wonderful but little-known anti-poverty weapon called the earned income tax credit.
This income supplement helps working parents with low wages by reducing their income taxes or, if they owe no tax, by paying them cash.

LEAD: The United States sank deeper in debt in 1989, the Commerce Department reported today, as the nation's overall deficit with the rest of the world swelled by 25 percent, to $663.7 billion.

Serbia Referendum Snubbed By the Albanians in Kosovo
LEAD: Voters in Serbia cast ballots today in a referendum whose passage could delay free, multiparty elections and reduce the autonomy of the Yugoslav republic's restive Kosovo region.


'Waiting for Harold,' a L.I.R.R. Saga
LEAD: On the first Monday of a major reconstruction project that will incovenience everyone who takes the Long Island Rail Road this summer, dozens of trains were late yesterday, scores of forlorn passengers waited at Pennsylvania Station for canceled trains, and Chris McEvoy spent more than three hours trying to go home.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in SportsMonday yesterday about disk golf misstated the location of the Buzzy Creek course.
It is in Blue Point Park in West Milford, N.J., not New Milford.


Viruses Said to Pirate Host's Genetic Material In Invasion Strategies
LEAD: JUST when they thought they knew most of the nasty parasitic maneuvers of viruses, researchers are now finding a new and exceedingly devious way that the microbes exploit their hosts.
They have discovered that viruses can pirate away copies of genes that control the health and well-being of the host and then turn those genes against the host species.

Company News;   Hercules Chief Retiring
LEAD: David S. Hollingsworth, the chairman and chief executive officer of Hercules Inc., announced today that he plans to retire next year.
He did not give a specific date.
Mr.
Hollingsworth, 62 years old, has been at the helm of the chemical company since March 1987.
Mr.
Hollingsworth joined Hercules 42 years ago and worked in or headed many of the its businesses including paper chemicals, flavors and fragrances and resins.


Global Auction Set for Some Savings Unit Assets
LEAD: The Government will hold an international auction in late September, via satellite, for properties worth more than $1 million each that were acquired from insolvent savings and loan institutions, Administration officials said today.


The Lip-Reading Slogan Aside, Mr. Bush Deserves Some Applause
LEAD: As the individual who is sometimes credited with making the biggest political mistake of the 1980's by saying -on no less an occasion than my acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention -that I would raise taxes, I take a special interest in how our President and members of Congress now struggle with the issue of taxes and the Federal deficit.


Stress and the Radish
LEAD: Pollen of radish plants subjected to environmental stress is less successful in siring seeds when in competition with pollen from radish plants grown in a more favorable environment, scientists reported in a recent issue of the journal Science.
The authors, Dr.
Helen J. Young, assistant professor of biology at Barnard College, and Dr.


French Air-Traffic Strike
LEAD: French air-traffic controllers said today that they would strike for three days beginning on Tuesday.
The action could wreak havoc with holiday traffic at the two main Paris airports, Orly and Charles de Gaulle.
Air France said the strike, over staffing, would force it to ground 60 percent of its European and Mediterranean flights, but that longer flights would not be affected.

Chronicle
LEAD: JOHN CHANCELLOR is recovering nicely after double-bypass surgery last Wednesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York and is to be released this weekend.
Mr.
Chancellor, 62 years old, had suffered chest pains after returning to New York last week from the tour for his new book, ''Peril and Promise.

LEAD: He'll take the record, but Cal Ripken Jr. would have been much happier with a victory.

LEAD: As the Federal Reserve's top policy makers met today in Washington, 31 business people and economic analysts convened at the grand old Toledo Club to imitate - and thereby fathom immediately - the thinking of the people who determine the nation's interest rates and availability of money.


Soybeans and Pork Surge On Forecast of Hot Weather
LEAD: Forecasts for sizzling temperatures in the Midwest sparked sharp gains yesterday in the prices of soybean and pork futures amid speculation that hot weather would scorch the bean crop and slow the movement of hogs to market.

LEAD: The Southland Corporation, owner of the 7-Eleven convenience-store chain, said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to revise the terms of its exchange offer to restructure its outstanding public debt and preferred stock.

He was 86 years old.

Review/Television;   Transforming a Man Into a Woman
LEAD: One of the most important and consistently laudable series on public television is ''P.O.V.'' (for Point of View).
Independent documentary makers are given an opportunity to show their work in as direct a context as possible.
The content may be sensitive or even controversial, but the broadcasts are not saddled with wrap-around panel discussions intended to convey the impression of balance or objectivity.

LEAD: ''God is great!'' begins the muezzin's cry, and the men put down their cups of sweet tea and amble toward the nearest mosque to join a rising tide of Islam, which is as evident as the minarets speckling the countryside here in northwestern China.

Rig Count Is Steady
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States slipped by only one last week, to a total of 1,020, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.
A year ago the count was 817.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on June 18 about the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow misidentified Yuri Grigorovich.
He is the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, not the Bolshoi Theater.
The ballet company is part of the Bolshoi Theater, whose general director is Vladimir Kokonin.

First Full View of Extinct Worm-Like Animal
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have discovered the first complete fossils of an armored worm-like animal that lived 550 million years ago.
Until now, paleontologists have only been able to guess at the anatomy of these early complex creatures, known as halkieriids, by piecing together fragments of scales and shells.

LEAD: At a time when tennis prodigies seem to be surfacing every week, the latest hot prospect is a 10-year-old Californian, Venus Williams.


WordPerfect Offspring
LEAD: SUCCESSFUL programs create little industries of their own.
Add-on software offers features the original programmers forgot, or different ways to do the same things.
Books supplement and frequently improve on the manuals, or provide information for people using illegal copies who never had an official manual in the first place.

LEAD: After deliberating for less than six hours, a jury acquitted the Rev.
Al Sharpton last night of all charges of fraud and larceny brought by the State Attorney General's office.

LEAD:
TRACK AND FIELD
Briton Sets Javelin Record
Steve Backley of Britain set a world record for the javelin throw yesterday in Sweden with a toss of 293 feet 11 inches in his first throw at a meet in Stockholm's Olympic Stadium.
Backley surpassed the mark of 293-1, set by Patrik Boden of Sweden earlier this year in the United States.

LEAD: R. H. Macy &amp; Company announced plans to open a new department store in Providence, R.I., in the autumn of 1993.

The store is expected to employ about 500 people.

LEAD: The French state-owned domestic airline Air Inter has signed a contract with Airbus Industrie for seven Airbus A321 planes and has taken options on eight more, Airbus Industrie said in a statement.
Air Inter also exercised its five remaining options on the A320 model.
The airline has ordered a total of 24 Airbus A320's.


Lima Journal;   What's Hawked at Curbside? Dolares
LEAD: With his white jogging shoes padding on the pavement, Fernando Pantigoso loped alongside a slowing car and offered the day's special - the United States dollar at 65,000 intis.


After Her Acquittal, Marcos Is Now Facing Civil Cases
LEAD: Rejoicing in court and at church and at restaurants and parties, and in front of an endless procession of cameras, Imelda Marcos has expressed her gratitude in the last two days to the American justice system for clearing her of criminal charges.


Markets Closed
LEAD: Markets for trading stocks, bonds, currency and commodities will be closed today in the United States in observance of the Fourth of July.
They will re-open tomorrow.


Ousted U.S. Research Leader to Join Computer Consortium
LEAD: Craig I. Fields, who was removed as director of the Defense Department's long-range research agency in April, will become the No. 2 executive and eventually the head of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a computer industry consortium in Austin, Tex.


Federated's New Buying Strategy
LEAD: Federated Stores Inc. is developing a new, more centralized buying strategy that could save it millions of dollars and enable it to lower its prices.
But the approach, which is central to Federated's plan to emerge from the company's five-and-a-half-month-old bankruptcy, could reduce the autonomy of the company's nine chains, which include Bloomingdale's and Abraham &amp; Straus, and make their merchandise more nearly uniform.


World Cup '90;   Argentina Eliminates Italy on Penalty Kicks
LEAD: Hot lava has gushed from Mount Vesuvius and earthquakes have rattled the city and foreign navies have sailed into the harbor, and now this city will be known throughout Italy for a sporting version of disaster: the defeat of the Italian national soccer team.


Wine Talk
LEAD: It seems only fitting, on Independence Day that we forgo what used to be known as the Old World and set out a few of our own good wines for consideration.
Traditionally, this is an occasion to talk about ''picnic wines'' and such.
The fact is that even in summer we sit down fully clothed at a table for most meals, and if wine is drunk it is not going to differ markedly from what we drink in winter.


Strawberry Hits 2 as Mets' 4 Homers Back Viola's 12th Victory
LEAD: After blitzing their way through June with 21 victories in 28 games, the Mets made it two straight in July last night when they hammered the Houston Astros, 12-0.
And they did it with a barrage of epic hitting that included four home runs, two of which banked against the scoreboard in remote right field.

Half of Cities in U.S. Say Revenue Fails To Cover Spending
LEAD: More than half the nation's cities and towns expect spending to exceed revenue in the current budget year and two-thirds of the municipalities say budget problems are worse than a year ago, according to a survey released Monday.


Critic's Notebook;   As Tanglewood Marks a 50th, Let the Cavils Not Be Sounded
LEAD: Coming up on Friday: the 50th anniversary of the Berkshire Music Center at the Tanglewood Festival.
So it's memory time - memories not only of the beginnings of the Music Center but also of the festival itself.


Dow-Datatimes Deal
LEAD: Dow Jones Information Services and Datatimes have agreed to a joint marketing and service deal to combine their electronic libraries, the two companies anounced on Monday.
Datatimes is a subsidiary of the Oklahoma Publishing Company, with a minority share owned by Dow Jones &amp; Company.
The arrangement will allow researchers to search electronically through the computerized files of 640 newspapers, magazines, news services and financial data sources.

Iran-Iraq Talks Produce Progress On Ending Long Confrontation
LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Iran today held their first direct talks since their 1988 cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.
The talks could open the way to a summit meeting between Presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and the negotiation of a peace treaty to end 10 years of hostility.


Memorial for John Faulk
LEAD: A memorial concert for John Henry Faulk, the Southern humorist and radio personality, is to be held at 5:30 P.M. on Monday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.
In 1962, Mr.
Faulk, who had a show on CBS radio, won a libel suit against Aware Inc., which was devoted to alerting broadcasters and advertisers about those in the entertainment industry it felt had ties to the Communist Party.

Book Notes
LEAD: The Other Burton Novels on the best-seller list are usually written by well-known authors, but the nonfiction list almost always includes books by little-known authors or books that survived small first printings. ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' by Allan Bloom (Simon &amp; Schuster), and ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' by Paul Kennedy (Random House), had first printings of fewer than 10,000 copies.

LEAD: Dr.
Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, elected yesterday as the new president of the New York City Board of Education, is an ardent champion of multicultural education, the idea that children can be taught to appreciate and respect the human coat of many colors.
It is a subject that was bred in the bone.

LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday superseded a Bronx school board after it failed to name a superintendent or acting superintendent.

Oil Activity Has Shifted From U.S.
LEAD: For the first time, oil companies operating in the United States are spending more to look for oil abroad than at home, and most of their production and reserves are outside the United States, Arthur Andersen &amp; Company, the accounting firm, said yesterday.


Group Withdraws Offer for Talman
LEAD: An investor group dropped its $700 million offer for the Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Illinois, the state's largest savings institution.
Talman said in a statement that a Chicago-area banker, Harrison I. Steans, leader of the investment group, had abandoned the buyout because the savings and loan association's revised earnings projections fell below his original expectations.


It's Summertime, So Pass the Mayo
LEAD: MAYONNAISE is the sauce that holds summer together.
From potato salad to cole slaw to sandwiches, mayonnaise is the common chord, and as the mercury shoots up, so do its sales.


Track Fire Delays Subway Service 3 Hours
LEAD: Tens of thousands of homebound subway riders on the IRT suffered new disruptions yesterday when a track fire knocked out service north of 96th Street for almost three hours.


Fleet Norstar Sued By Shareholders
LEAD: Five shareholders are suing Fleet Norstar Financial Group Inc. and accusing it of concealing the extent of problem loans at the company's banks.
Three lawsuits filed in United States District Court in Providence contend the company's failure to make timely disclosure of its loan problems artificially inflated its profits and the price of its stock.

LEAD: Riddick Bowe, the undefeated heavyweight (17-0, 15 knockouts), will headline his first network television card for CBS on Sunday against Art Tucker in Atlantic City.


Mentor Graphics Sees Profit Decline
LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said it expects to report second-quarter earnings of only 5 to 10 cents a share, down from 29 cents a year earlier.
Revenues of $100 million to $103 million are expected for the quarter, down from $106 million.
The company said the projected results would be significantly less than expected.

LEAD: As they pull out of Hungary, Soviet troops are leaving behind a legacy that to Hungarians somehow befits the 45-year occupation - rows of grubby, rundown barracks, shoddy apartment buildings, fields of unexploded artillery shells, oil and other waste dumped directly into the ground.

Factory Orders Up 2.1% in May
LEAD: Orders received by the nation's factories climbed a healthy 2.1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today, but the $5 billion rise was mainly attributed to higher production by auto makers worried about a possible strike this fall.


Marion R. Hart, 98; Made 7 Solo Flights Across the Atlantic
LEAD: Marion Rice Hart, a sportswoman and author who sailed a ketch around the world and in her later years made seven solo flights across the Atlantic, the last at 83 years old, died on Monday.
She was 98 years old and lived in Berkeley, Calif.
She previously lived in Washington and Manhattan.

Banks With Stakes in Borrowers Are in Spotlight
LEAD: The eagerness shown recently by many bankers to restructure the debt of RJR Nabisco Inc. has put the spotlight on an unusual feature of the leveraged buyout phenomenon: banks that own equity stakes in their borrowers.


Lloyd W. Hazleton, 79, Biological Researcher
LEAD: Lloyd Walter Hazleton, retired president of Hazleton Laboratories Inc., a biotechnology research company, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va.
He was 79 years old.
Dr.
Hazleton and his wife, Harriet, founded the company in 1946 on the grounds of an old country schoolhouse in Fairfax, Va.
It became one of the world's largest biological testing services, dealing with new chemicals and chemical compounds.

LEAD: A ruling by the Supreme Court that lucrative broadcast licenses may be distributed in a way that favors blacks and other minority members means that a variety of Federal programs requiring minority participation are now free from uncertainty and challenge, several legal scholars and civil rights lawyers say.

LEAD: United States Bankruptcy Judge Joseph Cosetti could confirm a bankruptcy reorganization plan for the Allegheny International Inc. as early as this week, officials close to the company and its creditors said today.


Officer Tells Jury of Finding Battered Jogger

McDonnell Douglas Close to Korean Pact
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that a final deal may be at hand for the Government to sell 120 of the company's F-18 fighter jets to South Korea.
The deal would be worth about $2.7 billion to McDonnell Douglas, which builds the attack fighter for the U.S.
Navy and also provides it to several foreign nations.

LEAD: The videotape of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. smoking what prosecutors say is crack in a hotel room provides several openings for his lawyers to raise an entrapment defense, lawyers and legal scholars say.
But while it may be easy to raise the issue, it will be extremely difficult for Mr.
Barry's lawyers to succeed in making their case.

Gustave Harrow Is Dead at 60; Assistant State Attorney General
LEAD: Gustave Harrow, a lawyer and former assistant New York State Attorney General who was a leader in shaping art legislation, died on Saturday.

Chapman S. Root, 65, A Coca-Cola Bottler
LEAD: Chapman Shaw Root, a former chairman of the country's largest Coca-Cola bottling company, died on Monday at Emory Hospital in Atlanta.
He was 65 years old and lived in Ormond Beach.
The cause of death was not disclosed.
Mr.
Root inherited Associated Coca-Cola Bottlers, which had plants in Pennsylvania, Florida, New York and New Jersey, from his grandfather.

LEAD: The Saudi Interior Minister, Prince Nayef, said today that 1,426 Muslim pilgrims died in a stampede in a pedestrian tunnel linking this city with a tent camp for pilgrims.

Economic Scene;   College Tuition: A Better Idea?
LEAD: THE problem: The earnings gap between those who went to college and those who did not has never been greater.
Yet tuition subsidies for all but the poorest students have become scarcer than Taittinger in Teheran.
Loans at market-rate interest are generally available to students who need them.
But not surprisingly, the children of financially pressed parents are loath to begin their working lives burdened with tens of thousands of dollars in education debts.


N and R Lines Will Undergo Repairs for Seven Weekends
LEAD: Riders of the N and R subway lines between Manhattan and Queens will face some trying weekends for the next month and a half as the Transit Authority halts service on sections of those lines for repair work, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

LEAD: CORNISH hens are ideally suited for barbecuing or broiling.
They weigh only about a pound each, so they cook relatively quickly.
And they have firmer, moister flesh than chickens, so they don't dry out as quickly.

Woman Gets $3.75 Million Over Diaper Soap
LEAD: A West German chemical company has agreed to pay $3.75 million to a woman who said her leukemia was caused by a detergent used to launder her diapers when she was a baby.


Kurile Island Deal Rejected
LEAD: Japan today rejected as premature a Soviet proposal to share ownership of Soviet-held islands in the Kurile chain, which Japan claims.
The issue is a longstanding sore point that has prevented the Soviet Union and Japan from signing a peace treaty to formally end World War II.
Earlier this week, a political commentator, Vsevolod Ovchinnikov, wrote in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, that the dispute over the islands could be settled if Tokyo and Moscow agreed to place the islands under United Nations trusteeship.

Horizontal Drilling, or How to Revive Oilfields
LEAD: In the long history of the Texas oil industry, there has rarely been a gusher as powerful as either of those that burst to the surface in the aging oil patch southwest of San Antonio last month.
In an area regarded as well past its oil-producing prime, the wells surged with 20,000 and 12,000 barrels a day, respectively, in a field where most wells produce less than 500.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds decreased $2.24 billion, to $382.70 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 161 institutional funds decreased by $222.8 million, to $91.61 billion.
The assets of the 250 general-purpose funds were down by $723.9 million, to $133.21 billion.

Ozone Action by Japan
LEAD: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry said on Wednesday that it was increasing financial help to industries that must limit the use of substances that damage the earth's ozone layer.
Ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons are to be phased out by the year 2000 and methyl chloroform by 2005 under an international agreement known as the Montreal Protocol.

LEAD: ANNA MAGNANI seems a bit too old, a bit too plump and awfully tired as she begins her role as a commedia dell'arte actress in ''The Golden Coach,'' Jean Renoir's unlikely 1952 film about an 18th-century Italian troupe performing in Peru.
Magnani's character, Camilla, has an ingenue's innocence and effortless charm, but she is played by a middle-aged woman who seems uncomfortably stuffed into a funny, harlequin-patterned dress.

Power Failure in Brooklyn
LEAD: A 30-minute power failure affected 6,000 customers yesterday in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.
A spokesman for Consolidated Edison, Martin Gitten, said a 27,000-volt line malfunctioned at noon, cutting off power from Avenue U to Manhattan Beach and from Brigham Street to Shell Road.
The power failure was not related to the weather, he said, although electricity use is always high during air-conditioner season.

Mr.

LEAD: Whimsy and politics make extremely strange bedfellows, at least in ''The Cassandra Cat.'' This 27-year-old political allegory from Czechoslovakia, opening today at the Public Theater, is the story of a bespectacled cat who brings chaos to a small town when his glasses are removed.
Without those blinders, people literally show their true colors.

Sounds Around Town

The last time Mr.
Thomas appeared in New York, he had a Paris-based band that was irresistible; this time, with musicians from Cameroon, he may be even better.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Beliefs
LEAD: For a year the United States has been embroiled in a fitful debate over obscenity.
That is not necessarily bad.
A country indifferent to such a question would probably be a country that no longer cherished any beliefs deeply enough to care whether they were transgressed.
Or it would be a country so monolithic and complacent in its mores that affronting them was unimaginable.

LEAD: Le Monde's editorial director, Andre Fontaine, remarked not long ago that European intellectuals, West and East-Central, were themselves undergoing a historic unification, having come to ''all use the same words and concepts and speak of the same things.'' LEAD: Galina Brezhnev, daughter of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader, has won a lawsuit claiming a variety of valuables confiscated when her husband was sentenced to prison.


Bug Strips' Health Risk Is Revised
LEAD: In 1987 a Government report cited a chemical in pest strips as a probable cause of cancer, and the insect-control devices seemed to disappear from store shelves.
Now the Government is preparing a new report that the two American makers of the strips hope will revive their sales.


Store's Sign Leads To Anti-Bias Protests
LEAD: The owner of a pharmacy posted a sign reading, ''The black Americans from the manor are not welcome here - they are thieves,'' on Tuesday, and protesters have been gathering outside the store.


Henry Allen Lord Mali, Executive, 58
LEAD: Henry Allen Lord Mali, a New York textile executive, died on Thursday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital.
He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn.
He died of complications from leukemia, his family said.


Philippines Given Advice
LEAD: The Philippines should improve its investment climate and work harder to sell itself abroad, a special representative of President Bush said today.


Seattle Gives Cheers To the Arts of Russia In Goodwill Festival
LEAD: During a single night here this week, theatergoers gave a standing ovation to a performance of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' performed in Russian, another audience rose to its feet to celebrate the Bolshoi Ballet's return to America, and a long line snaked outside the entrance of a gallery showing five centuries of treasures from Moscow.


Byron Rubenstein, 74, Rabbi in Connecticut
LEAD: Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein, leader of the congregation at Temple Israel in Westport, Conn., for 23 years before he retired in 1982, died on Thursday at Mediplex of Westport.
He was 74 years old and lived in Westport.

LEAD: Norman Wells Mather, professor emeritus of electrical engineering at Princeton University, died on Tuesday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center.
He was 76 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has ordered the lifting of police roadblocks and imposed curbs on other activities of security forces, to crack down on human rights abuses.


Renamed Exxon Valdez Will Ply Different Waters
LEAD: The Exxon Valdez, the tanker that caused the nation's worst oil spill, will be returned to service next month under the name Exxon Mediterranean and will ply the seas half a world away from Alaska, the company that owns the vessel said today.


Truck Driver Killed in Holdup
LEAD: The driver of a Pepsi-Cola delivery truck was fatally shot yesterday during a holdup in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said.
The driver, Hank Fallacaro, 35 years old, of Brooklyn, was shot once in the chest shortly after noon at 630 Central Avenue while making deliveries, said Patrolman Fred Weiner, a police spokesman.

LEAD: About 3,000 Albanians crowded into Western embassies in the Albanian capital today, and the Austrian news agency reported that 10,000 jammed the streets, some of them fleeing police beatings in Europe's last Stalinist state.

LEAD: Those traditional American rowing rivals, Yale and Harvard, advanced along with Temple today to the quarterfinals of the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta.

LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, champion of the slender insurgent minority at the Communist Party congress, warned the party today that it must change everything from its name to its undemocratic methods or soon be ''dragged from legal power'' by a disgusted Soviet public.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With the Perils of Parking a Car
LEAD: In big cities many drivers justify the expense of parking in lots or garages by pointing to the security they can provide.
Yet it is not uncommon for owners to return for their cars and find dented fenders or scratched finishes.
Sometimes, property is missing.
And occasionally the car itself is gone - stolen.

LEAD: Two Israeli researchers this week patented a method for producing an intense red dye for foods and cosmetics from carrot cells grown in petri dishes.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about immigrants in Spain misidentified the nation that formerly controlled Guinea-Bissau.
It is Portugal, not Spain.

LEAD: Standards of dress have subtly shifted in midtown Manhattan, and for once the culprit is not an avant-garde French designer or a trend-setting socialite.

It's hard to stay attentive.

It doesn't matter; the speaker's point was that we have to overcome the crisis of socialism,'' and he went on to the next speech.

LEAD: A former city employee testified today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial that she sold crack to the Mayor on more than 20 occasions in 1988, sometimes handing it over at her home after he arrived by limousine, other times delivering it to him at hotels and at a city office building.

LEAD: The innings had merged quietly one into the other.
The threats, mild menaces at best, had unraveled without much inspiration.
It appeared that the Mets' offense was fated to rest.

LEAD: Two New York City singers, Deborah Voigt and Hans Choi, won top honors today in the voice categories at the ninth Tchaikovsky International Music Competition.


Jean Dabry, French Navigator, 89
LEAD: Jean Dabry, navigator for Jean Mermoz on several of the French pilot's pioneering flights in the 1930's, died on Wednesday.
He was 89 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed.
On May 12, 1930, Mr.
Dabry and Mr.
Mermoz completed the first nonstop flight between Africa and South America, crossing the South Atlantic from Senegal to Brazil in 21 hours and 14 minutes.

LEAD: Six weeks before his suicide, Mitch Snyder told a meeting of his co-workers at the Community for Creative Non-Violence that he was being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service in connection with royalties he received from the 1986 television film of his life story, a spokeswoman for the organization said today.

VW Raises Prices
LEAD: Volkswagen U.S. raised prices by an average of 2 percent on its 1991 Golf, GTI, Jetta, Passat and Vanagon models arriving at dealers now.
Pricing for the full Volkswagen model line will be announced this fall when the remaining 1991 vehicles become available, it said.

LEAD: Michel Couturier still chuckles when he recalls the night he and his wife received a phone call at their Greenwich Village apartment from the excited rhythmic gymnastics coach at the United Nations International School on the East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: Mark Davis, who won the National League Cy Young Award last year as a relief pitcher with San Diego but has been a major disappointment for Kansas City in the bullpen this year, is going to get a chance at starting.


Tokyo Leader Bars Aid to Soviets Until Settlement of Island Dispute
LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today that ''it will not be possible'' for his Government to take part in economic assistance to the Soviet Union until Moscow has settled a 45-year-old territorial dispute over islands in the Kurile chain.


Navratilova Going for No. 9
LEAD: Martina Navratilova is known as the golden oldie at Wimbledon, where she is an eight-time singles champion, holds the record for singles victories with 98, and is poised to set another record Saturday if she can use her 11th appearance in the women's singles final to achieve a ninth title.


Fernandez Plans to Appeal Decision on Superintendents
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that he would appeal a State Supreme Court decision that limits his authority in the hiring of school district superintendents.


JOB FIGURES DEPRESS BOND PRICES
LEAD: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury securities plunged.
The sharp price declines were fed by conflicting employment data released by the Government before trading began in New York and the losses became even more pronounced during the session.


Officer Is Found Guilty In Slaying of a Motorist
LEAD: A 26-year-old police officer was convicted yesterday of shooting an unarmed motorist to death in a burst of anger over a traffic dispute.

LEAD: For parents who feel compelled to exhibit their children's latest fingerpaintings, a graphics designer in New York City has patented a picture frame that is simple enough for small children to assemble themselves.


In East Europe, Cries for Change
LEAD: President Petar Mladenov of Bulgaria resigned yesterday over charges that he had ordered tanks to disperse an anti-Government protest in December, and his resignation touched off rejoicing by thousands of Bulgarians.
After students demanded that Mr.
Mladenov quit, he submitted his resignation to the newly elected Parliament ''in order not to be a reason to increase political tension,'' Bulgarian television said.

LEAD: Rebel forces attacked the port of Monrovia today and fought a battle less than two miles from the executive mansion where President Samuel K. Doe is trying to stay in power.


Ban on Discovery Airways
LEAD: The Government today ordered the Hawaii-based Discovery Airways closed down in one week, accusing the three-month-old carrier of violating United States laws on foreign ownership.

LEAD: More and more vacationers are seeking significant discounts on hotel rooms in the United States through special clubs or coupon books.
Those savings can extend, too, to some rental cars and short-term condominium rentals.


Explosion Kills 17 at Petrochemical Plant in Texas
LEAD: A fiery explosion at a petrochemical plant near the Houston Ship Channel killed 17 workers and injured five others, the authorities said today.


Police Guard Is Gone, but Koch Is Not Unprotected
LEAD: The Police Department has taken away the six-member security detail assigned to former Mayor Edward I. Koch since he left office on Dec. 31.
The department's action was based on the decision that police protection was ''no longer warranted,'' a police spokeswoman said.

He was 78 years old and lived in Tenants Harbor, Me., and Chadds Ford, Pa.

LEAD: Many female workers in the European Community are unable to get as much work as they want and are often overqualified and underpaid for the jobs they hold, according to a study presented this week by the European Community's Executive Commission.

LEAD: To tighten control over military spending and save up to $150 million a year, the Pentagon plans to consolidate the separate accounting and finance offices of the Army, the Air Force, the Navy and the Marine Corps.

LEAD: Jurors in the trial of Rafael Rivera Garcia, the Puerto Rican artist and university professor accused of trying to kill his next-door neighbor, told the judge last evening that they are hopelessly deadlocked on most charges.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange censured Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday and fined the brokerage house $500,000 for improper actions during the firm's 1986 merger discussions with the E. F. Hutton Group, Wall Street executives said.

FERNANDEZ TAKES CHARGE
LEAD: James Traub depicts well the problems of corruption and inertia Joseph Fernandez faces as chancellor of the New York City schools system (''Fernandez Takes Charge,'' June 17).
But his article overlooks one ironic aspect of the situation, namely that Stanley S. Litow and Robin Willner, the powers who installed Fernandez, were themselves rewarded with posh jobs as his top lieutenants.


Moving On
LEAD: The man who pioneered the trust-fund program for The Athletics Congress and who was a key executive in long-distance running during the last decade, Alvin Chriss, has announced his resignation from TAC.
In addition to his work for the trust fund, designed to help athletes receive money for on-track and off-track activities while retaining their amateur status, the 60-year-old Chriss recently represented TAC in drug-testing appeals.


New York City Moves to Bar Idling Engines
LEAD: New York City workers armed with stopwatches will start a crackdown on engine-idling tomorrow in an effort to reduce air pollution.


A Fair That's Full of Style
LEAD: WHEN the glass blowers light their furnaces at the Allaire Craft Fair on Saturday, the fiery glow will echo flames that lighted a bog-iron forge at the same site nearly 200 years ago.


If Mozart Has Arrived, Can Kochel Be Far Behind?
LEAD: Bupleurum is the genus name for Hare's Ear, a plant marked by a single, earlike leaf that sheathes the top of its stem.
It is a member of the order Umbelliferae, which also includes carrots, parsley, dill, lovage and hemlock.
In the 19th century a new species of Hare's Ear was identified by one Professor Fenzl, who, following the custom of naming rare plants for distinguished botanists, called his discovery Bupleurum Koechelii.


QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

Without the opportunity to look back and see how far the sport has progressed in such a short time, America's task might seem insurmountable.

Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: The history of the game is replete with accidents of various kinds.
The first occurred in 1929 when Ely Culbertson took his foursome to Paris following a victory in London.
The scoring was French-style ''plafond'' with which the Americans were not familiar and the host country had a small lead throughout.

The Yankees' Week That Was
LEAD:
SUNDAY Three weeks after almost being released, Andy Hawkins pitches a no-hitter in Chicago and loses, 4-0.
The Yankees commit three errors in the eighth inning to allow the runs.
Hawkins becomes the first pitcher in 23 years to lose a complete-game no-hitter, the first in modern baseball history to pitch an eight-inning complete-game no hitter.

LEAD: On sultry summer days, when a child's toughest decision may be whether to sell lemonade or draw with crayons, the Brooklyn Children's Museum ranks as one of the more sophisticated - and fun - places to learn something.


Portugal
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to warn prospective travelers in Portugal of the possible theft of their luggage from a van or station wagon.
I remember vividly my shock and disbelief when five suitcases were stolen from our locked Ford while it was parked in a deluxe hotel parking lot.
The remaining 10 days of our stay were largely devoted to replacement of my husband's prescription medicines, some clothing and other necessities.

LEAD: To the Editor: Travelers who like to read must be annoyed by the tiny light bulbs found in most American motel rooms - small because many guests seem to think it is their right to take the larger ones as a part of the service.

Island Struggles With Increasing Toll of Children With AIDS
LEAD: At 3 1/2 years of age, Peter likes to play with keys and ars and to swing on his swing set.
Recently, his foster mother found him emptying onions out of the kitchen vegetable bin.
By the time she spotted him, he had peeled every onion and was lying among the skins.
Like any other child his age, he has a penchant for getting into mischief.

From a Writer's Standpoint, Rewards Are Worth the Risks
LEAD: The screenwriter Shane Black went off to his cabin for four months recently and emerged with an original screenplay that he then sold in an auction among the studios for $1.75 million.
While the price tag made national news, less noticed was the fact that Mr.
Black could have sold it for more but elected to take less - so that he could name the producer he wanted to work with.

LEAD: To the delight of serious collectors, older recordings of outstanding musical merit are constantly being reissued on CD.

Tips on Buying Garden Hose
LEAD: WHEN buying garden hose, choose either rubber hose or hose made of reinforced rubber and vinyl.
Both are more durable, although more expensive, than hose made only of unreinforced vinyl.


By Old Carriage Roads on the Hudson, a New Hiking Trail
LEAD: EACH week, after Robert Marshall completes his clerical duties for Metro-North, he returns to his home here, sheds his coat and tie, picks up his block and tackle and a couple of giant pry bars, and goes out to do his other work.
Mr.
Marshall, 54 years old, is a trail blazer.
He has just designed and completed, with the help of volunteers from the Mohican Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club, a new eight-mile looped hiking trail on the east bank of the Hudson, just a few miles north of the Bear Mountain Bridge.

Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar.
Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead.
The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since.
Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

Life, Death And Government
LEAD: When the advances of technology outstrip the quickening of ethical and moral values in a society, why then do we turn to the law for solutions?
The ''right to die'' bill in in the New Jersey Legislature (''Bill to Allow Living Wills Draws Criticism,'' May 20) is yet another symptom of our dependence on government to make more and more of life's decisions.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: It's no news to most of us that life can be, and very often is, ornery.
What's given with one hand is taken away with the other.
Nice things happen at inopportune times (there's no opportune time for bad things), perfect plans are marred by the unexpected, sure things turn out to be not so sure, and small gambles that are almost certainties backfire.

LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
One Germany, United by Dreams of Cars and Color TV's
The last time anyone decided to rejoin a unified German government peacefully and voluntarily was in 1935, when the Saar region held a plebiscite.
Ever since, Germany's neighbors have viewed its consolidation, or expansion, with alarm.

An Architecture That Set Out to Shake the World
LEAD: It is convenient to forget that for a brief moment in the 20th century, the Soviet Union was a throbbing center of modern art and architecture, perhaps even the most advanced country of all in terms of its official level of taste.
Modernism was not born there, but it could well be said to have reached its fastest, and in some ways its most promising, flowering in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner may have found an unexpected ally in the Major League Baseball Players Association because the union believes the Yankees owner may have erroneously been found guilty of tampering.


Topics of the Times;   Luggage, Lost and Found
LEAD: One day last week a young woman about to take a very long plane trip packed herself a kind of CARE package.
There was cheese, prosciutto, bread, a tomato and a mango because she distrusts airline food.
Two newly purchased shirts and a sweater because she is wary of air-conditioning.
And three books, also newly purchased, in case the flight attendant ran out of magazines before she got to her seat.

MOTHERS: TIRED OF TAKING THE RAP
LEAD: It is not a question of fixing blame or exonerating from blame, but of understanding the centrality of the early relationship between parent and child.
The infant makes of its world what the world presents to it, mediated by the mother.
In this sense, the mother is central and powerful.
We know the mother has environmental limits to her power; the baby does not.

Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
LEAD: In this unfortunate age of overpaid underachievers, Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs leads the majors in hits, runs scored and times at bat.
He is second in home runs and batting average, and tied for third in the National League in runs batted in.
And, everyone already knows that he is the best-fielding second baseman in the game.


Is It or Isn't It? A Van Gogh Languishes in Limbo
LEAD: They are the masterpieces on the museum walls, the unvarying stars in our artistic firmament, the van Goghs and Goyas and Rembrandts and van der Weydens.
In our youth, we stood before them, notebook in hand, feverishly analyzing them for art-history classes.
Later, as we revisited them through the years, they became dear friends.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Do not delay applying fertilizer to woody plants, which need the summer months to ripen (harden) new growth.
Spray fruit trees again to keep them insect-disease free for the summer-fall harvest.
Protect rosebushes from fungus diseases.
Last call to control woolly adelgids on hemlocks.

LEAD: You could say Glenallen Hill of the Toronto Blue Jays got caught in a spider's web.

FICTION
LEAD: FURORS DIE.
By William Hoffman. (Louisiana State University, $18.95.) William Hoffman's 10th novel is an ambitious, well-written book.
Its great theme is that the believer, the person of conscience and religious faith, is destined for destruction in our dissolute culture.
Amos (Pinky) Cody is the son of a poor, alcoholic father and a mother who appears to be a religious fanatic.

Keeping Score On Grammar

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:
POLITICAL CARTOONS


Currency;   The Dollar's Down Again
LEAD: For those planning a trip to England this summer, the news in recent weeks has not been so good.
Since the beginning of June, the pound has risen by 10.5 cents, to $1.7865, from $1.6810.
This is a 6 percent increase - or, put another way, a 6 percent cut in the budget for American travelers.
And four cents of the pound's rise came in the last week.


Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: Two influences, one American, one Soviet, have conspired to give Soviet players opportunities they never had before.


Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar.
Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead.
The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since.
Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.


Hungary Communists on Film With Terrorist
LEAD: State television today showed a secret film of talks between Hungarian officials and the international terrorist known as Carlos about 10 years ago and portrayed him as a playboy who sought out women and stayed in luxury hotels.


Italy Take Third Place
LEAD: Salvatore Schillaci took the goal-scoring lead for the World Cup and lifted Italy to third place in the soccer championship tonight, putting in a penalty kick with six minutes left for a 2-1 victory over England.


The Great Outdoors;


Food;   SAY CHEEEESE!
LEAD: I grew up thinking cheese was something a little smaller than a breadbox, about the color of finger-painted pumpkins and as perishable as powdered milk.
The only time I ever tasted the real thing was when my father was feeling flush enough to invest in a round of Colby longhorn to ration out in thin slices on saltines as a late-night snack.

LEAD: Kathryn H. Tunheim liked her job as Honeywell Inc.'s vice president of public relations, but she was hankering for the excitement of running a profit center.
Honeywell, meanwhile, wanted to halve the head count in Ms.
Tunheim's department.


Solar Derby
LEAD: The idea is appealingly Soap Box Derbyesque - a bunch of young people competing with their homemade cars.
Of course, the scale is slightly inflated.
Tomorrow morning, student teams from 32 colleges and universities will begin an 11-day, 1,700-mile race through eight states - from Walt Disney World in Florida to the General Motors Technical Center in Warren, Mich.


Mutual Funds;   Picking Apart the Returns
LEAD: Robert G. Maddern, an investor in Killingworth, Conn., knows the Fidelity Municipal Bond Fund is doing well.
But how well?
He got different answers from the three newspapers and magazines in his mailbox recently.
Because they arrived so close together, the discrepancy caught his eye.

Headliners;   Beyond Faith
LEAD: Some of the Boston jurors were in tears last week when they returned a verdict after a two-month trial, convicting two Christian Scientists, David and Ginger Twitchell, of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son.
Following the precepts of their religion, the Twitchells relied on prayer instead of seeking conventional medical care to treat their son, Robyn, who died in 1986 of a bowel obstruction.

Tips on Buying Garden Hose

LEAD: The Manville Trust was meant to compensate tens of thousands of workers dying or diseased from exposure to asbestos.
