Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q.Q.
Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar.
Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead.
The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since.
Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: During a recent trip to Spain as a guest at the Macarena Sol Hotel in Seville, my cameras were stolen.
This took place under the nose of my wife who only looked down to address a postcard.
I think that you should warn travelers to Spain, especially in light of the 1992 Olympics and Columbus celebrations, that they should hold on to their valuables, even in the lobby of a four-star hotel.

London's Garden Halls
LEAD: The well-known English indifference to fashion does not apply to plants.
A visit to the halls in Westminster in London where the Royal Horticultural Society stages 12 shows each year reveals that black pansies and hellebores (the claret colored ones above all) are now in favor.
And ''geraniums are making a comeback, you know,'' one frowzily dressed English matron excitedly assures her friend as they look over a display of pelargoniums.

Reflections on World Cup 1990
LEAD: One cannot be totally disappointed with the United States team's performance in the World Cup tournament, although the United States team has a few weaknesses.
The first was poor ball-controlling techniques, and the second was the long passing of the ball.
The improvement in these areas would require good coaching and playing many matches with international teams in the next four years to be exposed to the international standard of play.

German Aid to Iraq Reported
LEAD: West German companies helped build a weapons factory in Iraq where a cannon was to be made, the German news magazine Der Spiegel said today.
The Hamburg-based weekly said confiscated documents showed that the factory near Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, was designed to produce guns.
Specialists fear that it was also the site where a cannon with a barrel 150 yards long and a range of 600 miles was to be built.

That, in turn, meant brighter, louder instruments along with augmented performing forces.

Tips on Buying Garden Hose
LEAD: WHEN buying garden hose, choose either rubber hose or hose made of reinforced rubber and vinyl.

Latchkey Summer
LEAD: Some of the most popular baby sitters in the city are named Nintendo, Bugs Bunny and the Brady Bunch.
Some of the most popular baby sitters in the city are 9 or 10 or 11 years old.
School lets out at 3 o'clock.
Mom and Dad get home at 6.
Some people have their bigger children tend the small ones, and some have their children go home and watch television and wait for the sound of their key in the lock.

Far from the melee of tourist buses, I relax in the peace and quiet of the Montparnasse Cemetery.

LEAD:
Dripping Air-Conditioner
Question: We live in a very old building in Manhattan.
Since tenants above us installed a very powerful air-conditioner in their window water constantly drips and often pours from it down to our ledge and window sill.
When their air-conditioner is on we cannot leave our windows open.


WHAT'S DOING IN Cape May
LEAD: Technically, Cape May, N.J., is a beach resort.
But the rather uninspiring stretch of sand there, packed though it may be on summer afternoons, is not the main point of this exuberantly Victorian town at the southeastern tip of New Jersey.
Cape May, a National Historic Landmark, is made for strolling, for porch-sitting, for steeping oneself in the atmosphere of another era.

LEAD: With Approval confirmed his standing as the best grass horse in the East this year by scoring a comfortable 1 1/4-length victory over Alwuhush yesterday in the $87,600 Tidal Handicap at Belmont Park.


Reflections on World Cup 1990
LEAD: I was disappointed to read the article concerning the Ireland-Romania soccer match (''Ireland Tops Romania, Ending 0-0 Game on Final Penalty Kick,'' The Times, June 26).
Instead of quoting the Irish coach's remarks on tactics you quoted his remarks on drinking.
The article had many other slurs and subtle insults.

Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

Ford Plant for Hungary
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to spend $60 million to $70 million to build an auto-parts plant in Hungary, the state news agency said Friday.
The plant, which would also import Ford cars to Hungary, would be built southwest of Budapest, it said.
Ford plans to manufacture ignition coils and electronic fuel pumps at the plant.

The Editorial Notebook;   Johnny Can't Add, Hiroko Can
LEAD: In international education tests among industrial nations, American students usually come close to the bottom in math and science; the Japanese are always on top.
More than 90 percent of Japanese children graduate from high school; close to 30 percent of Americans drop out.
If a nation depends on the quality of its people, American children should be worried about their future competitors.

Hitachi China Software
LEAD: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan and a Chinese company will jointly develop Chinese versions of software that will connect Hitachi's general-purpose computer with China's personal computers, the Japanese company said last week.

PC/XT and PC/AT.

Mines Kill Sri Lanka Soldiers
LEAD: Tamil rebels detonated mines under a military truck and an armored car today, killing 8 Government soldiers and wounding 16, officials said.
The mines, buried in a road near Vavuniya, 140 miles north of Colombo, went off as the vehicles passed over them.
In Puttalam, north of the capital, President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed to foreign governments to help start peace talks with the separatist rebels.

LEAD: In a tangled part of town called Boulaq, all narrow streets and gimcrack homes and children beyond counting, a man called Hamid told a story the other day that said much about the problems confronting President Hosni Mubarak in the Arab world's most populous nation.


Police Officer Stabbed in Jerusalem


Bill Cullen, 70, Host and Panelist On Many TV Game Shows, Dies
LEAD: Bill Cullen, a host of television game shows for more than 30 years, died on Saturday at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles.
He was 70 years old.


George T. Eggleston, Leading Isolationist In World War II, 83
LEAD: George T. Eggleston, a cartoonist, yachtsman, author, editor and isolationist who became embroiled in a national controversy in the 1940's, died Saturday in a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla.
He was 83 years old.


Dr. Jane Parnes Becomes a Bride
LEAD: Dr.
Jane Robin Parnes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Irving Parnes of Baldwin, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr.
Nicholas Adrian Cataldo, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Nicholas Cataldo of Eatontown, N.J.
Rabbi Cy Lowenheim officiated at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I.


Fear of AIDS With Rape: How a Case Was Affected
LEAD: Prosecutors in Manhattan have agreed to a reduced sentence for a defendant in a rape case in exchange for the man's promise to take an AIDS test and provide the results to his victim.


Chronicle
LEAD: Racing fans in the Northeast will get their first look at WILLY T. RIBBS driving on the Championship Auto Racing Teams' Indy-car circuit next Sunday at the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands.
Rooting for him will be BILL COSBY, his backer.


G. Zambonini, 48, Architect Who Led A New York Atelier
LEAD: Giuseppe Zambonini, an architect and loft renovator who founded the Open Atelier of Design in Manhattan, died on Saturday at his home in Atlanta.
He was 48 years old.
His death apparently resulted from a heart attack, a friend of the family said.


Bridge
LEAD: A social headache, less common now than it once was, belongs to the hostess who plans two tables of Chicago after-dinner bridge and finds herself with seven players instead of eight.
The solution, easy when you think of it, is ''shuttle dummy.'' Two tables are placed close together, and when one table has finished bidding the dummy crosses to the other to bid there.


Reds' Armstrong Is All-Star Starter
LEAD: Jack Armstrong of the Cincinnati Reds will start for the National League in Tuesday night's All-Star Game, Roger Craig, the league's manager, announced today.


Ms. Mallin Weds James K. Hanson
LEAD: Letitia Jane Mallin, the daughter of Joel M. Mallin of New York and Janice P. Mallin of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Kenneth Hanson, the son of Donald W. Hanson of Salt Lake City and Jeanne Morrison of Jamestown, R.I.
Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.


Motorola Said to Seek License From I.B.M.
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation is in negotiations to license its most advanced memory-chip technology to Motorola Inc., several Government and industry officials say.


Page Buys 2 Publications
LEAD: Page Group Publishing Inc. has purchased a pair of reader-written magazines in Beverly Hills and Brentwood.

Morton H. Kaplan of Pittsfield, Mass.

LEAD: An exhibition that was staged by the Nazis to vilify artists like Picasso, Wassily Kandinsky and Paul Klee will be presented in Los Angeles next year, but under very different auspices.

LEAD: George Archer, who took a two-shot lead into the final round of the Northville Long Island Classic at the Meadow Brook Club, won a head-to-head battle with Frank Beard today to capture the Senior PGA Tour event.

LEAD: A Federal District judge has denied a request from jurors in the trial of three commodity traders that they be allowed to tour the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

LEAD: When the match was over and it was truly time to surrender his title to the man he had claimed it from last year, Boris Becker paused for a moment and took a mental snapshot of the surroundings that have been most conducive to his urge to terrorize his competition.

LEAD: The Pittston Company, a coal producer, air freight carrier and armored car service, has named Joseph C. Farrell president and chief operating officer and David L. Marshall vice chairman.


Frenchman Buying 80% Of Adidas
LEAD: Bernard Tapie, a French entrepreneur, politician and soccer team owner, has agreed to buy an 80 percent stake in Adidas A.G., the West German company that is one of the world's largest makers of sporting goods.


Many Census Aides Are Denied Chance For Jobless Benefits
LEAD: As thousands of temporary Census Bureau workers wrap up their work this summer, they are finding that they may not be able to collect unemployment checks because of a cost-cutting move by Congress six weeks ago.

Shah Jewna Journal;   Village Women Earn Respect (and Rupees, Too)
LEAD: To be a woman, 40 and unmarried in a farming village of rural Pakistan is virtually to count for nothing.
About all the attention a single woman can attract is negative: social ostracism and sometimes physical abuse.
But here in Shah Jewna, nobody fools with Jivni.


Boeing Expects to Trim More Jobs
LEAD: The Boeing Company said last week that it expected to cut its work force in Washington State by another 2,700 jobs in the second half of 1990, bringing total job reductions for the year to about 5,600.

LEAD: PRODUCERS from two of the five series CBS will broadcast this summer call what they are doing ''guerrilla'' television.

LEAD: For Damon Bailey and Eric Montross, the distinctions between basketball myth and basketball reality sometimes blurred during their last three seasons in high school.


Chronicle
LEAD: Since February, KATIE KELLY has been teaching English to Amerasian children in Saigon.
She left her job as television critic and commentator on WNBC-TV in December.
She had been a schoolteacher in the 1960's and after vacationing in Vietnam in 1988, decided to return to Saigon.

LEAD: Charon scored an overpowering nine-length victory yesterday in the $287,500 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park, and only one thing could have made her handlers happier: they almost wished that Go for Wand had been in the race.

Evolution in Europe;   Democratic Hungary Nibbles on Political Fringes
LEAD: Three months after parliamentary elections in which voters here chose to make a clean break with the Communist past, Hungary is still lingering in a prolonged state of transition, debating issues that many thought were behind them.


Evolution in Europe;   Budapest Memorial to Jews
LEAD: Several thousand people crowded outside Hungary's main synagogue today as a memorial was dedicated honoring 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed during World War II.
The memorial by the sculptor Imre Varga depicts a powerful tree, 33 feet across, shaped like an inverted menorah, or candelabrum, with leaves bearing the names of victims.


As '900' Phone Lines Grow, Debate on Their Use Widens
LEAD: George Burditt of Santa Barbara, Calif., won $1 million recently by being the first person to punch in, using the buttons on his telephone, the correct numerical answers to seven questions.
He was the first winner of a new national contest that people enter by dialing a ''900'' telephone number, paying $2.99 for the call.

LEAD: PHIL LOMBARDI and Greg Olson are starring in this season's poor man's version of the Wally Pipp and Lou Gehrig story.

Greece and U.S. Sign 8-Year Pact Exchanging Arms Aid for Extended Use of Bases
LEAD: Greece's new Conservative Government and the United States signed an eight-year agreement here today providing Greece with more than $1 billion worth of arms in return for the continued operation of American military bases in this country.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump is set to announce this morning that France's largest retailer has signed a 25-year lease in Trump Tower in a deal worth tens of millions of dollars, bankers said.

Joy and Challenge Mix In Dancing of the Giglio
LEAD: An ornate 85-foot tower, festooned with papier-mache lilies, angels and cherubim, bobbed and swirled through the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon as about 30,000 people crowded onto the normally quiet blocks around North Eighth and Havemeyer Streets for one of New York's oldest and liveliest festivals.


Painting the Pentagon Green
LEAD: Senator Nunn has recently offered a plan to enlist the Pentagon's aid in saving the planet.
Though the chairman of the Armed Services Committee's new interests may not be entirely unconnected to his old interest in safeguarding military spending, his ideas are worth considering on their merits.
They open up potentially important areas for cooperation, and set off a number of alarm bells.


Metro Datelines;   Prison Letters Warn Youths About Crime
LEAD: A Superior Court judge, hoping to gather vivid descriptions of criminal life that will warn young people away from lawlessness, has begun ordering convicted criminals to write him letters from jail.


The Industry Fights Back Over Taxes
LEAD: THE advertising industry has been waging a fierce battle with legislators who want to tax advertising or restrict ads for cigarettes and alcohol.
So far, the intense lobbying by Madison Avenue and its clients has kept tax laws and regulations off the books.

Reporter's Notebook;   The Welcome by Bush Is as Big as All Texas
LEAD: The Group of Four went to the rodeo tonight, where they saw armadillo races, bull riding, barrel racing, calf scrambling, the Grand Ole Opry, an Old West village, cowboys and Indians, oil rigs, square dancing, a sheriff with silver spurs, Styrofoam cacti, a model of the space shuttle, horseshoe contests, 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce and jalapenos, 500 pounds of onions, 5,000 servings of cobbler and carrot cake, and 650 gallons of lemonade and iced tea.


Sizzling Mets Edge Braves
LEAD: At the game's start, the thermometer read 99 degrees.
An hour later, it had climbed to 102.
Warm, to be sure, but nothing like the reading inside John Franco's cap with one out in the the ninth inning.
That was off the chart.
Franco, just a couple of outs away from the cool of the clubhouse and the relaxation of the All-Star Game break, stood on the lonely rise of baked clay, upset at a rut in the mound, concerned about the 2-1 lead over the Braves he had been charged with preserving and incensed with himself for having issued consecutive walks.


Metro Datelines;   Vandals Set Fires In a Catholic Church
LEAD: Vandals broke into a Catholic church on Long Island, setting fires and knocking over holy water fonts, the police said yesterday.


Soviet Magazines Testing the American Market
LEAD: In the ultimate capitalist test, Soviet publications are gingerly making their way on to American newsstands in a market already saturated with foreign policy journals and glossy travel magazines.

LEAD: The Wausau Paper Mills Company has named Arnold M. Nemirow president and chief executive to succeed William L. Goggins, who was killed in December in an auto accident.


2 in Family Die in Bronx Fire
LEAD: A smoky house fire, accidentally started by a child playing with a cigarette lighter, took the lives of a 43-year-old Bronx woman and her 4-year-old son yesterday in the Williamsbridge section, the authorities reported.
A police spokesman, Sgt.
Edward J. Burns, said the fire broke out about 4:15 P.M.

LEAD: After the discovery of masses of human bones in secret graves in caves here and nearby over the last two weeks, a series of witnesses have come forward to report seeing large-scale shootings 45 years ago, painting a grisly picture of mass murder by the Communist Partisans led by Marshal Tito.

LEAD: When John Javna and Julie Bennett were discussing how to publish ''50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth,'' they considered offering it to a commercial book company. ''But we wanted it out in a hurry at an affordable price, so we decided to publish it ourselves,'' Mr.
Javna said.

LEAD: Although the Teutonic triple that many Germans had been dreaming of fell through, they won the big one - the world championship of soccer - and East and West Germans alike poured into the streets today to celebrate West Germany's 1-0 triumph over Argentina.

DOG SHOW
World Champion Crowned: A dog whose ancestors came from the sacred city of Lhasa, Tibet, is the champion of the canine world.
He is Ch.
Chakpori's Mao, a golden Lhasa Apso owned and handled by Bianca Saasen of Eindhoven, the Netherlands.
Mao triumphed yesterday at the world show in Brno, Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: The group Faith No More, riding a hit album, ''The Real Thing,'' came to the Ritz on Friday night for a sold-out show.
The band, from California, falls into a loose group of rock bands that add a handful of different musical styles to raw rock-and-roll, sprinkling punk and metal with other rock forms and rap.

Patients have no property rights to tissue used for medical research, but doctors must tell them if the research is potentially profitable, a California court ruled.

CYCLING
Italian Takes 9th Stage
Massimo Ghirotto of Italy won the ninth stage of the Tour de France yesterday while Steve Bauer of Canada held onto the overall lead for the ninth day.
Ghirotto broke away with Eduardo Chozas of Spain in the first of the mountain passes as the race crossed into Switzerland on a 122-mile leg from Besancon to Geneva.

OPEC Output Slipped in June
LEAD: Oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries fell by 420,000 barrels a day in June, to 23.26 million, mainly because of a sharp drop in Iranian production, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sunday about a computer technology known as virtual reality misidentified the television program on which Timothy Leary demonstrated such a system.
It was the ABC News program ''20/20,'' not CBS ''60 Minutes.''


Chance of Tuition Aid Keeps Needy in School, Study Finds
LEAD: Minority students, often from families unable to send them to college, are staying in school longer when they participate in programs that guarantee college tuition to needy students who are academically ready, according to a study by the United States General Accounting Office released yesterday.

Calspan Awarded Air Force Contract
LEAD: Arvin Industries said its Calspan Corporation unit had been awarded a five-year contract to operate and maintain aerospace flight dynamics test facilities at the Air Force's Arnold Engineering Development Center in Tennessee.
Total value of the contract over the five years is $276.5 million, Arvin said.

LEAD: Work is to begin in September on a monumental $738 million structure to be known as the International Cultural and Trade Center.
The complex, to be completed in 1995, is to be situated on Pennsylvania Avenue two blocks from the White House, and will also provide office space for a number of Federal agencies.

LEAD: Leo T. is a Roman Catholic priest who, like Catholic priests around the world, took a vow of celibacy when he was ordained.

Senate Set to Take Up Civil Rights Bill
LEAD: With the White House and civil rights groups at an impasse, the Senate is scheduled this week to take up major civil rights legislation that President Bush has vowed to veto.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, said yesterday that he had hired Caroline Jones Advertising as the agency of record for Trump City, his development project on Manhattan's West Side.
The agency has been working on the account, whose size was not released, for several months.

Corrections
LEAD: A brief report by Reuters in the Company News columns of Business Day on Friday misstated the relationship between the USAir Group and CCAir Inc., which has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
CCAir operates USAir Express flights under a contract agreement; it is not owned by USAir.


Cotton Extends Steep Slide As Energy Contracts Rise
LEAD: Cotton futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, extending a slide that began last week and that represents the market's steepest drop this year.

Deep Discounts By Continental
LEAD: To attract impulsive leisure travelers, Continental Airlines is offering discounts of up to 65 percent on flights from its four hub cities during the next two weekends.
The catch is that the trips must be booked before midnight tomorrow, and the travelers must return the same weekend they leave.

LEAD: The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks.
If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the third world, they will hear this: Open up markets, or forget about new trade rules on services and intellectual property.


Frances Vengen; Union Official, 93
LEAD: Frances Vengen, a garment industry union official for 25 years, died on Wednesday at her home in Lake City, Fla.
She was 93 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed.
There are no immediate survivors.

LEAD: Nike Inc. vaulted ahead of all worldwide competitors in sales last year, the company said yesterday in reporting an 84 percent leap in its fourth-quarter profit.

LEAD: Contract talks between Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association have reached an impasse and a 30-day period for cooling off will begin on Tuesday, the sides said today.

LEAD: Thirteen-year-old Diana Figueroa will leave her home in the South Bronx this fall for the distinctly different world of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.
The distance in miles is small compared to the distance she has already traveled to win admission and the personal journey to come.

It is Wegee Creek.

Patient's Right to Tissue Is Limited
LEAD: In a case with far-reaching implications for research scientists and the biotechnology industry, the California Supreme Court ruled today that a patient does not have property rights over body tissues that may be used to develop new drugs or medicines.


Ex-Official in Prague Convicted of Abuses
LEAD: The former municipal head of the Communist Party in Prague was convicted today of abusing power by ordering the police to deal harshly with anti-Government demonstrators.
The ex-official, Miroslav Stepan, was sentenced to four years in prison.
He said he would appeal.


Rain and Cooler Trend Slow Alaskan Fires
LEAD: Rain and lower temperatures over the weekend helped slow the spread of wildfires that have charred more than 550,000 acres of timber, but 2,100 firefighters remained on the job today.

LEAD: Howard Duff, a character actor who played the tough private detective Sam Spade on radio in the 1940's and a colorful Southern sheriff, Titus Semple, on the television series ''Flamingo Road'' in the 1980's, died Sunday at his home.
He was 76 years old.

LEAD: A New York City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would further limit city business with banks or companies that have ties to South Africa and seek to reward banks that put pressure on the apartheid government there.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan for Galeries Lafayette to open a store on the site previously occupied by Bonwit Teller misstated the address.
It is at 4 East 57th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues.
Fifth and 57th is the address of Tiffany's.

Allan A. Boesak, a Dutch Reformed cleric who gained renown in the struggle against apartheid, has resigned his ministry after acknowledging he had an extramarital affair with the niece of a former South African Cabinet minister.


Denial by Thompson
LEAD: The Georgetown University coach, John Thompson, in New York yesterday to promote Nike television commericals with a pro-education and anti-drug message, denied that the commercials were made in response to the recent controversy over high-priced sneakers.


Market Place;   Cleaning Spills: Is It Profitable?
LEAD: FROM the Exxon Valdez to the Mega Borg, when a tanker's oil hits the water these days, huge sums are spent on booms, skimmers and personnel for the cleanup.
But there are no pure plays in oil-spill cleanup companies.


Two of Three Convicted in Futures Case
LEAD: In the first of three trials stemming from the Government's undercover investigation of futures trading here, a Federal jury today convicted two traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange of cheating customers but acquitted a third defendant.
The jurors were unable to reach verdicts on dozens of other charges.


Chronicle
LEAD: WILLIAM MEREDITH is joining the company of ROBERT FROST, WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS, EZRA POUND, MARIANNE MOORE, ELIZABETH BISHOP and some 40 other American poets honored by their colleagues for distinguished poetic achievement.


Larry Conrad Is Dead; Indiana Politician, 55
LEAD: Larry Conrad, a former Secretary of State of Indiana, died Saturday at the Cardiology Hospital in Lyons, France.
He was 55 years old.
Mr.
Conrad suffered a ruptured aorta while attending a conference in France last month and died after undergoing open-heart surgery, Gov.
Evan Bayh's office announced.


General Dynamics In Saudi Tank Deal
LEAD: Saudi Arabia has signed a $3.1 billion deal to buy 315 M-1A2 tanks and support equipment from the General Dynamics Corporation, the Pentagon said today.


Europeans Accuse the U.S. of Balking on Plans to Combat Global Warming
LEAD: Senior European officials at the economic summit conference accused the United States today of frustrating their efforts to reach a new accord to combat global warming.

Thinning Arctic Ice
LEAD: Surveys by submarines have turned up evidence that ice in the Arctic Ocean may have been thinner in the 1980's than in the 1970's, and scientists have tentatively raised the possibility that the thinning might have been caused by global warming.

Panel Hears How Federal Aid Profited a Savings Institution
LEAD: A Senate subcommittee was told today that a Texas savings and loan association made up of 15 failed institutions earned huge profits as a result of Government subsidies, but made only four new loans in 1989.


Still a Cold War for Aliens
LEAD: For 38 years, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed the U.S. to bar foreign visitors whose ideas the Government finds offensive.
The number of visitors kept out each year varies, but the Government maintains a list of more than 350,000 people to be excluded.
At a time when world tensions are easing, that's an astounding victory of narrow-mindedness over good sense.


Denise Musnik; Advertising Executive, 58
LEAD: Denise Musnik, an advertising executive in Paris, died on Friday at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France.
Miss Musnik, who was born in New York, was 58 years old and had lived in Paris for about 30 years.
She died of cancer, a friend said.
Miss Musnik was head of international communications for Publicis, the French advertising agency, and had previously worked for Glamour Magazine and Bonwit


Search for Flood Dead Ends
LEAD: The search for any remaining victims of last month's flooding has ended with the death count at 26, officials say.
Seven people are still listed as missing since June 14, when floodwaters and debris hurtled down Wegee and Pipe creeks on the outskirts of this eastern Ohio town, but officials now believe those people were not in the area at the time.


Oil Rig Count Falls by 9
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States declined by nine last week, to a total of 1,011, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago this week, the count was 825, Baker said.
Baker Hughes's rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells.

Cab of the Month
LEAD: How slowly does traffic move in New York City on hot summer afternoons?
A passenger in a taxi meditated on the subject as the crush of cars on Central Park West inched forward at the rate of one or two cars per traffic-light cycle.
Then he was startled by a sight inside a cab inching along in the adjacent lane.


Are Laws Needed On Canned Music At Live Shows?
LEAD: With the best intentions, state legislators in New York and New Jersey are wading into a quagmire as they propose laws regulating the use of recorded music at live concerts.

LEAD: The leaders of the seven richest Western nations began their 16th annual summit conference in the tropical heat of Houston this afternoon, with an intractable dispute over trade policy threatening to disrupt the unity of the three-day meeting.

LEAD: In an emotional national debate set off by recent discoveries of mass graves, the Chilean armed forces have defended the widespread executions after the overthrow of Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973 as a response to ''internal war'' instigated by Allende partisans.

LEAD: Raymond Buckey's molestation trial went to the jury today after Judge Stanley Weisberg of Superior Court delivered 30 minutes of legal instructions.

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. asked a Federal court today to rule that five American chip makers must obtain licenses to continue using a technique for gluing semiconductor components to their base.

LEAD: A candidate for the State Legislature has been asked to resign from the parish council of a Roman Catholic church because he supports a woman's right to have an abortion.


Bulgaria's Renamed Communists in Disarray After Election
LEAD: Despite their solid victory in elections to Parliament last month, Bulgaria's renamed Communists are acting like a party in disarray.


Sallie Mae Prices $600 Million Issue
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced a $600 million issue yesterday in its regular monthy sale.
The Government-sponsored public corporation usually sells short-term floating-rate notes on the Monday before the second Thursday of each month, The notes, due Jan. 10, 1991, were priced at par to yield 25 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill and are expected to begin trading today.


Vroooooooooooooooom Ends in 'Here's Your $220 Summons'
LEAD: John Mayak, a tour-bus driver from Pennsylvania, arrived in New York for the first time yesterday, so you can't blame him for being a bit surprised when a city inspector tapped on the door of his bus and presented him with a $220 ticket.
For idling.
Not a man to hide his feelings, Mr.
Mayak got back into the driver's seat and gunned his engine, spewing a gust of exhaust over the inspector.


Japanese Shrine Burns Down
LEAD: A fire today destroyed an important Shinto shrine guarding sacred rice being grown for the coronation of Emperor Akihito.
The police said they suspected anti-monarchist militants, who have said that they plan to disrupt Akihito's November coronation.
They say the imperial system is a remnant of prewar nationalism.


Auto Makers Split on Tax
LEAD: Sharp disagreement among Detroit auto makers over the need for a rise in gasoline taxes could reduce the industry's influence in the debate over reducing the Federal budget deficit, the American Automobile Association says.


U.P.S. Deal Set
LEAD: Mail Boxes Etc. signed a letter of intent to sell to United Parcel Service Inc. 400,000 shares of its common stock for $10.1 million and 400,000 warrants, each exercisable into one share of Mail Boxes common stock, for $1.2 million.
If U.P.S. fully exercises the warrants, it would acquire about a 17.4 percent equity interest in Mail Boxes.


Vincent Draddy, 83, an Innovator In Apparel Manufacturing, Dies
LEAD: Vincent de Paul Draddy, an innovative manufacturer of sportswear who introduced the Izod and Lacoste knit shirts to America, died on Sunday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y.


The Arts on Parade
LEAD: A New Yorker at a small-town Fourth of July parade last week was thrilled by the bugle and drum corps, the floats and a veritable retrospective of fire trucks through the centuries.
But what thrilled her most were those marchers who brandished banners for the National Endowment for the Arts.
She liked their own small float, too - a city built of cardboard and colored a dark, dismal gray, over which was a sign that read ''A World Without Art.

2 G.M. Units Form Joint Subsidiary
LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company and the Delco Electronics Corporation, both subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation's GM Hughes Electronics unit, said they had formed a joint subsidiary to manufacture high-technology electronics.
The new subsidiary, H E Microwave, will produce electronics for automotive and military applications.


Output Climbs in China
LEAD: China's industrial output rose by 5.9 percent in June compared with the comparable period a year ago.
It was the biggest monthly jump this year.
The New China News Agency said today that the rate was evidence of a steady economic recovery from a stagnant period earlier this year.
But diplomats said the figure might be artificially high because a great deal of production was lost last June in the aftermath of the military crackdown in Beijing against pro-democracy demonstrations.


Thornburgh and Sessions Assailed for Traveling on Confiscated Jets
LEAD: A Congressional report criticizes Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for their official travel aboard three executive jets seized from drug traffickers.


Consultants Ponder Coming Elections
LEAD: These are not the best of times for the men and women who produce political campaigns.
Analysts, pundits and even some politicians are deploring the state of American campaigning.


Ban on Hunting of Whales Upheld
LEAD: The International Whaling Commission has averted a threat to the five-year-old moratorium on commercial whaling.
The threat was turned back on Friday when the American representative blocked a proposal that would have allowed a limited catch of whales in the Atlantic.


Venezuela in Shift on Citgo
LEAD: The Venezuelan state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., no longer plans to sell the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it purchased in February from the Southland Corporation, a senior Petroleos official said today.


Joseph Mailman, 88, Head of Philanthropy
LEAD: Joseph L. Mailman, an investor and philanthropist who was president of the Mailman Foundation, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 88 years old.

LEAD: Britain said today that it would reopen a 1912 inquiry into whether many of those lost with the Titanic could have been saved by a ship that was nearby when the liner sank.


Japan Air in Korea Link
LEAD: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it would cooperate with Korean Air Lines to develop their computer reservation systems jointly.

LEAD: Five people were reported killed in clashes with the police today as anti-Government protests spread from Nairobi to outlying cities.
The authorities were told to use whatever force was necessary to quell the demonstrations, which have left eight people dead in the last three days.

Connecticut Indian Land in Legal Quandary
LEAD: For more than 300 years, since one of the first Indian reservations in the New World was set aside near what is now Bridgeport, the law of Connecticut has been the law of all the lands within it.


HarperCollins Buys 3 Jeffrey Archer Books
LEAD: HarperCollins has bought the next three books of Jeffrey Archer, the English author who recently said he was offered $20 million for the books by an unnamed publishing house.


German Fans Greet Team
LEAD: Tens of thousands of flag-waving fans greeted West Germany's World Cup champions here today in a peaceful show of pride that was a stark contrast to Sunday night when four people were killed and hundreds injured after street celebrations turned violent.


An Investment Banker Moves to Brick Making
LEAD: Philip R. Mengel, an investment banker, is moving from an abstract business to a concrete one, and from New York City to Reading, Pa., where the company he will head makes concrete products, bricks and other building materials.


Playing Their Own Game
LEAD: With the World Cup and Wimbledon finally settled and the Tour de France still in early stages, international sports fans can turn this week to the World Games in Australia.
Five teams are in Perth for the world championship of lacrosse - the United States, Canada, Britain, Australia and the Iroquois.


Sentence in Rape Hoax Appealed
LEAD: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her appealed today to the Nebraska Supreme Court her perjury sentence, which requires her to pay for advertisements apologizing to the man.


Sex Differentiation
LEAD: NEWLY discovered fossils of a tree-dwelling primate that lived in North America 50 million years ago show the earliest known signs of sexual differentiation in primate behavior, paleontologists say.


Dollar Mixed in Light Day As Pound Continues to Rise
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed in light domestic trading yesterday as currency traders kept a close watch on the economic summit meeting in Houston but had little news to act upon.


Five Cubans Seek Protection
LEAD: Five Cubans entered the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana today and asked for protection, an embassy spokesman reported.
It is not clear whether the five are seeking political asylum in Czechoslovakia.
Diplomats said it was the first time that Cubans had managed to obtain refuge in an East European embassy in Havana.

Tests Find Leak Clues On Shuttle
LEAD: Space agency officials said today that a primary seal in a large pipe that carries liquid hydrogen fuel to the space shuttle is the ''prime suspect'' for causing leaks that have grounded all three of the spacecraft.

Ford Cancels Plant In the Philippines
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has canceled plans to build a $150 million car-stereo plant in the Philippines because of fears about political stablility and security, the Trade and Industry Secretary, Jose Concepcion, said.
He said Ford was now considering Indonesia for a new site.

Bridge
LEAD: Early in the century, even before auction bridge turned into contract, it was normal in many parts of the world for bridge columns to end with a double-dummy problem.
Such problems rarely appear naturally, but the diagramed deal from the Spingold Knockout Teams in Chicago last August is certainly a candidate.


Chess
LEAD: There are certain logical, positional problems that come up from time to time in various games without getting a clearcut solution.
Often inaccuracies by both players disqualify the games as proper tests of the strategic values in question.
Moreover, special features of these positions can also intervene to make proving a general point difficult.


Homophobia: Scientists Find Clues To Its Roots
LEAD: A RISE in hostile actions against homosexuals can be traced primarily to hatred based on fear and self-righteousness rather than to the AIDS epidemic, researchers are finding.
Although polls show more Americans are beginning to accept homosexual men and women and support their rights, there has been a great increase in reports of anti-gay bias since the beginning of the epidemic.


New Details in Book on Brawley Case
LEAD: A new book on the Tawana Brawley case gives new details about how the black teen-ager fabricated her story that she had been raped by white men.


Defense in Jogger Trial Argues Rights Violation
LEAD: Defense lawyers in the Central Park rape trial tried to show yesterday that one of the defendants charged with attempted murder and rape of a jogger last year was arrested without first being read his rights.

LEAD: New guidelines issued yesterday by the National Endowment for the Arts require grant recipients suspected of violating its restriction against obscenity to supply ''a written justification of the project'' and an explanation of how it complies with the language in the agency's 1990 appropriations legislation.

Bidder for Hotel On W. 42d St. To Be Examined
LEAD: New York City officials said yesterday that they would investigate allegations that a group that has bid to run a former welfare hotel on West 42d Street had collected rent at two buildings in Brooklyn even after it had been ordered to relinquish control because of poor maintenance.


Brademas Plans to Step Down as President of N.Y.U. in 1991
LEAD: John Brademas, who nearly doubled the endowment of New York University and helped transform it into a major research institution in his nine years as president, said yesterday that he intended to step down in December 1991.

Dow Jones Profits Fall
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company said yesterday that its profits for the second quarter fell 27.9 percent.
One reason, it said, was interest and other costs related to its acquisition of Telerate Inc.; another was a weakness in the market for information services.

LEAD: An All-Star Game in Wrigley Field with two runs scored?


Norwest Merger
LEAD: United Banks of Colorado, the largest banking company in the state, said yesterday that it was discussing a possible merger with the Norwest Corporation, the largest banking company in Minnesota.
With $6 billion of assets, United Banks is about a fourth the size of Norwest.
The two companies, which have been the focus of merger rumors, said no agreement had been reached.

Education;   Fluency in English Required of Faculty
LEAD: A new law in Pennsylvania requires all college and university faculty members, including graduate teaching assistants, to be proficient in English.


Soviet Aid: Short Reach
LEAD: Sometimes the very struggle for unity undermines the semblance of unity, and such was the case, it seemed tonight, in the search here for a formula that would unite the seven leading democracies on the question of aid to the Soviet Union.


More South Africa Sanctions
LEAD: A tougher and expanded South African sanctions bill was unanimously adopted by the New York City Council yesterday.
The bill will expand existing laws that bar the city from doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa and will establish a rating system to judge the posture of banks in dealing with South Africa.


King Says His Goal Was a Title Rematch
LEAD: Don King testified yesterday that the reason he made a ringside protest over a referee's long count during the the Mike Tyson-James (Buster) Douglas heavyweight title fight was to lay the foundation for his real objective, to get a Douglas-Tyson rematch.


Ruth Brooks Littman And Jack Gross Marry
LEAD: The marriage of Ruth Brooks Littman to Jack Gross took place yesterday at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.
Rabbi Mark Winer performed the ceremony.

LEAD: ''If I had gone into the front office before the season began and asked for a $15,000 All-Star clause in my contract,'' said Greg Olson, the catcher for the Atlanta Braves, ''I would have been laughed out of there.''

MAXWELL R. THURMAN, the commander of the United States invasion of Panama last December, was admitted to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington on Monday with a preliminary diagnosis of leukemia, the Pentagon has announced.

LEAD: Burger King will begin test-marketing six-inch Domino's pizzas at four of its South Carolina restaurants in September.
The one-year experiment is aimed at the McDonald's Corporation's test of its own pizza in 200 of its restaurants.

Chronicle
LEAD: CALVIN KLEIN was released from New York Hospital on Monday after a six-day stay for treatment of injuries he suffered while horseback riding on Long Island.
The 47-year-old fashion designer suffered two broken ribs and other injuries when he was thrown from a horse on July 3 in Bridgehampton.

LEAD: John F. Connelly, chairman of the Crown Cork and Seal Company and head of the Connelly Foundation, a Philadelphia philanthropic organization, died Sunday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
He was 85 years old.

Saudis Press Oil Cutbacks
LEAD: Saudi Arabia held a meeting today of Persian Gulf oil ministers in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, on establishing a new OPEC output pact to end the overproduction that has sent oil prices plummeting.


Book Notes
LEAD: Appeal on Cheever The Illinois Appeals Court recently upheld a lower court decision that prohibited Academy Chicago from publishing its proposed collection of 68 stories by John Cheever.
But Jordan Miller, vice president of the independent Chicago publishing house, said yesterday that he would appeal the court's June 27 decision.


Evolution in Europe;   CONFRONTING FOES, GORBACHEV KEEPS PARTY LEADERSHIP
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev swept confidently to re-election as head of the Communist Party today, after confronting the party's hard-liners with a militant defense of the changes he has ignited in his society.


AIDS in Black Women Seen as Leading Killer
LEAD: AIDS is rapidly rising nationally as a cause of death among women aged 15 to 44 years old, and is the leading killer of black women in that group in New York and New Jersey, according to a new study by researchers at the Federal Centers for Disease Control.


World Bank Is Beginning To Tap Smaller Markets
LEAD: The World Bank began borrowing money in the smaller financial markets of the world yesterday when it became the first nonresident borrower in New Zealand.


Rangers Get a Center
LEAD: The Rangers yesterday acquired Brian McReynolds, a center, from the Winnipeg Jets in exchange for Simon Wheeldon, another center.
McReynolds, 25, had 2 assists in 9 games with Winnipeg and scored 18 goals with 41 assists for 59 points in 72 games with the Moncton Hawks of the American Hockey League last season.


Citing Extra Costs at 5 Airports, American Adds Ticket Surcharge
LEAD: American Airlines, reacting to what it calls ''excessive charges'' imposed by five airports, plans to add ticket surcharges of $1 to $4 beginning next week for its flights from those airports.


Cairo Journal;   With Islam in Vogue, Boutiques for the Pious
LEAD: When Mona el-Rifai returned from a spell in Saudi Arabia eight years ago, she had become used to wearing Islamic dress and thought others might like to do so as well, so she opened a store.


U.S. Team to Defend Title After 3 Decisive Victories
LEAD: Three decisive victories in three days have cleared the way for the United States to defend its world lacrosse title on Sunday.


Top Hurdles Matchup
LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the world-record holder in the heptathlon, and her teammate, Gail Devers-Roberts, a 1988 Olympian who set the American record of 12.61 in the 100-meter hurdles in 1988, will compete in the 100-meter hurdles at the New York Games on July 29, said Fred Lebow, the executive director of the New York Road Runners Club.


Dollar Falls Against Pound; Forecast on Rates Lifts Yen
LEAD: The pound took center stage in foreign exchange trading yesterday, sending the dollar to an 18-month low against the British currency.
The dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen.


The Editorial Notebook;   Women Stereotyping Women
LEAD: Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, predicts ''the feminization of power'' as more women win public office.
Women politicians talk enthusiastically about the ''decade of the woman.'' Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee for governor of California, says that a woman official can protect abortion rights more reliably than a man.

INSIDE
LEAD:
Judge Orders Vote Monitors At All Teamster Locals
A Federal judge ordered the teamsters' union to put court-appointed monitors at each local to scrutinize the election of national officers.
The judge said the monitors were needed because teamster leaders had tried to sabotage Federal efforts to rid the union of criminal influence.


Mulheren Convicted Of Fraud
LEAD: John A. Mulheren Jr., once an aggressive Wall Street speculator, was convicted yesterday of conspiring with Ivan F. Boesky to illegally manipulate stock prices, conduct sham transactions and exchange confidential market information.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Down
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again and interest rates rose further yesterday despite a highly successful auction of $5 billion worth of new 30-year bonds offered by the Resolution Funding Corporation, the Federal agency charged with financing the savings and loan bailout.


Brooklyn Youth Is Wounded in Dispute Over Coat
LEAD: A 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student was shot and critically wounded yesterday during a disputeover an expensive coat, the police said.


Out-of-Control Car Kills Two Children And Hits Two Others
LEAD: A boy and a girl playing on their front lawn in Rosedale, Queens, were struck and killed last night by a car that ran through a stop sign, apparently out of control, the police said.


A.T.&amp;T. Layoffs
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said the number of employees to be laid off in its Network Services Division had been reduced to 4,300, from 6,000, because many workers had accepted early retirement.
The cuts, beginning in September, will affect workers in all states except Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, Idaho and Vermont.

LEAD: A group of music publishers, including the songwriter Sammy Cahn, has filed a lawsuit seeking to halt the sale in the United States of new digital audio tape recorders, contending that they contribute to copyright infringement.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: CERTAIN lean, meaty fish, like halibut, swordfish and marlin, require utmost care in preparation to prevent dryness.
If you barbecue or broil them, frequent basting is necessary.
Sauteeing is less risky, but you must check frequently to avoid even the slightest overcooking.
In this recipe for halibut with lemon sauce, I take the safest route, poaching.


Beach Towel a 9-5 Favorite To Win Meadowlands Pace
LEAD: Despite drawing the outside position in the field of 10 horses, Beach Towel is still the overwhelming favorite in the $1,153,500 Meadowlands Pace on Friday night.


New Chief Is Named At Wilkinson Sword
LEAD: Fred E. Hiller has been named president and chief executive of Wilkinson Sword North America, replacing Norman R. Proulx, who resigned from those positions in June, the company announced yesterday.
Mr.
Hiller, 50 years old, has been vice president of finance of the Atlanta-based razor and lighter company since 1986.

LEAD: Ronan Pensec celebrated his 27th birthday today with as pretty a present as the Tour de France can offer: he received the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

LEAD: Near the beginning of ''Father Was a Peculiar Man,'' an exhilarating evening of environmental street theater presented by En Garde Arts, an actor from the company of more than 60 performers approaches the audience and excitedly offers his theory of the significance of Madonna.
By suggesting that sex is possible in the age of AIDS, he says, she is ''trying to become a Christ - she will link us together.

LEAD: All Nippon Airways said today that it planned to buy about 30 medium-sized passenger jets for about $3.3 billion, substantially increasing its fleet.

Sasser Injury Not Bad
LEAD: Mackey Sasser, the Mets' catcher who was injured in Sunday's game in Atlanta in a collision at home plate with Jim Presley, was examined by the Mets' team physician, Fiske Warren, yesterday and was reported to be suffering from a sprained right ankle.


State Dept. Tells Americans To Postpone Trips to Kenya
LEAD: The State Department advised American citizens today to defer all nonessential travel to Kenya because of anti-Government strife there.


Devils Like Newcomers
LEAD: Three of the Devils' most highly regarded prospects have signed multiyear contracts with the National Hockey League team, said Lou Lamoriello, the club president and general manager.
Zdeno Ciger, Jason Miller and Jarrod Skalde signed their first professional contracts and will attend training camp in


A Program to Make the Streets a Safe Place to Play


Al Merrill, Ski Coach, 69
LEAD: Al Merrill, coach of the United States Nordic ski team in three Olympics and a member of the National Ski Hall of Fame, died Sunday at Curley Health Care Center.
Mr.
Merrill, who suffered a stroke two years ago, was 69 years old.


Backward Flow The Years
LEAD: At last it seems possible to get younger.
Growth-hormone injections have done the trick for a test group of men aged 61 to 81, according to last week's science news.
Practically all of them perked up noticeably, regaining scientifically measurable amounts of the mustard commonly associated with younger men.


Brademas to Leave N.Y.U. Presidency


Rinfret and London Slug It Out as Cuomo Steps Deftly Aside
LEAD: While Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo was campaigning upstate yesterday, two opponents spent most of a half hour in a Manhattan television studio challenging each other's credentials and credibility.


USX and 2 Union Leaders Convicted in Alabama
LEAD: The USX Corporation and two United Steelworkers officials were convicted today of conspiring to provide the union officials with company pensions in exchange for major concessions in a 1983 labor contract.


Sikh Who Promoted Truce Is Shot to Death
LEAD: A Sikh leader who helped fashion a brief truce between the Indian Government and Sikh militants was assassinated today in the capital of Punjab.

United Parcel to Alter Its Trucks In Los Angeles to Use Natural Gas
LEAD: The United Parcel Service said today that it planned to convert its 2,700 delivery trucks in the smog-choked Los Angeles area to run on cleaner-burning natural gas in the first major step by a company to comply with strict new vehicle-emissions laws here.


Drop in Worker Drug Use Found
LEAD: The number of American workers and job applicants who have tested positive for drug use has declined in recent years, a company that conducts the tests said today.


European Jobless Rate
LEAD: The unemployment rate in the European Community has remained steady at 8.6 percent for the first five months of the year, the European Community statistical office reported on Monday.
Unemployment ranged from 1.7 percent in Luxembourg to 16.6 percent in Ireland.

LEAD: When MADONNA, in Rome on the latest stop on her round-the-world tour, came under attack from the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano.
In an unusual commentary over a pop star passing through town, it declared her show to be sinful.

NICARAGUA POLICE RAZE ROADBLOCKS
LEAD: Hundreds of striking Sandinista workers and students stood aside and offered little resistance today as riot police officers and army bulldozer crews knocked down barricades that the protesters had built to stop traffic in a nationwide protest that began here Monday morning.


SUPPORT FOR BUSH DECLINES IN POLL
LEAD: In the first public opinion survey to be released since President Bush abandoned his ''no new taxes'' pledge, the Gallup Organization reports that just over half the public disapproves of his new stand while 4 out of 10 approve.


Savings Office In Policy Shift
LEAD: Savings and loan bailout officials approved a policy today that they hope will save taxpayers money by selling insolvent institutions before they lose value under Government control.


Market Place;   Who Should Set Margin Levels?
LEAD: With the financial futures industry fearing for its future, and some parts of the securities industry warning of a financial crisis unless there is reform, pressure is building for Congress to control just how much risk speculators can take when they use the futures market to bet on whether stock prices will rise or fall.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Galeries Lafayette's plan to open a store on 57th Street misstated the location of Henri Bendel.
That store is at 10 West 57th Street, just west of the Galeries Lafayette site.
The article also misstated the location of Saks Fifth Avenue in some editions.


Bo Knows How to Pitch a Product
LEAD: IN Bo Jackson's latest commercial for Nike Inc., there does not seem to be anything the versatile sports celebrity cannot do.
Playing on the well-known Nike theme that ''Bo knows,'' the spot shows the professional baseball and football player in at least 15 sports roles, from surfing to soccer.


Mary Gordon Is to Read In Trinity Church Series
LEAD: The novelist Mary Gordon is to read from her writing today at noon at St.
Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street.
The reading, part of a free series sponsored by Trinity Church, was originally scheduled for last month, but had to be postponed because of activities involving the New York visit by the South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela.


Chronicle
LEAD: When they get off the plane in Moscow today, 50 young American musicians from all over the country will have just two days before they meet and start rehearsals with 50 of their Soviet counterparts for a joint concert at the Moscow Youth Palace on July 19.

San Diego Bishop Resigns
LEAD: The Vatican announced Tuesday that Pope John Paul II had accepted not only Archbishop Marino's resignation but that of Bishop Leo T. Maher of San Diego.
Bishop Maher underwent surgery for a malignant brain tumor this spring and is 75 years old, the customary retirement age.
He will be succeeded by Msgr.


Monitors Ordered for Teamster Voting
LEAD: A Federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to put court-appointed monitors at every union local to scrutinize the 1991 election for national union officers.

LEAD: A Literary Approach ''People don't have as much time to read as they used to have - that's why we need songwriting,'' Steve Earle said the other day. ''Songwriting is literature that you can read in your car.''


Alain Chapel, French Master Chef And Restaurateur, Is Dead at 53
LEAD: Alain Chapel, regarded as one of the finest chefs in France, died yesterday while visiting friends in Avignon, France.
He was 53 years old.


About New York;   Best of Friends Get Together, With Supervision
LEAD: Edgar B. sat with his 6-year-old child, Edgar B. Jr., at a small table.
Each week, the Bronx Family Court allows the father exactly an hour-and-a-quarter of closely supervised time with his son.
This was it.

LEAD: *
Lorraine Alper-Kramer has been appointed senior vice president and creative services director of BBDO Los Angeles.


Witness Says He Warned Barry to Curb Drug Use
LEAD: Testifying for a second day that he supplied Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. with drugs, including opium, a Washington restaurateur said today that he warned the Mayor many times that ''enough is enough.'' The witness said he urged him to cut back on drugs and to stop taking chances about where and with whom he used them.


Willis Reese, 77, Professor and Expert In International Law
LEAD: Willis L. M. Reese, the Charles Evans Hughes Professor of Law at Columbia University and the director of the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia for 25 years, died on Monday at his home in Hughsonville, N.Y.
He was 77 years old and also had a home in Hewlett, L.I.
He died of colon cancer, a friend said.

McMahon Agrees To Become an Eagle
LEAD: Jim McMahon, the quarterback who led the Chicago Bears to victory in the Super Bowl in 1986, yesterday agreed to a one-year deal with the Philadelphia Eagles as a backup to Randall Cunningham, the elusive passer and runner.
McMahon understands the plans the Eagles have for him, according to Buddy Ryan, the Eagles' coach, who was the defensive coordinator for the Bears during their Super Bowl season.

American Medical Holdings Inc., Dallas, said its American Medical International Inc. subsidiary, Beverly Hills, Calif., had completed the sale of its Swiss and Greek hospital companies for about $176.7 million.


Former West Virginia Governor Is Sentenced to 5 Years for Graft
LEAD: Former Gov.
Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to 5 years and 10 months in prison and a $170,000 fine for a variety of corrupt acts both in and out of office.


U.S. Savings Agency Weighs Suit Against Bush's Son and Others
LEAD: Federal regulators are considering filing a $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush, the President's son, and other directors and officers of the defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, seeking to recover some of the $1 billion in losses from speculative lending and insider transactions, officials said today.


G.E. Sees Breakthroughs From New Diamond
LEAD: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had created a form of diamond with an enhanced ability to transmit heat and light.
Company spokesmen said it could lead to important advances in microchip design and new applications for lasers.


Textron Settles U.S. Charges
LEAD: Textron Inc. has agreed to pay a record $17.9 million to settle a whistle-blower's charges that one of its subsidiaries supplied the Coast Guard with faulty helicopter engines, the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: A subsidiary of the Lockheed Corporation said it had signed a lease to take over a hangar at Norton Air Force Base in San Bernardino, Calif.
Norton is one of 86 military bases scheduled to be closed by 1994.
The value of the lease was not disclosed.

LEAD: A panel of space agency experts has concluded that the nation's planned $37 billion space station will require nearly 75 percent more maintenance than predicted in even the most recent gloomy forecast.

LEAD: Last month, the police say, a 95-year-old Navy veteran entered an elderly neighbor's apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and bludgeoned her to death - thus becoming one of the oldest murder suspects in the city's history.

LEAD: STEVEN RUBIN, who founded a large oil brokerage firm, flees his life several times a year for the Maharishi Ayur-Veda Health Center in Lancaster, Mass., a serene and elegant retreat where the emphasis is on integrating the mind and the body.

LEAD: The leaders of seven major industrial democracies effectively agreed today to go their own way on the matter of aid to the Soviet Union, European and American officials said tonight.


Pitney Bowes Stock Plunges by 12.8%
LEAD: The stock of Pitney Bowes Inc., a maker of postage meters and mailing systems, fell sharply yesterday after the company announced that it expected weak second-quarter earnings.
Pitney Bowes shares fell $6.375, or 12.8 percent, to $43.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 1.6 million shares were traded.

LEAD: IF the annual International Fancy Food and Confection Show is a barometer of American taste, the culinary atmosphere is heating up.
At the four-day trade show that ends today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, there appeared to be more salsas, mustards and other condiments and spice-flavored items than ever, especially among new products.

The Sunny Side of the Street
LEAD: The law we learned in Physics 101 that two bodies cannot occupy the same space at the same time is getting its annual hot weather test on the sidewalks of New York.
Back in January and February, streetwise walkers used the west side of the avenues in the morning and the east side in the afternoon, absorbing whatever warmth they could from the winter sun.


Evolution in Europe;   Czech Food Prices Increase 25% As Many Subsidies Are Removed
LEAD: Prices rose an average of 25 percent at grocery stores today as the Czechoslovak Government ended subsidies on farm products and fresh and processed food.
There was some grumbling, but on the whole there appeared to be widespread acceptance of the increases.

Bridge
LEAD: Bidding that starts at the one-level is usually very accurate, like the operation of a watch.
But if the opponents begin with a pre-empt, it is like throwing sand in the watch.
Some good guessing is needed to be accurate, complicated by the fact that bad breaks are now more likely.


Fedders in Deal To Buy Emerson
LEAD: The Fedders Corporation, a leading manufacturer of air conditioners, said it plans to acquire Emerson Quiet Kool from the Jepson Corporation.
Terms of the transaction, which will combine two of the best-known names in air conditioners, were not disclosed.


Fathers' Rights On Adoption Are Expanded
LEAD: New York State's highest court today widely expanded the rights of unwed fathers, ruling that a state law restricting their ability to intervene in adoption proceedings was unconstitutional.

LEAD: The prosecution reached the midway point of its case in the Central Park rape trial yesterday, introducing additional photographs that showed the extent of the jogger's injuries.

LEAD: A. Donald MacKinnon, a lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, &amp; McCloy for nearly 50 years, died on June 21 at the Seabrook Health Center in Hilton Head Island, S.C.
He was 94 years old and moved to Hilton Head recently from Summit, N.J.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary last Wednesday about Gustave Harrow, Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York in the battle over the estate of the artist Mark Rothko, referred incompletely to the suit against Rothko's executors.
The heirs accused the executors not only of mismanaging the estate but also of conspiring with the Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan to defraud it.

LEAD: The California Supreme Court has ruled that patients have no right to share in profits if their blood or organs become the source of lucrative scientific research.

LEAD: Vernon Grant, a magazine and book illustrator who was the creator of the Kellogg's cereal characters Snap, Crackle and Pop, died on Monday at a nursing home where he had been staying for several weeks.
He was 88 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a German-born scientist seeking to regain his United States citizenship referred incorrectly to the V-2, a World War II weapon on which he worked.
It was a ballistic rocket, not a flying drone or buzz bomb.

Ads That Bash the Japanese: Just Jokes or Veiled Racism?
LEAD: American advertisers are stepping up their attacks on Japan and its people, attempting to thwart sales of Japanese products through commercials that feature ominous references to the late Emperor Hirohito, photographs of Samurai warriors, exaggerated accents and veiled ridicule of the Japanese physique.

LEAD: New York State's highest court yesterday let stand a lower court order suspending Alton H. Maddox Jr., who represented Tawana Brawley and other clients in racially sensitive cases, from practicing law.

Review/Music;   Recalling the 70's Magic
LEAD: When Jackson Browne released his first album 18 years ago, the Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter brought a deeply personal strain of romantic idealism to the folk-pop movement.
Steeped in the utopianism of Southern California's hippie culture, Mr.
Browne wrote visionary love songs and meditations that had dark premonitory undercurrents.

LEAD: The American Red Cross has delayed reporting or has failed to report to the Federal Government hundreds of errors it has made in handling contaminated blood, a Federal inspector reports.

LEAD: A television reporter was freed today from the jail where he had served two weeks for refusing to identify a person who helped him get a telephone interview with a jailed murder suspect.


Senator Says A Bidder Urged Test of Telescope
LEAD: The losing bid to build the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope called for a test that would have detected the flaw that has blurred its vision before it was ever launched into orbit, Senator Albert Gore Jr. said today.


Increases Voted on Rent-Stabilized Units
LEAD: In a decision that dissatisfied both landlords and tenants, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night approved rent increases of 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases in rent-stabilized apartments.


Eric M. Rogers, 87; Teacher Humanized Physics' Complexity
LEAD: Eric M. Rogers, a professor emeritus of physics at Princeton University who was known for his exuberance in explaining complex principles to non-science students, died on July 1 during a visit to Cambridge, England.
He was 87 years old.

LEAD: Eric M. Warburg, an international banker and a member of the German banking family, died on Monday at his home in Hamburg, West Germany.

Tin Group Nears End
LEAD: The International Tin Council, which never recovered from the 1985 collapse of its plans to support the price of tin, said last week that it would vote on July 31 to disband.
The Tin Council, made up of 22 tin-consuming and producing countries, no longer has any reason to continue after it settled its debts in March from a long-running case that followed the collapse of its buffer stock operations.

Dirty Schools: Will a New Contract Help Clean Them?
LEAD: A little more than two years ago, before the signing of a contract hailed as the start of a new era in school maintenance, New York City school custodians cleaned classrooms every other day, cafeterias once a week and mopped floors three times a year.
Head custodians were paid almost $20,000 more than the average teacher and about $7,000 less than the average principal.


Waterford Strike
LEAD: Workers at Waterford Crystal glass works in Ireland ended a 14-week strike today after agreeing on cost-cutting proposals with management.The strike by 2,300 workers at Waterford's three plants began on April 5 over cost cuts, including the scrapping of bonuses for 500 glass cutters.
Waterford said management and unions had agreed to refer issues on pay and conditions still in dispute to binding arbitration.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Squeaky Floors
Q.
I have a one-story house that was built in 1968 and has hardwood floors.
Practically all these floors squeak when someone walks across them.
Can I cure the squeaking by working from under the house and driving wood screws up through the subflooring and into the finished flooring?

Wheeler Peak
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it had received a preliminary expression of interest about an acquisition by the Wheeler Peak Capital Corporation.
The company said Wheeler Peak had not submitted a formal proposal but had suggested a deal in which Public Service shareholders would receive $12 a share in cash and a portion of the common equity of the surviving company.

German Funds Frozen
LEAD: East Germany said today that it had frozen 56 new hard-currency bank accounts containing tens of millions of marks on suspicion that the sums were amassed through illegal speculation.
East Germany adopted the West German mark as its currency when the two Germanys merged their economies on July 1.
A Government spokesman, Matthias Gehler, said huge sums had been deposited in some special exchange accounts set up by citizens before the economic union, prompting investigations of 60,000 cases.

LEAD: The Advertising column on March 9, about advertising to minorities, omitted a name among founders of the Mingo Group agency.
In addition to Frank L. Mingo Jr. and Caroline R. Jones, they included Richard A. Guilmenot 3d.
Mr.
Guilmenot recently pointed out the error after a letter he wrote in March failed to arrive at The Times.

Market Place;   Finding a Forum For Arbitration
LEAD: THE legal view of where investors' disputes with their brokers can be arbitrated is becoming increasingly muddled.
State and Federal courts disagree sharply; Federal regulators are undecided, and state lawmakers, sympathetic to the consumer, are adopting statutes that fly in the face of brokers' preference for industry-run arbitration panels.


Citing Study, Cuomo Urges a Drop in Milk Prices
LEAD: In a practice that state officials called unfair and unfortunate, New York retailers reduced the price of milk only slightly this spring after the farm price of milk plummeted from the record levels of last winter, according to a state report released today.


U.S. ADMITS PERIL OF 40'S EMISSIONS AT A-BOMB PLANT
LEAD: The Energy Department today acknowledged for the first time that the doses of radiation produced by an atomic weapons plant here in the 1940's and 1950's were high enough to cause illnesses, including cancer, in residents of the Pacific Northwest.

Corrections
LEAD: A article on Tuesday about labor negotiations at The Daily News referred incorrectly in some copies to a statute that empowers New York State to inquire into labor disputes.
It is 49 years old, not 39.

New Therapy Shown to Fight Bone Loss in Elderly
LEAD: The largest study ever conducted on osteoporosis has confirmed that a new treatment can strengthen elderly women's brittle bones and greatly reduce the risk of painful and deforming spinal fractures.


Architects Expand Use Of Glass Art
LEAD: PEOPLE who live in glass houses have begun to color the door, etch the windows and cloud the view.
The artists who create this haunting choreography - transforming the game of tag between sun and shadow into an architectural play of light - are glassmakers.
And the modernization of their medieval craft is invigorating both architecture and art.


Rear Adm. Paul Foley, Ex-Hofstra Official, 81
LEAD: Rear Adm.
Paul Foley Jr., former head of the Command and Staff Department of the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., and a retired Hofstra University official, died on Saturday at his home in Manhasset, N.Y.
He was 81 years old and died of pnuemonia and congestive heart failure, his wife, Cornelia, said.


Amid Discord, Talks on Boat People Are Put Off
LEAD: A 28-nation conference on Vietnamese boat people was postponed today when it became apparent that differences between the United States and Vietnam on one side and the Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong on the other have not been bridged.


Trottier Disappointed
LEAD: A week after being released by the Islanders for whom he had played 15 seasons, Bryan Trottier yesterday issued a statement titled ''Trottier Bids Farewell to Islander Fans,'' in which he said he hoped to play a minimum of two more years in the National Hockey League.

Summit Promise - and Shame;   A Chance, at Least, for Fair Farm Policy
LEAD: The Houston summit meeting resolved no important dispute.
The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations did more agreeing to disagree than agreeing.
But to judge their annual economic conference a failure is hasty.
The leaders differed about how to aid the Soviet Union.
Dismayingly, they condoned help for China.

LEAD: DeSoto Inc., which has been fending off a hostile takeover attempt since last year, announced today that it planned to sell most of the company's operations and distribute the proceeds to shareholders.

LEAD: Salad-bar tortellini has never looked as pathetic as it does in ''No Picnic,'' where the black-and-white photography gives it the color and texture of dingy gray sweat socks.
There are just a few close-ups of the dreary salad bar in Philip Hartman's 1986 film, which opens today at Anthology Film Archives after having made the rounds of several smaller film festivals.

Review/Music;   Mostly Mozart Opens, With Humor
LEAD: Mozart worship is, on the whole, a healthy thing.
It testifies to the possibility that vestiges of good sense may still be found in modern society.
Still, it does no harm occasionally to face the truth: even he sometimes had to produce music when the fires of inspiration flickered low.
One such work, ''Der Schauspieldirektor,'' a jocular singspiel known in English as ''The Impresario,'' served on Tuesday evening as the centerpiece of the opening concert of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival.

LEAD: A colleague and former roommate of the Central Park jogger testified yesterday that his friend's face was so disfigured after she was beaten that it took him nearly 15 minutes to identify her at the hospital.


Richard B. Bernstein, 66, Is Dead; A Pioneer in Modern Chemistry
LEAD: Richard B. Bernstein, who pioneered a branch of science that studies details of the ultrafast processes that occur in chemical reactions, died in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday.
He was 66 years old.


Summer, Children And 'War of the Exes'
LEAD: FOR legions of divorced fathers, a ritual is under way.
A time of love and reunion, it can also be an agony of dashed hopes and recrimination.
It is the extended summer visit with the children, an arrangement included in most divorce settlements, which in 9 of 10 cases give custody to the mother.

19 Years Later, Father Asks New Inquiry on Police Killing
LEAD: Even after 19 years, Thomas Emma keeps his pain packed in a box, dragging it out for anyone who asks.
Marked ''Court Records,'' the box contains the facts and files that bring to life, time after time, the night in 1971 when Mr.
Emma's 17-year-old son, Anthony, was shot and killed by a Paramus police officer.

TENNIS
Edberg Struggles
Three days after winning the Wimbledon championship, Stefan Edberg had to struggle yesterday to beat Tommy Ho of the United States, 2-6, 7-6, 6-4, in the first round of the Gunze World tournament in Osaka, Japan.
Jaime Yzaga of Peru beat Jason Stoltenberg of Australia, 6-1, 6-3.


Chronicle
LEAD: PEARL BAILEY's left knee was replaced yesterday in a 55-minute operation at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. ''Everthing went according to plan,'' said the chief surgeon, Dr.
RICHARD H. ROTHMAN. ''There were no surprises.'' The 72-year-old singer received a new knee joint of plastic and metal.

Yesterday, he was hired as general manager of the Denver Nuggets.(AP)

Joseph Sloan; Food Executive, 81
LEAD: Joseph Sloan, the owner of a supermarket chain in the Bronx, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
