N.B.A.'s Games Contribute To 16% Profit Gain at CBS
LEAD: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its net income had risen 16 percent in the second quarter, in part because of one-time gains from the National Basketball Association's games and lower programming costs.


Senate Votes Sweeping Crime Bill, Banning Some Assault Weapons
LEAD: The Senate today overwhemingly approved a crime bill that includes a temporary ban on the sale and manufacture of certain semiautomatic assault weapons, greater Federal assistance to law-enforcement agencies and an expansion of the number of Federal crimes for which the death penalty can be imposed.


Democratic Chief Considers Cutting Convention for TV
LEAD: Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, said today that he was thinking of shortening the party's 1992 Presidential convention to help make it more interesting to television viewers and thus television broadcasters, both of whom have been tuning out.

Talking Deals;   Bid for Kay Stirs Bondholders' Ire
LEAD: GIVEN the turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market over the last 12 months, holders of the highly leveraged securities should be accustomed to bad news.
But the recent offer by Ratners Group P.L.C., the world's largest jewelry retailer, to acquire Kay Jewelers Inc. for about $410 million in a stock swap has left many of bondholders upset by what they regard as the sheer brazenness of the proposed transaction.

LEAD: Seeking an urgent solution to violent political clashes that have shaken her Government, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said today that she would reopen negotiations with Sandinista unions and political leaders if they acted to end recent protests and restore public order.

LEAD: The National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors is expected to issue a report on Thursday stating that the American electronics industry is endangered by a decline in strength of the American companies that produce sophisticated equipment and materials for making computer chips.

LEAD: Bozell has appointed Kim Gaynor general manager of Bozell Detroit.
He will replace George Beech, who will remain a consultant to the Detroit office during the transition.
Dennis F. Visich, the chief operating officer of Warwick Baker &amp; Fiore, will replace Mr.
Gaynor as executive vice president and director of client services at Bozell Dallas.

Ethiopia Said to Cut Off Flight of Jews in Effort to Gain Israeli Arms
LEAD: Ethiopia has interrupted the emigration of Ethiopian Jews, apparently in an attempt to compel Israel to send it more weapons, according to the chairman of a Congressional panel on Africa.


2 New York Officials Attack Phone Request
LEAD: Two senior state officials yesterday strongly criticized a $1.4 billion rate increase sought by the New York Telephone Company, and said that the New York Public Service Commission should reverse its decision to allow the company to choose what information in the rate increase request is labeled a trade secret and sealed.


Economic Scene;   Deep Divisions At Summit Talks
LEAD: The Houston summit conference was a successful holding operation.
In the face of conflicts over aid to the Soviet Union, the elimination of agricultural subsidies and actions to deal with environmental pollution and global warming, the leaders of the seven major industrial countries preserved their civility and produced a set of compromises that will enable them to go on working together a while longer.


Liberian Army's 'Reign of Terror' Protested by U.S. and Other Embassies
LEAD: What many residents of this city call a ''reign of terror'' by Government troops against unarmed civilians thought to sympathize with rebels in this country's six-month-old civil war has worsened in recent weeks, diplomats and Liberian and foreign journalists say, prompting several embassies to file official protests.


Greenspan Talk Spurs Bond Rally
LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose and short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, strongly suggested to Congress that the central bank was on the verge of easing monetary policy.

Arlington Race May Have Only 6
LEAD: The showdown at Arlington Park on Aug. 4 among Criminal Type, Easy Goer and Sunday Silence might just as well be a three-horse race.
Only three others are likely to run and they seem to be gunning for no more than fourth place.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Wilander Beaten in Second Round
Mats Wilander's comeback suffered a setback yesterday when the Swede was beaten by Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-2, 3-6, 7-6, in the second round of the Swedish Open in Bastad.
Wilander, ranked No. 1 in the world before slipping and then taking a five-month break, made several unforced errors in losing the third-set tie breaker.

LEAD: A 33-year-old messenger in the Time-Life Building was arrested yesterday and charged as the mysterious attacker who blew darts at well-dressed women in midtown Manhattan.

Merger in France
LEAD: In one of the biggest mergers in French corporate history, the water utility Lyonnaise des Eaux will join with the construction company Dumez, creating a company with 100,000 employees and annual revenue of about $14.9 billion.
The merger will be through an exchange of four Lyonnaise shares for three Dumez shares.


Marvin S. Pittler, Executive, 61
LEAD: Marvin S. Pittler, vice president of manufacturing research for I.B.M.
Research, died on Wednesday at his office in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
He was 61 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
The cause of death apparently was a heart attack, a spokesman for the company said.


Farm Trade Discussed
LEAD: Negotiators began discussing a compromise plan today to cut subsidies in world farm trade, a proposal that leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies backed at their economic summit meeting in Houston this week.


Impasse Ends on U.S. Bill to Aid Europe
LEAD: The Bush Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have reached agreement on the structure of an economic aid package for Eastern Europe that would allow the President to provide technical help to Moscow for the first time, Administration and Congressional officials said today.


Albany: More Errors Than Hits
LEAD: Sadly, it's easier this year to list Albany's sins of omission than its achievements.
The Legislature approved the state budget seven weeks late, at great cost to the taxpayer.
It failed to revise the inequitable school aid formula to direct more money to New York City and other needy districts.
It failed to impose new penalties for bias-related violence.

Scents and Sport
LEAD: Walk along a weedy roadside or an unmowed field, especially toward the end of a heavy summer day, and suddenly you are surrounded by surprising flowery smells from a couple of commonplace plants.
The bright, heady scent is from honeysuckle, an aggressive and unwelcome vine that climbs everywhere.
The musky scent comes from the gawky milkweed, whose clustered flowers summon up the poet's perfumes of Araby.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump took the witness stand yesterday to deny seven-year-old charges that he knowingly used 200 undocumented workers to demolish the old Bonwit Teller building to make way for Trump Tower, the glittering centerpiece of his real-estate empire.

Review/Photography;   Beauty and Challenge In Modern Landscapes
LEAD: One of the tasks of the art of the last 10 years has been to reconstruct the notion of natural beauty in the face of a seemingly endless onslaught against nature.
Mankind's alteration of previously pristine spaces, from tropical rain forests to the very air we breathe, poses a challenge that is not only environmental, but also esthetic: can art reflect what is happening to the natural world while retaining its traditional attachment to the sublime?

English, Language of Summits
LEAD: English is the lingua franca of summitry.
At NATO summit meetings, France's representatives still make a point of speaking French in plenary sessions, but in the corridors they converse informally in English.
At economic summit meetings, some leaders still rely on translators, but the sherpas who accompany them to the summit do their communique drafting in English.

Restaurants
LEAD: In today's perilous marketplace, one might think it imprudent to tinker with a winning formula.
Yet Richard Lavin, the affable and savvy restaurateur who owns Sofi on lower Fifth Avenue and Lavin's on West 39th Street, has done just that.
He has taken the popular Sofi, which served inventive American food for three years, and made it northern Italian - a move that seems akin to converting the New York Mets to a soccer team.

LEAD: As President Reagan's Secretary of Transportation, Elizabeth Dole was criticized for not pushing companies to install passive restraints - air bags and automatic seat belts - in cars.

LEAD: Supplies of corn and soybeans appear tight, while wheat supplies are swelling with a big harvest, the Agriculture Department reported today in its monthly crop report.

ARNOLD RELMAN , editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine, is to retire next June after 14 years at the helm of the prestigious chronicle of medical research.
Dr.
Relman, who is 67 years old, said he plans to write, teach and lecture.
The weekly magazine is owned and published by the Massachusetts Medical Society, which is to form a committee to select a successor to Dr.


No Headline
LEAD: For the first time since testimony began nearly three weeks ago, the jury in the Central Park attack trial yesterday heard evidence linking one defendant with the rape and attempted murder of a jogger.


Louisiana Governor Tells of Quandary Over Bill to Ban Abortion
LEAD: When Gov.
Buddy Roemer of Louisiana was elected three years ago, he overthrew the political establishment by promising to make the tough decisions that others would not face.
Now he faces a decision that he says he is finding nearly impossible to make.


Investors Warned on Global Frauds
LEAD: Small investors were defrauded of $1.1 billion in the last two years through international investment swindles, the North American Securities Administrators Association told a Congressional committee yesterday.


Cray President Leaves In Rift With Chairman
LEAD: Marcelo A. Gumucio, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research Inc., resigned yesterday, saying that he and Cray's chairman, John A. Rollwagen, had agreed that their contrasting management styles made it impossible to work together.


Pirates Edge Padres By 4-3 in 15th Inning
LEAD: Jeff King's two-out single down the right-field line in the 15th inning ended a bullpen duel and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory tonight over San Diego, spoiling the debut of the new Padres manager, Greg Riddoch.

LEAD: Not long into their respective tenures as Governors of New York and New Jersey, Mario M. Cuomo and Jim Florio each audaciously expressed political philosophies of unapologetic liberalism.


U.S. Presents Anti-Drug Curriculum for Schools
LEAD: The Department of Education today issued a detailed program for drug prevention lessons that it will send to more than 120,000 school administrators across the country, in an effort to teach children skills for resisting drug use.

I.B.M.-Diebold Joint Venture
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and Diebold Inc. said they would combine their automated teller machine operations and develop and market new and existing products worldwide under a joint venture.


Waltrip Departs
LEAD: Darrell Waltrip, the Nascar driver, yesterday was released from the hospital in Daytona Beach, Fla., where he was recovering from injuries suffered last week during a practice run for the Pepsi 400.
Waltrip was flown to Nashville to continue his recovery from a broken left thigh bone and a dislocated bone in his left arm, said Larry Balewski, spokesman for Daytona International Speedway.

United Resolve Marked Conference on AIDS
LEAD: To the Editor:


Sudan Forces Refugees Back to Barren Lands
LEAD: In a new tactic in the seven-year Sudanese civil war, the Khartoum Government is forcing tens of thousands of refugees who fled to Khartoum from the south to return home, further straining food supplies in the famine-struck region, relief workers and village chiefs here say.


Cuomo Unafraid of Health Veto
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he would not care about the potential political fallout of vetoing a major health-care bill in this election year, but he said he has not decided whether to sign or kill the legislation.

LEAD: Patty Sheehan and Nancy Lopez spurred each other to their best starts ever today in the United States Women's Open, the biggest tournament neither has ever won.


Where to Hear the Seminar Performers
LEAD: The New Music Seminar will run through Wednesday at various clubs in New York City and New Jersey.
A series ticket of $95 is good for admission to all regular performances and to one of five gala performances next week.
The series ticket will be available today and tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Village Voice, 842 Broadway, at 13th Street.

Abitibi Explores Recycled Paper
LEAD: Abitibi-Pricei Inc., the giant Canadian forest-products company, and two British publishers agreed to buy a venture that has been exploring building a newsprint plant in Scotland that would use only recycled fiber.
The partners are two London-based companies: The Daily Telegraph P.L.C., led by Conrad Black, and Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd., led by Robert Maxwell.

FED CONSIDERS CUT IN INTEREST RATES TO BOOST ECONOMY
LEAD: Expressing concern that banks have become overly cautious in lending money, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the central bank might need to cut interest rates to keep the economy moving ahead.


A $45 MILLION LOSS IS CITED ON LOANS TIED TO NEIL BUSH
LEAD: As a director of a Denver savings institution, Neil Bush voted to approve loans for a close business associate that resulted in a loss to the Government of at least $45 million, according to documents released by Federal regulators.


In Coal Fields of Siberia, Memories of a Promise
LEAD: ''What kind of masters are we?'' asked the miner, gray and lean and angry in his ebony moonscape of a workplace here in the rebellious coal fields of Siberia.

Administration Is Cool To Tougher Spy Laws
LEAD: The Bush Administration reacted coolly today to some parts of a bipartisan Senate proposal to toughen Federal espionage laws, saying a number of the steps proposed were better left to the White House than to Congress.


In Washington, a Battle About a Prosecutor

Japan's Trade Surplus Rises
LEAD: A surge in exports widened Japan's trade surplus by 27.5 percent in June, causing some analysts to believe that an 18-month shrinking of the trade imbalance may be over.

Marc Haas, Philatelist, Dies at 82; His Collection Netted $11 Million
LEAD: Marc Haas, a philatelist and business executive, died on Sunday at his home in Burgenstock, Switzerland.
He was 82 years old and also had a home in Manhattan.


Pauperized Workers Are Price of 'Free' Trade
LEAD: To the Editor:


After The Cold War (2)
LEAD: Through most of its history this has been an unmilitarized country.
The Framers of the Constitution wanted it that way.
To prevent a large standing army becoming a habit, they provided that Congress could not appropriate money for the military ''for a longer term than two years.''

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 512 money market mutual funds increased $3.10 billion, to $385.83 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $215.40 million, to $91.82 billion.
The assets of the 250 general-purpose funds were up by $763.50 million, to $133.98 billion.


Robert B. Davies, Accountant, 72
LEAD: Robert B. Davies, a certified public accountant in Manhattan for 35 years, died on Wednesday.
He was 72 years old and lived in White Plains.


German Knife-Wielder Insane
LEAD: A woman who tried to kill West Germany's opposition candidate for Chancellor, Oskar Lafontaine, by attacking him with a knife is unfit to face trial and should be confined to a psychiatric hospital, prosecutors said today.
They said that the woman, Adelheid Streidel, 43 years old, was schizophrenic and asked a court not to proceed against her.


Oil Prices Surge as Saudis Agree to Reduce Output
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and byproducts soared yesterday on the news that Saudi Arabia had agreed to reduce its oil output temporarily to bolster sagging oil prices.

Review/Art;   Plaster as a Medium, Not Just an Interim Step
LEAD: ''The Expressionist Surface: Contemporary Art in Plaster,'' at the Queens Museum, calls attention to the current prominence of plaster.
With its modeled, carved, cast and rolled plaster, with its plaster boulders, tapestries, mannequins and horses, the exhibition suggests the many ways the material is now being used in sculpture, painting and installations.


Wayne J. Turnage, 47, An Operatic Baritone
LEAD: Wayne Jackson Turnage, a baritone who sang with the Washington Opera and Opera Ebony, died at his home in New York on Monday after a long illness.
He was 47 years old.

Radiation Peril at Hanford Is Detailed
LEAD: One in every 20 residents of 10 counties surrounding the Hanford nuclear weapons plant here absorbed ''significant'' amounts of radiation in three years ending December 1947, a panel of radiation and health experts said in a report released today.


Cuomo to Move His Own Funds Over Apartheid
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo, who for years has berated Republicans for blocking his efforts to rid New York State of any possible links to South Africa, announced tonight that he was withdrawing his own money from two financial institutions that have been made targets by a prominent anti-apartheid group.

Beating Japan at Its Own Game
LEAD: The story is familiar: An American company develops and dominates a consumer electronics market, only to lose it to lower-cost competitors from East Asia.
It happened with color television sets, calculators, digital watches and computer games, among many other products.


Barry Witness Says He Worried About Effect of Drugs on Mayor
LEAD: Describing himself as someone who had shared drugs with Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and loved him like a twin brother, a Washington advertising executive testified today that he worried about the effect that frequent cocaine use was having on the Mayor's ability to govern.


Plea Deal Talks in Vento Case
LEAD: Preliminary discussions to arrange a possible plea bargain for John S. Vento have begun in the Bensonhurst murder case, a law-enforcement official said yesterday.


The Talk of Sullivan County;   Victory Leaves a Prosecutor With an Orphaned Court
LEAD: More than two years after the Sullivan County District Attorney's office asked, in an anonymous complaint, that a state judicial commission investigate the county court judge here, prosecutors have emerged triumphant in theory, if a little traumatized in practice.


A Clowning Bank-Robbery Caper
''What kind of clown are you?'' a bank guard snarls at a man in a circus costume, who has wedged one giant red shoe in the door at closing time.
Beneath his painted smile, Bill Murray assumes the most serious, sincere expression and answers sweetly, ''The crying-on-the-inside kind, I guess.''
After Mr.
Murray's character, Grimm, robs the bank and takes some hostages, the police chief bargains on the phone for their release. ''At least give me the women,'' the chief pleads, and Grimm yelps, ''Get your own women!''

Contel Agrees to Takeover Offer by GTE
LEAD: In a move that would sharply expand both its local telephone operations and its fast-growing cellular telephone business, the GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Contel Corporation to acquire the Atlanta-based company in a stock swap.
The deal would be worth about $6 billion, based on yesterday's closing stock prices.

Manila Tourist Areas Hit by 6 Bomb Blasts
LEAD: Six bombs exploded simultaneously before dawn today in the city's main tourist and financial districts, damaging several cars and buildings but causing no casualties, the police said.


Oil Spill Compromise Calls for Double Hulls
LEAD: A Congressional conference committee drafting legislation on oil spills decided today to require almost all oil tankers to be equipped with protective double hulls, phasing in the change over the next 20 years.


Government Seeks to Extend Ban On Broadcast of Offensive Shows
LEAD: Armed with new information about the viewing and listening habits of children, the Federal Communications Commission made a new effort today to impose a complete ban on what it considers indecent radio and television broadcasts.


Monoclonal Backs Quidel Acquisition
LEAD: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc., which sells fertility-test kits, said it had reached an agreement with the privately held Quidel Corporation under which Monoclonal would exchange about 9.7 million of its common shares for all shares of Quidel.


Review/Theater;   Shakespeare in the Wild West, in the Park
LEAD: If Cole Porter and company could transplant ''The Taming of the Shrew'' to sedate, late 1940's Baltimore, why can't the New York Shakespeare Festival let Kate and Petruchio have their standoff in the wild, late 19th-century West?
A.
J.
Antoon's rambunctious production of Shakespeare's comedy, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, turns out to be its own best argument.


Republicans on the Attack In Savings and Loan Crisis
LEAD: Unnerved by the rising public outrage over the nation's savings and loan scandal, the Republican Party opened an orchestrated effort today to blame the Democrats before the Democrats succeed in their effort to blame the Republicans.


Rating of Time Warner
LEAD: The Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation said this week that it had affirmed Time Warner Inc.'s BB-rated long-term debt and B-plus subordinated debt and preferred stock ratings.
The securities were removed from S.&amp;P.'s Creditwatch, where they had been placed for possible downgrading.
Roughly $1.5 billion of long-term debt and $5.6 billion of preferred stock are affected.

King Tells the Court Of Parrying Tactics
LEAD: Don King yesterday ended about 13 hours of loquacious testimony over two and a half days in the trial of his breach-of-contract suit against James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and John Johnson, his manager.


Nova Scotia Issue
LEAD: A $300 million debenture issue by Nova Scotia was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.375 percent debentures due to mature in 2002 are offered at 99.36 percent to yield 9.465 percent, or about 95 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

LEAD: In a letter to Commissioner Fay Vincent, attorneys for George Steinbrenner have finally replied on the procedure for the remaining portion of baseball's investigation of the Yankee owner's activities.
But Vincent declined to say today what the reply was.

Casino Revenues Rise
LEAD: Revenues at Atlantic City's casinos rose 13.3 percent in June from a year earlier, helped by the $34.8 million net ''win'' reported at Donald J. Trump's new Taj Mahal casino, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said today.
Gaming revenues amounted to $258.5 million in the month, but only four casinos had higher winnings than in June 1989.


Sandinistas End Strike as Chamorro Yields on Key Demands
LEAD: The Government and Sandinista unions reached agreement early today on a package of wage raises, job guarantees and political concessions, ending a 10-day walkout by Sandinista-led Government workers that had paralyzed the nation and provoked violent clashes between armed Sandinista and pro-Government demonstrators.

Baruch M. Bokser, 44, A Professor of Talmud
LEAD: Baruch M. Bokser, a professor of Talmud and rabbinical studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center.
He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Curtiss-Wright to Pay $30-a-Share Dividend
LEAD: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, a diversified aerospace components manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had declared a one-time dividend of $30 a share.


Scientists Discover the Gene In a Nervous System Disease
LEAD: After three years of struggling to overcome frustrating technical snags and red herrings, scientists have isolated the gene that causes the disfiguring and sometimes fatal condition known as Elephant Man's disease.


In a Shift, Beijing Shrugs at Fang's Criticism
LEAD: In China's first official response to criticism over the last week from the exiled dissident Fang Lizhi, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that his conduct was not worth discussing.


Hawkins Loses Another No-Hitter, but Not His
LEAD: The Yankees are learning to expect the unexpected whenever Andy Hawkins starts a game, and they got it for the third successive time last night.
Melido Perez pitched a rain-shortened six-inning no-hitter against Hawkins and the Yankees and led the Chicago White Sox to an 8-0 victory at Yankee Stadium.

Mistrial Ruled for Mulheren
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan declared a mistrial yesterday on 26 felony counts against John A. Mulheren Jr., the securities trader already convicted of illegal dealings with the stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky.


Refugee Ships Leave for Albania
LEAD: Ships from three nations sailed today to a rendezvous off Albania in a sea lift of more than 4,500 Albanians seeking to escape their homeland, Europe's last haven for hard-line Communists.


Eugene Levy, 63, Republican Member of New York Senate
LEAD: State Senator Eugene Levy, a Republican from Suffern, N.Y., who had served in the State Legislature since 1969, died yesterday in Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla.
He was 63 years old.


Italian Climbs Into Lead; LeMond Gains
LEAD: A day after he became the man to beat in the Tour de France, Ronan Pensec was beaten badly in an individual time trial and lost the overall leader's yellow jersey.

Hyannis Journal;   Rose Kennedy at 100: Still Very Much Rose
LEAD: On Sunday, after Mass in her rambling seaside home here, Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy was sitting on the porch with her daughter Eunice Shriver and her grandson Robert Shriver.


William M. Weil, Manufacturer, 89
LEAD: William M. Weil, a retired manufacturer of specialized lighting, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Rockwell Stock
LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said its board had extended the company's stock repurchase program by an additional $500 million.
It said that the program was started in March 1986 and extended in $500 million increments in March 1987 and December 1988.
Rockwell said that at current prices, the extended program would reduce common shares outstanding by about 7.5 percent.

KREMLIN MAVERICK LEAVES THE PARTY; MORE MAY FOLLOW
LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the popular maverick of Soviet politics, announced today that he was quitting the Communist Party, dealing a sharp new blow to the once-monolithic force even as it struggled to stay united.


Six Nights for Sampling A World of Unsung Bands
LEAD: IN the next six days, 400 bands from around the world will pile into Manhattan as part of this year's New Music Seminar, an annual music-industry convention.
More than 30 nightclubs will overflow with the sounds of Spanish flamenco, Swedish hard-core, British hip-hop and industrial disco, German heavy metal and New York noise rock.


Review/Film;   Looking to the Dead For Mirth and Inspiration
LEAD: Current Hollywood thinking extends into the next world, but not very far.
Being dead has lately been presented on screen as a character-building experience, but beyond that the current ghost films hedge their bets.
The questions of just what ghosts can do, of what effect ghosts may have on others or even of how ghosts regard their new status are seldom even addressed.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: For 10 years, the New York Public Library has bestowed its Literary Lions awards on contemporary writers, men and women whose works range from the urban sociology of Tom Wolfe to history in the making by Henry A. Kissinger or the novels of Toni Morrison and the plays of Edward Albee.
Many of the 200 award recipients will be honored at the library on Nov.


Paramount Lifts TV Stake
LEAD: Paramount Communications Inc. has increased its majority stake to 83.3 percent in a company that owns six television stations and has offered to buy the remaining interest for about $52 million.


G.M.A.C. Prices A Note Offering
LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is offering $200 million in senior notes due in 2005 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


AT THE BAR
LEAD: There is nothing odd about lawyers' showing up in the Albany City Courthouse.
But over the past few months and continuing through the summer, a steady stream of lawyers are coming before the court in a most unusual capacity: as defendants.

William Borden of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening at the Tam O'Shanter Club in Brookville, L.I., to Dr.

Space Program Builds America's Future;   Big-Science Bubble
LEAD: To the Editor:
Double, double, toil and trouble;
Challenger lost, and now it's Hubble.
Mirror faulty, image shake.
Water freeze, O ring break.
Heirs of Newton set aside.
Bottom line: cost override.
Double, double, toil and trouble;
Time to prick big-science bubble.
WILLIAM VOLK

LEAD: The prospect of lower interest rates and higher corporate profits pushed stock prices to record levels yesterday.

John H. Baer, Executive, 71
LEAD: John H. Baer, a textile industry executive, died on Tuesday at the Hotel Norfolk in Nairobi, Kenya, while on a business trip.
He was 71 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.


Florio Signs and Explains Tax Rise
LEAD: The battle over how to explain the largest tax increase in New Jersey history was joined by Gov.
Jim Florio today, as he signed the bill to raise $1.25 billion in new income taxes.
He described the action as property-tax relief for the middle class.


Repricing Calls Abroad
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it wants to change the international phone pricing system so that carriers can compete fairly and charge consumers less to call overseas.


Review/Ballet;   A 2d Cast in Bolshoi 'Swan Lake'
LEAD: More than one film or novel (usually comic) has concerned itself with the intrigues and gossip inherent in the ballet world.
But in the end, the only thing that matters is what takes place on stage.


Disney Tells Mowgli's Tales
LEAD: Its setting notwithstanding, ''The Jungle Book'' presents Walt Disney-style animation at its most urbane.
First released in 1967 and last shown theatrically in 1984, this full-length animated feature, which opens nationwide today, has a droll wit guaranteed to keep parents as well entertained as their children.


Democrats Retreating On Inquiry
LEAD: Democratic leaders pounded the Republicans over the savings and loan scandal today.
But the attempt to compel the Attorney General to consider appointing an independent prosecutor in the case of Neil Bush appeared to founder as Republican leaders threatened to retaliate by seeking an outside prosecutor to look into the actions of former Democratic leaders.

LEAD: A lawyer for a Bronx man accused of blowing homemade darts at women said yesterday that the evidence against his client is flimsy and the charges motivated by the publicity surrounding the attacks.

LEAD: Beach Towel rallied midway through the stretch tonight and captured the $1,153,500 Meadowlands Pace by a nose over Jake and Elwood.

Protectionism?
Recession?


Review/Music;   Against All Odds: A 'Village' Festival
LEAD: For sheer feistiness, few classical-music series rival the Washington Square Music Festival, which has stood up to the vicissitudes of its Greenwich Village surroundings for more than three decades.
In recent years, with the park overrun by successive drug cultures, the setting has often seemed unwelcoming, if not actively hostile.

LEAD: ''I want to change my life.
I want to lead a better life.
I don't want Communism.''
- Eno Vaso, an Albanian who fled to Italy. [5:5.]


Bahamas Facing More Questions As It Buries 39 Drowned Haitians
LEAD: Thirty-nine Haitians fleeing their impoverished Caribbean island drowned when their sailboat capsized and sank in choppy seas while being towed by Bahamian authorities, Government officials said.


Evolution in Europe;   20,000 in Bucharest Demand Release of Student
LEAD: More than 20,000 people gathered outside government buildings in Bucharest today in the biggest opposition protest since the December uprising that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator.


U.S. Policy on Cambodia Shifts a Bit
LEAD: In a break from past policy of shunning the Cambodian Government, the Bush Administration announced today that it had accepted an offer by Phnom Penh to cooperate in examining what could be the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.


Airbus Industrie
LEAD: Airbus Industrie declined to comment on a French newspaper report that the European aircraft consortium had sharply cut its losses in 1989.
Airbus would say only that it expected to break even sooner than originally forecast.
Quoting sources in the industry, La Tribune de l'Expansion, a Paris daily, reported that Airbus had cut its losses to $150 million last year, from $508 million in 1988.


McDonnell Stock Climbs on Rumors
LEAD: The stock of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation moved higher today amid rumors and speculation about the struggling military contractor's future.
McDonnell Douglas's shares rose $1.25 each, to $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Rights Bill for Disabled Is Sent to Bush
LEAD: The Senate today completed Congressional action on a far-reaching bill to bar discrimination against people with physical and mental disabilities.


British Inflation at 9.8%
LEAD: Britain's inflation rate, among the highest in the industrial world, climbed again in June, reaching an eight-year high of 9.8 percent, the Government said today.
The increase in the retail price index, from 9.7 percent in May, was slightly below economists' forecasts.
But the underlying rate of inflation, which excludes home loans and the poll tax, fell to 6.9 percent, from 7 percent in May, the Central Statistical Office said.


Inmate Executed in Alabama For 1976 Murder of Woman
LEAD: A black man convicted of murder 12 years ago read a statement denouncing the death penalty as racist and then was strapped into Alabama's electric chair and executed early today.

LEAD: The staff of the state's utility regulating board recommended today that a rate increase sought by New York Telephone be denied and the company be forced to cut its rates instead.


Rates Fall On Moves By Fed
LEAD: The Federal Reserve took steps yesterday that lowered interest rates, a day after the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested that lower rates might be needed to stimulate the economy and alleviate a tightening of credit by major banks.

LEAD: A biotechnology company in New Jersey won a patent this week for a method of preventing fruits and vegetables from spoiling by using genetic engineering to enhance their natural defenses against fungus.

LEAD: Representatives of the clergy and the laity of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Western hemisphere have recommended that the church allow married priests to become bishops.

LEAD: The former head of the Hooker Corporation, the collapsed retailing concern, and his wife have declared bankruptcy, citing debts of nearly $400 million.
George and Sheila Herscu filed debtors' petitions in the Federal court at Melbourne on Monday, which the court accepted.
The Hooker Corporation was placed in receivership a year ago with debts of about $1.6 billion.

Adiey, Deux Chevaux
LEAD: This is a tough summer for the French.
Bad enough that a reunited Germany will put an end to French aspirations to the leadership of Europe.
Bad enough that the English are buying up half the Normandy and Brittany coasts as summer homes.
But now, the truly inconceivable has happened: Citroen has announced that, after 43 years, the last Deux Chevaux will roll off the final remaining production line, in Portugal, at the end of the month.


Viola Is Erratic and Reds Prove Exploitive
LEAD: From the season's start, Frank Viola has insisted that he doesn't focus on his statistics, being, among other things, suspicious that he might get dizzy from any high opinion of himself that might result.
Tonight, his numbers weren't anything to get dizzy about.

Schools Chief in Los Angeles Says He'll Leave Next Year
LEAD: The Superintendent of Schools here announced Thursday that he would resign at the end of the next school year.


Concerns Grow About Marketing of Medical Alert Systems
LEAD: The growing use of personal emergency-alert systems, devices of potential benefit to millions of older people, is giving unscrupulous businesses a chance to prey on some of the nation's most vulnerable consumers.


Nunn Panel Cuts Pentagon $18 Billion
LEAD: In the first Congressional action on the 1991 military budget, a Senate committee today approved a plan to cut $18 billion from the Bush Administration's proposal, and called for sharp troop reductions in Europe and cuts in the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.


Diaper Debate: Cloth or Disposable?
LEAD: Disposable diapers have become a symbol of a throwaway society.
They squander resources and clog scarce landfills.
To be environmentally responsible, parents should use cloth diapers, which can be washed and re-used many times.
Or should they?
A study of the comprehensive environmental impact of both kinds of diapers, conducted for Procter &amp; Gamble by a prominent consulting company, suggests that neither has a strong advantage.


New Push For Adjusting Of Census
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York stepped up their criticism of the Census Bureau today, charging that the accuracy of the 1990 census was imperiled by the agency's reluctance to correct its tally to make up for millions of uncounted Americans.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
William N. Martin of West Hartford, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Morris Martin and David Noah Brown, the son of Murton L. Brown of New York and Carol Z. Brown of Boston.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Sabatini to Meet Grossman: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and Ann Grossman of the United States won their semifinal matches yesterday and will meet today in the singles final of the Gunze World tournament in Tokyo.
In men's play, Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the Wimbledon champion, withdrew from his semifinal against Jaime Yzaga of Peru after bruising his knee when he tripped over his racquet.


GORBACHEV MEETS WITH NATO'S CHIEF
LEAD: Underscoring a search for new relations between the North Atlantic alliance and the Kremlin, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today received the leader of NATO and agreed to visit and address the alliance at its headquarters in Brussels.


Wesleyan Student's Killing Is Tied to Drugs
LEAD: A student militant at Wesleyan University who was once considered one of the university's most promising minority scholars was killed during a drug deal, a police affidavit says.


Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
LEAD: If guilty, yes.
If innocent, he should be allowed to return to his fraternity of selfish and arrogant owners, overpaid ballplayers, agents, and be forced to watch a Yankee game every day.


Perspectives: Town-House Rentals;   Awaiting a Comeback in High-End Sales
LEAD: It is not quite what they had in mind, but Irving Kovner and Jack Shafran have had no trouble finding tenants.
What they wanted was buyers.


Wall Street;   Close Ties at a Closed-End Fund
LEAD: One of the popular Wall Street parlor games these days is buying closed-end funds at a discount.
The rules are simple.
Check the price of a closed-end fund, a fund whose shares trade publicly like common stock.
Check the per-share market value of the fund's portfolio.
If the fund's price is a lot lower than its net asset value, consider it a bargain.


Investing Is One Thing, Insurance Another
LEAD: To the Editor:


Coach Arrested
LEAD: Just two days after he signed a two-year contract to remain head basketball coach at Cleveland State, Kevin Mackey was arrested Friday night on a charge of driving while intoxicated as he left a suspected drug house, the police said.
The school immediately suspended him without pay until more is learned about the case.


Focus: The Lake Erie Waterfront;   A Shrinking Supply of Developable Land
LEAD: After several years of rapid construction in the resort areas along Lake Erie, little waterfront property remains for additional development.
As a result, attention is turning to a tiny cluster of islands off the shore here.


Gastineau Is Thrown Out
LEAD: Mark Gastineau's debut in the Canadian Football League was just as provocative as the sack dance that used to set off opponents in the National Football League.
Doug Flutie's was just as spectacular as his college career.

Business Diary/July 8-13
LEAD:
INTERNATIIONAL
The Best Little Summit in Texas
A summit conference meant to celebrate the triumph of free-market economics became a demonstration of laissez-faire diplomacy as well.
For every country and cause, the final communique had a clause.
As the conference in Houston ended, West Germany came away with the right to unilaterally aid the Soviet Union, Japan the right to aid China.

LEAD: The Mostly Mozart Festival will open a series of pre-concert Meet-the-Artist ''Tastings'' tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.


On One Philippine Village, All the Forces That Rend
LEAD: The road from Lucena, the capital of Quezon Province, bogs down in mud miles from this fishing village at the base of the Bondoc peninsula.


College Students, at Least, Aren't Apathetic;   The Most Put Down
LEAD: To The Editor:


In Opera, 'Live' Is Livelier, but Also Riskier
LEAD: There are some things about a live operatic performance that a studio-made recording just can't duplicate.
All the possibilities - inspiration, subtlety, revelation of a composer's work, seizure of a great moment, athleticism with its risk of disaster, simple music-making - are in play before an audience of flesh and blood, in one particular moment.


The Secrets Of Gray Ranch
LEAD: In the nearly 90 years that Gray Ranch was managed as a working cattle ranch, it was able to preserve, as your article states, ''more separate species and subspecies of mammals . . . than any existing national wildlife refuge or national park in the continental United States.''


After Everything Came to Nothing
LEAD:
A LOT TO MAKE UP FOR.
By John Buell. (Farrar, Straus &amp; Giroux, $18.95.) ''Strange that living should be so difficult,'' muses Stan Hagan, one of the three central characters in this quiet, sad, yet hopeful novel of people struggling to restore meaning and purpose to their lives.
Stan, a recovering drug addict and alcoholic, comes to the small Canadian town of Ashton in search of Del Symons, a young woman he mistreated during the time of their mutual enslavement to ''pleasures now joyless that they couldn't stop pursuing.


Tipping a Hat to the Universality of Modern Dance
LEAD: When Twyla Tharp is presented with the annual Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival Award today for lifetime achievement in modern dance, she will not - as is customary - accept it in a theater.
The annual $25,000 award was established by the festival 10 years ago specifically to honor modern dance and its creative personalities.


Hampshire College
LEAD: As the mother of a 1990 Hampshire graduate and a veteran of various academic ceremonies, I feel that the unique quality of the college is perhaps most evident at its graduation ceremonies.
Instead of a mass of academic robes, there was a jaunty parade of individuals in costumes ranging from the outrageous to the conventional.

Streetscapes: Morrisania Hospital;   A Tidy Relic of the 1920's Looking for a New Use
LEAD: Hidden by surrounding buildings, the 1929 Morrisania Hospital complex in the Highbridge section of the Bronx comes on you by surprise.
It's a full-block derelict, closed since 1976, but all the more surprising because it is such a tidy derelict, with its windows neatly removed.

Taking a Number
LEAD: In West Virginia politics, they do take prisoners.
Last week former Gov.
Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced to become one, joining nearly a dozen state legislators, lobbyists and government workers who have been convicted on corruption charges in the last couple of years.
Mr.
Moore, who served two terms as Governor in the 1970's and one term in the late 1980's, pleaded guilty to Federal charges of extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and attempting to obstruct the grand jury that indicted him.

FICTION
LEAD:
BEN.
By Max Schott. (North Point, $17.95.) '' 'Mom has a tumor in her brain.
It's growing,' I said, brightly.
To have a tumor in your brain - like a ship in a bottle - would be novelty enough alone, but to have one growing was nearly a miracle.'' Max, the young boy who narrates this novel by the author of ''Murphy's Romance,'' is naive enough to be fascinated and hopeful about desperate situations, yet he is honest and real enough that the reader never tires of him.

The Fascination of Dinosaurs
LEAD: In the recent interesting article about an exhibition of dinosaurs at the Monmouth Museum (''Don't Pet the Dinosaurs, Museum Hit Show Asks''), it was pointed out that in the first three weeks the exhibition drew 29,000 children and adults, illustrating the fascination that dinosaurs have for people of all ages.


Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: When you give up a rook for a minor piece - a bishop or a knight - the process is called an exchange sacrifice to indicate that even though each player has exchanged one unit, the value of the respective units is unequal.
Yet, although a rook is formally worth approximately one and a half pawns more than a minor piece, the transaction is frequently a gain of material because the opponent must lose several pawns along with his bishop or knight.


Patriarch Reaches Out to Embrace Far-Flung Flocks in Orthodoxy
LEAD: Within 24 hours of arriving in New York City, Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I of Constantinople, spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, presided over two services aimed at healing centuries-old divisions among Eastern and Western Christians as well as more recent divisions in his own flock.

Leaving the Groves of Academe for the Fruits of Painting
LEAD: WHEN Virginia Woolf wrote about a room of one's own, she didn't specify which room.
She didn't rule out the attic, for instance.
Woolf, claiming for women writers the physical space in which to explore spiritual space, left self-image issues to later generations of feminists.


FICTION
LEAD:
AWAY FROM HOME: A Novel in Ten Episodes.
By Penelope Farmer. (Victor Gollancz/Trafalgar Square/David &amp; Charles, $19.95.) When it is pointed out to Elinor, the central character in the British writer Penelope Farmer's third novel for adults, that she is letting her feelings run away with her, she rails against the notion that people ought to have a sense of humor, a belief that she equates with not taking oneself seriously.


Rolling on the Rogue
LEAD: I have always loved rivers.
I learned I could feel the rhythms of a river in a canoe.
But I hoped that, in a whitewater kayak, I could become part of the river.
So I ventured in May to Sundance Expeditions on the Rogue River in southwest Oregon for a nine-day kayaking course.

LEAD: Grand Canyon, headed for last May's Kentucky Derby until sidelined by injury, was humanely destroyed today after contracting laminitis, a frequently fatal disease of the hoof, Overbrook Farm said.

She was unaware at the time that Haggerty, coach of the men's and women's teams, had vowed not to allow any more walk-ons.

The Census: Why We Can't Count
LEAD: When the nation's greatest and most troubled exercise in counting finally comes to an end - when the last form flicks through the machines, when the last enumerator turns in the last Questionnaire Misdelivery Record Nonresponse Follow-up, when the last lawsuit is filed - the 1990 census seems certain to stand as a bleak landmark in the annals of arithmetic.


Mexican Dishes at a New Address
LEAD: WE first encountered Clyde's Mexican Grille and Bar (then Clyde's Mexican Cafe) late in 1988, ensconced in tiny quarters in a fitness club in Stamford.
Now it is in a free-standing building (formerly occupied by the Gaslight and several other restaurants) on Route 1 in Old Greenwich.


Practical Traveler;   Getting Cash Abroad: Bank Cards Make It Easy
LEAD: When my family and I first traveled to England in 1965, we carried an engraved-letterhead note from our bank in New York that would have done credit to Edith Wharton.
It introduced us to a bank in the City of London that would cash one of our New York checks, in case we ran through our $10 ''tip pack'' of British currency and our traveler's checks.


Lawns Exact Price Some Won't Pay
LEAD: WHEN 17-month-old Ari Winkleman toddles around his Hastings-on-Hudson backyard, his parents worry about the spills and falls he will take as he exercises his new-found motor skills.
What they don't worry about is his exposure to pesticides on their property.

Books From The Times
LEAD:
LANGUAGE MAVEN STRIKES AGAIN.
By William Safire. (Doubleday, $22.95.) What is a maven, anyway, and how is it different from a pundit or a boffin?
How formal is semiformal?
Which is worse, going bananas or going ballistic?
When did anxiety turn into stress?
William Safire's sixth compilation from his weekly column On Language in The New York Times Magazine - augmented with contributions from friends and readers, the Lexicographic Irregulars - addresses these and many, many other pertinent issues raised in the course of reading, writing, talking and listening in America.

Postings: Paying the Points;   50 Affordable Bronx Town Houses
LEAD: 50 affordable two-family town houses nearing completion in the Crotona Park section of the Bronx, offered to pay the mortgage points for the first 25 buyers.
A point is 1 percent of a mortgage, and most lenders charge two or three as an origination fee for a home loan.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side.
We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped.
We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding.
Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

Harpists Without Halos Test Their Wings
LEAD: A determined group of younger musicians, mostly women, is scrambling to find ways to bring the harp into the late 20th century.
For an instrument that numbers diminutive angels and a Marx brother among its best-known virtuosos, that is no easy or straightforward task.
Some harpists are following the Swiss star Andreas Vollenweider into New Age washes.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Mont Belvieu, Tex.;   A Gas Leak Prods Exodus
LEAD: SINCE 1986, more than 200 families and five churches have moved several miles from the five-square-mile center of this town of 1,700 people.
They moved because the town sits on a salt dome where 43 percent of the liquid natural gas in Texas is stored and where a dangerous leak was discovered in 1980.

Ms. Allen Plans To Wed in August

Mailing Is Curbed in Vermont
LEAD: Mailing privileges for Vermont lawmakers will be suspended through Jan. 1, 1991 as part of a cost-cutting effort.
The Legislative Council, eight lawmakers who oversee internal business, this week notified the other 172 members of the House and Senate of several cost-savings measures.
The changes included suspension of stenographic services, stationery and postage.


Eastern Is Expected to Face Criminal Charges
LEAD: A Federal grand jury is preparing to file criminal charges against Eastern Airlines, accusing it of faulty maintenance practices at La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports in New York and Hartsfield International in Atlanta, lawyers involved in the investigation said yesterday.


Sheehan Sets 2 Marks at Open
LEAD: In the midst of a meterological Maelstrom, Patty Sheehan completed the two best opening rounds in the history of the United States Women's Open today to take a six-shot lead into what officials hope will be a 36-hole finale Sunday.


The Lake Erie Waterfront; A Shrinking Supply of Developable Land
LEAD: After several years of rapid construction in the resort areas along Lake Erie, little waterfront property remains for additional development.
As a result, attention is turning to a tiny cluster of islands off the shore here.


Grocery Bag Re-use Nets Rewards
LEAD: JANET MURPHY of West Hartford stood in line at the checkout counter of the Cheese and Stuff supermarket in Hartford and handed the cashier a wrinkled brown grocery bag and a green-and-white card.
As she watched, the cashier punched the card.
When all the holes in the card are punched, Mrs.
Murphy will receive one dollar off on a purchase.


Corrections
LEAD: An article last Sunday about bills adopted in the New York State Legislature misstated the status of one.


Lawmakers Vote to Reduce Allowances of Ex-Presidents
LEAD: The House of Representatives voted Friday to trim the Bush Administration's request for office allowances paid to the four living former Presidents.
It rejected a proposal to eliminate the allowances entirely.

LEAD: Everybody expected the Tour de France to get off to a new beginning today, and it did as Erik Breukink and Greg LeMond went on a long breakaway and made up nearly five minutes of their deficit on the man in the yellow jersey, Claudio Chiappucci.

Once Upon a Time, Berlin, Too, Was a City of Light
LEAD: In the matter of the great city of Berlin, which is now in such a state of ebullition, I have a mental image that many people find perverse.
My private Berlin has nothing of the pompous, bombastic, self-satisfied Berlin, all tuba and trombone and bass drum, that was the natural backdrop for the outbreak of World War I.


Political Crisis Grips India's Governing Coalition
LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh offered his resignation on Saturday to his party's leader, who said later that he had rejected it.

In his autobiography, ''Inside Track,'' Mr.
Lewis focuses not on his athletic prowess but on the reasons why he has been unable to cash in on his celebrity.


An Explanation On Missed Vote
LEAD: The July 1 edition reported that I was absent during the vote to approve a 43,000-square-foot terminal at the County Airport [''Legislators Seek New Compromise on Air Terminal''] .
It was correctly reported that I voted for the proposed 24,000-square-foot terminal - which also went down to defeat during our June 25 meeting.

LEAD: R. J. Reynolds's two-run single broke an eighth-inning tie and Barry Bonds hit a homer today as the surging Pittsburgh Pirates continued to dominate San Diego by beating the Padres, 8-4.
Pittsburgh has won 10 of 11 games against the Padres this season, including all 5 at Three Rivers Stadium, after losing 9 of 12 to them last season.

LEAD: Conditions for children in New York City have deteriorated significantly in the last 15 years, with marked increases in infant mortality, reports of child abuse and the number of children living in poverty, according to an index tabulated by social scientists at Fordham University.

Easing the Task of Buying Lumber
LEAD: BUYING lumber can be confusing.
For example, any piece of lumber that is less than two inches thick and eight inches wide is called a strip; any piece less than two inches thick but more than eight inches wide is called a board.


Review/Theater;   From Trivia to Tragedy in 'Jersey City'
LEAD: As the audience meets Magaly and Pa in ''Jersey City,'' Wendy Hammond's jarring new play at the Second Stage Theater, they are finishing their evening meal with a game of baseball trivia.
Magaly, still tomboy enough at age 15 to prefer a catcher's mitt to a new dress for a present, knows what year Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle broke in as rookies, then stumps her dad with a question about what outfielder is named after a fruit (until she starts chanting ''Dar-ryl'' to give him a clue).

In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   High-End Sales Are Down in Greenwich
LEAD: In northeast Greenwich, 26 stately pleasure domes have been built at Conyers Farm, a 1,500-acre enclave resembling a contemporary Xanadu.
Maintaining its private, pastoral quality is a set of covenants under which no more than 60 families may live on minimum lots of 10 acres, protected in perpetuity by deed restrictions.


Currency;   Surprises From the Fed
LEAD: Last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took the foreign exchange market by surprise, announcing Thursday that the central bank might ease interest rates because of dwindling credit from commercial banks and then, on Friday, actually pushing rates down slightly.
The dollar fell sharply after his remarks but recovered some on Friday, partly because the June increase in producer prices was disappointingly high.

LEAD: To anyone who had known Moscow when secrecy was an obsession and the Communist Party was almighty, the action last week in the Kremlin's cavernous Palace of Congresses was wondrous to behold.

LEAD: In an attempt to ease some of the tensions between the cities of Cincinnati and Cleveland, Sam Wyche, the Bengals' coach, put himself at the mercy of the infamous ''Dog Pound'' fans in Cleveland on Friday and in doing so raised about $8,000 for the Salvation Army homeless and hunger programs in that city.

TB Testing And Treating
LEAD: Although tuberculosis can affect almost any organ, by far the most common form involves the lungs.
Its symptoms include a cough, fevers, drenching night sweats, fatigue, weight loss and blood-tinged sputum.
They can vary in severity.
Some patients dismiss their symptoms as a smoker's cough while others have a serious pneumonia.

Bridgeport Celebrates Its Diversity
LEAD: TRUMPET fanfares will introduce the 50th anniversary gala of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in Norfolk this afternoon at 3, followed by opera arias and vocal duets, short instrumental works of Bartok and Schumann, a Mozart String Quartet and other compositions.
The performers, all members of the Norfolk faculty, include the trumpeters Allan Dean and Robert Nagel, the pianists Donald Currier, Ward Davenny and Joan Panetti, the oboist Ronald Roseman, the Tokyo Quartet and others.

She was wearing high heels, the bottom to a bikini, and a satin banner that said in glitter 1976.

St. Andrews Through the Caddy's Eyes
LEAD: Forgive my lack of modesty, but I am the most experienced and the best regular caddie at the Old Course at St.
Andrews.
I have caddied there at least four times a week for the last 44 years, since I was 14 years old.
Of course, it has been my great privilege to carry Arnold Palmer's bag there in three British Opens, as well as the 25 others he has played in.

So when you get right down to it, there isn't a time of the year when great numbers of people aren't getting married.

CRIME
LEAD: If you're over 60 and still on Wall Street, you might as well be dead.
So goes the cutthroat business credo in Annette Meyers's TENDER DEATH (Bantam, $17.95), which causes the heroine, Leslie Wetzon, no end of distress.
Not only is the headhunter-sleuth having problems placing her veteran clients (''The older broker had become a dinosaur''), but the mysterious death of a 78-year-old woman with vast stock holdings has her wondering whether there might be some plot afoot to boot all the old-timers off the Street and into the grave.


They're Foreign But Getting More Familiar
LEAD: Later this month New Yorker Video will release four titles from its library of 400 foreign films.
One, ''Sand and Blood,'' is in French.
Two others are in Spanish and German.
The fourth, ''Dragon Chow'' (set in a Chinese restaurant) is in German, Urdu and Mandarin.
Along with other recent releases, the four films may be indicative of what some hope is a growing interest in foreign movies in this country, not to mention a developing tolerance for something many

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side.
We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped.
We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding.
Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

LEAD: A businessman has dropped plans to kill 30,000 South African seals after protests by international animal rights advocates, the Government said today.


Tech Notes;   A New Lease on Life for the Printed Word
LEAD: For libraries around the world, the enemy is time.
Since the 1850's, when all-rag paper became prohibitively expensive, printing has been done on wood-pulp paper.
But alum, a component in that paper, reacts with atmospheric moisture to form an acid that dissolves the wood fibers: books become discolored and brittle.

Black Children Living With One Parent Put at 55%

Zombie Assassins, Desert Rhythms and the Beats
LEAD: Rock-and-roll, with its unbookish culture, seems an unlikely candidate to adopt a literary figure.
But there is no longer any doubt that the perennial iconoclast-author William Burroughs has been given a lifetime pass to the rock-and-roll circus.
The bassist and songwriter Bill Laswell, leading a loose assemblage of players he calls Material, recently drafted the writer to read excerpts from his latest novel, ''The Western Lands,'' as part of the album ''Seven Souls'' (Virgin 91360; CD and cassette).

LEAD:
NEW AND OLD


Too Many Bosses, Too Few Workers
LEAD: Before Americans can celebrate the decline of Communism, we should ponder why a Japanese eighth grader typically knows more mathematics than an American with an M.B.A., and whether our own decline can be far behind the Soviet Union's.
I believe we can avoid that fate, but we need to make a number of fundamental changes in business, government and education if we are to continue to prosper.

LEAD: The danger peaks near dawn, said a man named Jenkins, when Government soldiers, sometimes wearing masks, stalk the gates in front of the makeshift refugee camp within the walls of the American Cooperative School.


Fashion;   What They're Wearing: The Bright Suit
LEAD: Has black been banished?
Probably not, but it has been pushed aside for the moment.
These photos, taken at recent social events in New York, clearly show that vibrant colors have overtaken black as the sophisticate's choice.
And it's not just the obvious shades, like red, that are being chosen, but juicier ones like orange and pistachio.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Snap old flowers off geraniums and cut them off pansies, petunias, snapdragons and other annuals to keep the plants blooming; formation of seed pods will stop flowering.
If bloom is finished, cut stalks off astilbes, foxgloves, phlox, lilies, heucheras, delphiniums and other perennials to prevent seed pods.

It is unlikely that players accustomed to a perfunctory two or three riffles will change their ways, but a point to consider is the type of bridge being played.

LEAD:

By Harold T. P. Hayes.

HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
LEAD:
Here are some notable releases of the last few months.


Connecticut Democrats Split in Peace
LEAD: Connecticut's Democrats split over the choice of a candidate for governor at their state convention here today, forcing the first gubernatorial primary in 12 years.
But the break was far less rancorous than many delegates had feared.


Campus Life: Michigan State;   Anti-Drinking Bid Results in Seizure Of Fake Licenses
LEAD: In an effort to crack down on what they said was an increase in under-age drinking, the East Lansing police have confiscated more than 700 fake driver's licenses from students.


IN SEARCH OF THE LATINO WRITER
LEAD: When Oscar Hijuelos, a Cuban-American, won the 1990 Pulitzer Prize in fiction for his novel ''The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' the award raised the possibility that Latino writers in the United States could at last find a wide audience for their work.
If so, their success has been a long time coming.


Amper Is Using The Environment
LEAD: P. T. Barnum, who mockingly announced there was a sucker born every minute, has a new and aggressive student in Richard Amper.
Unfortunately for the rest of us, Mr.
Amper looks to sucker the taxpayer and in his essay, ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us'' (May 28), he shows just how adept he is at his scam.


Is Tonality Pie in the Sky Or Pie in the Face?
LEAD: Nothing is harder to kill than a good myth.
Beat on it with hard facts, and it will hardly notice.
Chop off its head, and it will grow another one by nightfall.
Nothing, it seems, can put an end to a myth but its replacement by another myth.


The Prince of Many Faces
LEAD: To the Editor:


Running the Rapids Of Utah's San Juan
LEAD: A white roar disturbs the canyon quiet.
Roabie Johnson pulls a pair of pliers from the holster on her belt and draws a diagram in the sand: two parallel lines to show the course of the river, three or four circles to indicate rocks, and a series of peaks that stand for tail waves. ''These pliers are your boat,'' she says as she threads the tool through the circles and aims it directly at the peaks.


'Hedda' Wears Brain on Her Sleeve
LEAD: ''HEDDA GABLER'' is 100 years old, but the tantalizing title character in Ibsen's classic of demented psychology remains a puzzlement.
The prevailing perception of Hedda as predator, ''a hopeless specimen of degeneracy'' or merely ''mean'' was epitomized by Brooks Atkinson's pronouncement in 1936: ''In cold fact, she is the most hateful woman in dramatic literature.


Gabrielle von Henneberg Is Engaged
LEAD: September wedding plans for Gabrielle Jesman von Henneberg and David Archibald Gillies, a son of Joy Gillies of Northport, L.I., and Archibald L. Gillies of New York, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs.
Robert P. Bass Jr. and Jacek von Henneberg, both of Cambridge, Mass.


Vincent Studies Past for Help On the Decision at Hand
LEAD: Fay Vincent's commissionership is relatively young.
Yet, as he begins his deliberations on the fate of the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, he does so equipped with the knowledge of 70 years of precedent-setting acts by commissioners past.


On the Road, Again
LEAD: A recent Midwestern drive presented more than expected sights like the Gateway Arch, Sears Tower and Blue Water Bridge.
The roads between scheduled stops revealed a four-decade evolution in American motoring.
The Interstate highways enter the 1990's, like many of us who travel them, pushing middle age.


AFTERSHOCK IN SAN FRANCISCO
LEAD: Fenton Johnson's article ''Aftershock in San Francisco'' (June 17) left the mistaken impression that San Francisco's disaster planning is rooted in denial.
Nothing could be further from the truth.


Little Progress Is Seen OnEnvironment Goals
LEAD: THREE years after Connecticut developed a comprehensive environmental plan setting out goals for the year 2000, a state environmental panel has reported little progress toward meeting them.


East's Archives Reveal Ties to Terrorists
LEAD: With every passing day, disclosures from secret files of the former Communist governments in Eastern Europe show more clearly that well into the 1980's, they gave sanctuary to Middle Eastern and Western European terrorist groups that were attacking Western targets, despite official denials at the time.


Free to Speak, Bulgarians Aren't Sure What to Say
LEAD: Bulgarians like Stefan Dankov are having a hard time deciding if these will be the ''good old days.''

NONFICTION
LEAD:
CLOWN PRINCE OF HOLLYWOOD: The Antic Life and Times of Jack L. Warner.
By Bob Thomas. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) ''Moguls?
Don't like the word,'' Jack Leonard Warner once said. ''It reminds me of some bad Turkish cigarettes I used to smoke.'' Yet for more than 25 years there was perhaps no better word to describe him as he helped run Hollywood and dictate the cinematic tastes of the American public.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.

Taking Bows
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation had Lee Iacocca; New York University had John Brademas.

Brademas took over as president in 1981, but it was looking to grow and looking for a leader who knew where to look for money.
Dr.
Brademas did.
He came to the university with 11 terms in Congress behind him and quickly became a familiar figure in the New York financial community.

LEAD: If the modern watch industry had a theme song, it would probably be Peter Allen's ''Everything Old Is New Again.'' Mechanical watches, which all but ceded the market to quartz movements more than a decade ago, are best-sellers again.
Analog faces, the ones with big hands and little hands, have recaptured a chunk of the market from digital displays.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Salt is something associated with health - too little can cause fainting in hot weather and too much can raise blood pressure.
But, salt is a necessity, especially in hot climates, and its use has been a curious amalgam of barter and currency for centuries.
The word salary, for example, comes from the Latin salarium, which was the money paid to Roman soldiers to buy salt.

Easing the Task of Buying Lumber
LEAD: BUYING lumber can be confusing.
For example, any piece of lumber that is less than two inches thick and eight inches wide is called a strip; any piece less than two inches thick but more than eight inches wide is called a board.

Kaunda, they were expressing what citizens in many parts of Africa have been saying more and more: Africa's original big men have been around too long.

And both houses are rushing bills to beef up the pursuit of S &amp; L crooks.

But there is a problem: The fishing is lousy.


Review/Opera;   A Plausible Semi-Staged 'Pique Dame'
LEAD: Like Zubin Mehta, Seiji Ozawa seems eager to expand his operatic activities.
Perhaps partly for that reason, he has taken to offering semi-staged operatic productions every summer with the Boston Symphony at its Tanglewood festival in the Berkshires.
This year's installment was tonight's ''Pique Dame,'' and despite some reservations it turned out to be a genuinely effective realization of one of Tchaikovsky's masterpieces.

Associated Press Pact
LEAD: The Associated Press and its technical employees reached a tentative agreement on a new three-year labor contract, both sides announced yesterday.
Under the agreement, reached Saturday, the weekly salaries of top-scale technical workers would increase $23.50 the first year, $24 the second and $24.50 in the third year, to $636.50.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers.
At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers.

LEAD: EVEN though it was late afternoon when Vic Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and I reached Chapin Pond, the heat was oppressive.
It was not ideal trout-fishing weather.
The surface temperature of the pond was 72 degrees, too hot for trout, which begin to languish when the water gets much above 65 degrees.

Big Soviet Harvest Seen
LEAD: The prospects are still good for a bumper grain harvest in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said last week.
Total grain production is estimated at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million in 1989, the department said in a report.
That would be the largest since a record 237.4 million tons in 1978.

Bridge
LEAD: Suppose you wander into a strange club in another country and sit down behind one of the players.
He holds the West cards shown in the diagram, and you wonder whether or not he is an expert.
You are mildly surprised that he chooses to open one spade rather than one no-trump: It is obvious that he employs four-card major openings, and you suspect that he favors the weak no-trump opening.

LEAD: The cautious process of rebuilding the strained relations between the Soviet Union and China have taken another modest step forward with a report here today that the first Chinese-Soviet joint venture in China will soon be established.

LEAD: AT first glance, the new campaign for Barq's soft drinks is nothing out of the ordinary, with shots of soda cans under the headline, ''So try 'em already.''


3 to Share DHL Stake
LEAD: The Japan Air Lines Company, Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. and the Nissho Iwai Corporation, a Japanese trading company, agreed to take a combined stake of 2.52 percent in the DHL Corporation, the American holding company of the DHL World Express air-courier service.
J.A.L. and Lufthansa will each own 1 percent and Nissho will buy the remaining stake, subject to the approval of the United States Government.

LEAD: The Nasty Boys had their nasty stuff, a rude state of affairs that made for a very quiet, very polite exit by the Mets.


Carcasses of 23 Gray Whales Wash Up on Islands in Alaska
LEAD: Twenty-three gray whale carcasses have washed up on two remote islands in the Gulf of Alaska, and scientists plan a study to determine why they died.

Youth Shot Over a Coat Dies
LEAD: A 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student who was shot last Tuesday during a dispute over an expensive coat died yesterday at Brookdale Hospital, the police said.
The dead student, Peter Andrews, of 103d Street in the Canarsie section, was shot outside South Shore High School.
A 14-year-old suspect, Wayne McIntosh, of Avenue B in the East New York section, now faces homicide charges, which will be considered by a grand jury, said Sgt.


A Way to Drink and Dive
LEAD: A scuba diver in Miami has developed a pouch that allows divers to drink fluids under water.
The device comes with a collapsible bag that feeds beverages through a port in a specially designed mouthpiece.

LEAD: The Government said on Saturday that it was helping about 190,000 refugees return to the south, where they had fled famine and civil war.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and officials at a group of Michigan universities have quietly begun discussions with the Federal Government about creating a nonprofit company that would operate a high-speed computer network that could one day reach every home in the country.

LEAD: The final standing of the 1990 lacrosse world championships may read four losses in a row for the Iroquois Nationals, but team officials are calling the Native Americans' return to international competition after a century's banishment a major success.

LEAD: Two final decisions on pivotal land-use questions face the Board of Estimate before it ceases to exist under terms of the new City Charter.

They will be remembered as a test of wisdom and courage as the board closes its 90-year run.

LEAD: Under pressure from the federal Government and burdened by economic problems, the newly elected leaders in the Yugoslav republic of Slovenia are pressing to forge a sovereign state and recast Slovenia's relationship with the country's five other republics.


Business Scene;   Unexpected Shift In a Labor Rate
LEAD: AN era might be ending, unexpectedly.
Americans have been jumping into the labor force in ever-increasing numbers since the 1960's, so that today about 66.4 percent of the working-age population holds jobs or seeks them.
The problem is that the labor participation rate, as it is called, was the same 66.4 percent a year ago.

LEAD: While Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister argues for a new political architecture in Europe and Poland's Foreign Minister concentrates on safeguarding his nation's postwar borders, Romania's new Foreign Minister, Adrian Nastase, has a different focus: helping his nation join the family of Europe.


Powerboating: Women and the Sea
LEAD: WOMEN who go to sea on powerboats tend to go along for the ride.
Although a vast majority of the 15 million recreational boats in the United States are powerboats, it is not the women of America in charge of driving.

Jim Florio's new school financing formula.
They say the figures pose nightmarish years ahead for the town's children and taxpayers.

LEAD: Argentina's Supreme Court has removed a legal obstacle in the privatization of the Aerolineas Argentinas carrier, the official news agency said on Saturday.


Little Change Expected for Rates
LEAD: The bond market, which has so far this summer received help from both the President of the United States and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, may have a more difficult time finding new friends in the weeks ahead.
But without further assistance, credit market analysts said, interest rates were not likely to decline much from current levels, and might even rise.


Data Verify Economy's Malaise: 16 States in or Near a Recession
LEAD: The national economy has become so sluggish that 16 states, with more than a third of the nation's population, are in a recession or close to one, an analysis of employment data shows.
And throughout the country, people are talking of stagnant wages, falling real estate prices, deeply indebted corporations and jobs that are getting harder to find.

2 New Laser Printers From Apple
LEAD: APPLE Computer Inc., trailing its competitors by many months, has introduced two new lower-cost laser printers.
At suggested list prices of $1,999 and $3,299, they do not approach the low prices of personal laser printers available for MS-DOS computers, which are now widely available for less than $1,500.

LEAD: Israeli troops shot and wounded 11 Palestinian protesters in the Gaza Strip today and entered the town of Rafa and the refugee camp nearby for the first time in months to order residents to erase Palestinian nationalist graffiti.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission, concerned that the cost of providing international telephone service has been falling far faster than the prices that callers pay, has begun an effort to force down rates by up to 50 percent within three years.

Parasites Take the Biological Spotlight
LEAD: TO the ancient Greeks, the word ''parasite'' meant one who eats at the table of another.
But far from having the decency to sit down for dinner, most parasites in nature suck the blood, sip at the gastric juices of the intestines, pierce into the nourishing warmth of muscle tissue and otherwise leech rudely off the fluids and labors of their unwilling hosts.


The Education of Jim Florio
LEAD: Gov.
Jim Florio has courageously raised New Jersey's taxes, and his reward is a 19 percent crash in popularity.
His experiment is being watched around the country by Democrats who wonder if voters can be persuaded to overcome their resistance to taxes.
Mr.
Florio doesn't deserve to be punished for his honesty, but he does need to explain better what he is doing and why.
