Chess
LEAD: There are indeed setups in chess that demand patience and invincible will.
Most of these are characterized by an aggressor with an advantage in space trying to break through a solid, though cramped, position with a latent weakness in pawn structure.
This does take time and relentless determination and extended maneuvering.

Bridge
LEAD: Conventional wisdom dictates that a player with a freakish hand and a very long suit should make every effort to play in that suit.
In exceptional cases, especially at match-point scoring, it may be right to venture three no-trump if the suit is a minor.
To do so in a major is hardly ever appropriate, and the diagramed example may constitute a world record in this area.

He was 76 years old and lived in East Rockaway, L.I.

LEAD: The vast and rich Ukraine, one of the largest and most important republics in the Soviet Union, became the latest to declare its sovereignty today, challenging the Gorbachev Government to a larger share of self-determination and natural resources.

Rite Aid Charges Dismissed
LEAD: A judge dismissed all charges against the Rite Aid Corporation and its president today after ruling that the evidence against them in a bribery case was circumstantial.


Environmentalists vs. Property Owners in Staten Island Wetlands


Review/Television;   Jane Pauley Interviewing The Harried and Hopeful
LEAD: Fans of Jane Pauley, relax.
She returns tonight at 10 on NBC in an easy-to-take hour called ''Real Life With Jane Pauley.'' It is the first of five summer specials adapted to the popular former co-anchor of the ''Today'' show, with the prospect of finding a place in the new television season.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American National Can Co., Chicago, a can manufacturer, promoted Thomas N. Eagleson to senior vice president for manufacturing, food metal-North America, and Richard G. Sturdevant to senior vice president for manufacturing, beverage cans-North America.


Evolution in Europe;   Baker Says U.S. Is Ready to Create Links With Soviet Non-Communists
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States is prepared to begin a dialogue with the emerging non-Communist opposition to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


U.S. Policy On Inquiries
LEAD: Federal regulators who have opened civil proceedings on failed savings institutions to public scrutiny, including a case involving President Bush's son Neil, may expand the policy to include institutions not under Government control.


Cummins Shares Rise By $3.125
LEAD: Shares of the Cummins Engine Company rose sharply yesterday as analysts and shareholders assessed the company's plan to sell $250 million worth of its common stock, representing a 27 percent stake, to three industrial companies.

Data Hint More Dust Hides Spiral Galaxies
LEAD: ASTRONOMERS have long thought that spiral galaxies were relatively free from opaque clouds of dust, but new observations suggest that they are much less transparent and thus contain an enormous amount of mass in the form of unseen stars.
If true, the finding could undermine one theoretical pillar in modern astrophysics.


New Funds Bailing Out Bad Buyouts
LEAD: A $1 billion fund raised last week by two Chicago investors who make up the Zell/Chilmark limited partnership is a sign of how finance in the 1990's will differ from the 1980's.


State Gave 2 Liquor Permits to Same Times Sq. Bar
LEAD: After a brief run, the Stage Left cabaret closed its doors on Times Square last year.
But the failed club lives on in a lawsuit and an investigation that has entangled the State Liquor Authority, present and former officials, the son of a top official, prominent lawyers and two companies that had hoped to reap considerable income.


Larkin H. Farinholt, 84, Professor And Sloan Foundation Executive
LEAD: Dr.
Larkin H. Farinholt, a chemistry professor and foundation executive who held a number of scientific posts in Washington, died Thursday at the Long Green Nursing Home in Baltimore.
He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and Leonia, N.J., for many years.
A daughter, Kathryn, said he died of pneumonia.


Vision Becomes Reality for Europe
LEAD: President Gorbachev yesterday showed great courage in accepting a unified Germany in NATO.
And Chancellor Kohl of West Germany demonstrated high statesmanship in agreeing to limit the future all-German army to troop levels below those now possessed by West Germany alone, and to grant credits to Germany's longtime adversary.

2 Families Sue Heavy-Metal Band As Having Driven Sons to Suicide
LEAD: Two days before Christmas in 1985, a pair of young Nevada men shot themselves after listening to albums by the heavy-metal band Judas Priest.
Today the rock group and CBS Records went on trial in Washoe County District Court here, accused by the men's families of having driven them to suicide.


U.N. Says Pretoria Meets 1 of 5 Conditions
LEAD: The United Nations said today that the South African Government had so far fully carried out one of the five measures it believes must be taken before a climate of genuine political freedom can develop and meaningful negotiations take place on ending apartheid.


More Growth for Lilly As a New Drug Stars
LEAD: Even before this month, Eli Lilly &amp; Company was having a year beyond the dreams of most American companies: It was well on its way to surpassing its 1989 performance, when it was the fourth-best company on the Fortune 500 list in terms of profit as a percentage of sales.

Yanks End Latest Dry Spell, Beating Royals
LEAD: The signs were all there for another night of doom in the Bronx.
Jesse Barfield's first-inning drive to the left-field fence, which seemed certain to become at least a two-run double and possibly a three-run home run, had been transformed into an out because of fan interference.


New Rules and Incinerator Jitters Mean Hospital Waste Piles Up
LEAD: Two summers ago, the New York metropolitan area recoiled in horror as a few syringes and blood vials washed up on local beaches.
The authorities pledged to hunt down and punish those responsible and New York, and many other states, made hospital disposal practices subject to sterner regulation and stricter punishment.


Ralph Humphrey, An Abstract Painter And a Teacher, 58
LEAD: Ralph Humphrey, an abstract painter whose works were a link between Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism, died on Saturday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: Among the 10 African-Americans honored by the National Coalition of 100 Black Women last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York were EUZHAN PALCY, the director of ''A Dry White Season,'' a film that examines South Africa's system of apartheid; JUDITH JAMISON, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, and MAYA ANGELOU, the poet.


18 Killed in Lebanon as Shiites Battle in South
LEAD: Warring Shiite Muslim factions today fought their fiercest battles in six months for control of a strategic district in southern Lebanon, and the police said 18 people were killed and 50 wounded.

Corn and Other Grains Drop On Good Weather Forecast
LEAD: Prices of corn futures sank yesterday to the lowest levels in three months on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting forecasts for more good growing weather and a lack of strong export demand.
Other grain and soybean futures also ended lower.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: Every summer the power pack migrates to the Rockies, where the Aspen Institute holds its symposium on domestic and international affairs.
This year, MARGARET THATCHER and PRESIDENT BUSH will speak to 400 government and business leaders at the institute's 40th anniversary symposium.


RJR Move Helps Lift 'Junk Bonds'
LEAD: Word that the RJR Holdings Corporation has begun a $6.9 billion refinancing program for RJR Nabisco served as a long-awaited tonic to the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' yesterday, and prices of most issues posted strong gains in heavy trading.

Terrell Spurns Minors
LEAD: The pitcher Walt Terrell is declining his demotion to the Pittsburgh Pirates' Class AAA farm club in Buffalo. ''He's not going to Buffalo; he's not even considering going to Buffalo,'' Terrell's agent, Alan Meersand of Manhattan Beach, Calif., said yesterday.
On Saturday, Terrell, who had a 2-7 record, was given three days to accept or reject the assignment to the farm club.

Syrian Leader Says He Is Ready to Seek Peace

British Retail Sales Fall
LEAD: Retail sales in Britain plummeted by 2.8 percent in June, the biggest drop since 1979 and the clearest indication that consumers are feeling the pinch of the Government's high interest rate policy.
The decline compared with a rise of 1.4 percent in May.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace referred incorrectly in some copies to a Watergate tape in which President Nixon told Attorney General John N. Mitchell that he wanted aides to ''stonewall it.'' The tape was recorded on March 22, 1973, not in 1972.

Queens Pitcher to Jays
LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays have persuaded the pitcher Steve Karsay, who was 14-1 with Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens, last season, to forgo college and pursue professional baseball.
Karsay was Toronto's first pick in the June free-agent draft.
The 18-year-old Karsay said he signed a one-year deal and received a big signing bonus, but he refused to get into specifics.

Island Building Plan Dropped
LEAD: The developer of a proposed $1 billion high-rise condominium complex on Davids Island in Long Island Sound, two-thirds of a mile from the mainland, withdrew his application today in the face of its rejection as an ''elitist concept'' by state officials.


Earthquake in the Philippines Kills at Least 258, Including 48 Children in One School
LEAD: A major earthquake registering 7.7 on the Richter scale killed at least 258 people on Monday on the main island of the Philippines, including 48 children whose school collapsed and 210 others caught in stampedes or in falling buildings, officials said.


Alcoa's Net Is Down by 43%
LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America, citing a softening in aluminum prices and lower income from the company's affiliate in Brazil, yesterday reported a 43 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.

LEAD: Reader's Digest yesterday named Richard D. Wright to the new position of associate publisher-sales development and said that it was eliminating about 25 jobs in its advertising sales organization.

He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Avalanche Kills 40 Climbers in Soviet Central Asia
LEAD: One of the worst tragedies in the history of mountain climbing has claimed the lives of at least 40 members of an international team killed Friday by an avalanche in the remote Pamir mountains in the Soviet Union near the Chinese border, according to Government reports.


A and C Trains Halted
LEAD: More than 100,000 IND riders on the Fulton Street line in Brooklyn lost service for several hours yesterday because of problems in replacing track, the Transit Authority said.
The problems began at 6:15 A.M., and A and C trains from Broadway-East New York to Jay Street-Borough Hall were stopped for a few hours, a spokeswoman for the authority, Caren Gardner, said.

One Germany: Next Steps
LEAD: Some dates are tentative.
Sept. 12. 'Two plus four' talks involving the two Germanys and the four World War II victors, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, prepare a 'final document' to present to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Oct. 4.
East German elections in reconstituted states (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Saxony-Anhalt, Brandeburg, Thuringia and Saxony), paving the way for the accession of East Germany to West Germany under Article 23 of the West German Constitution, which authorized every state to join the federation.

The major wire services and most newspapers - The A.P., U.P.I., Reuters, The Washington Post, Newsday and The New York Times, among others - reported it verbatim.

Boat Speed Limit Is 4 M.P.H.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins signed a bill yesterday to limit boats to 4 miles an hour on the Pelham Bay Park lagoon in the Bronx, too slow for water-skiing.
The measure was introduced by Councilman Jerry L. Crispino, Democrat of the Bronx, who said homeowners had complained about the noise and danger from the boats.


Iraq Threatens Emirates And Kuwait on Oil Glut
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today openly threatened to use force against Arab oil-exporting nations if they did not curb their excess production, which he said had weakened oil prices and hurt the Iraqi economy.

Two Held in a Robbery and Impersonation
LEAD: An employee and a former employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Service have been arrested in connection with a Bronx robbery on Saturday in which the robbers posed as Federal drug-enforcement agents, the police said.
A third suspect was being sought.
The police were investigating whether the two suspects, a man arrested on Monday and a woman arrested yesterday, were involved in a similar robbery 12 hours earlier in the Soundview section.

LEAD: Japan will stop drift-net fishing in the South Pacific this season, a year before the date set by a United Nations resolution, the Japanese Embassy said today.

Group Reduces Multimedia Stake
LEAD: A group of three investment partnerships led by Sandler Associations of Hewlett, L.I., said it had lowered its stake in Multimedia Inc. to 2.9 percent from 7.34 percent.
Multimedia, based in Greenville, S.C., publishes newspapers and operates radio and television stations.
The company has 11.3 million shares outstanding.


Madonna Talks End
LEAD: Madonna will not be as ubiquitous as planned.
Reebok International Ltd., the athletic footwear company, said yesterday that negotiations for an endorsement agreement with the pop singer and star of ''Dick Tracy'' had ended. ''Timing and schedules became the critical factors,'' a spokeswoman for Reebok said, referring to Madonna's current world concert tour.


In Land of Big, Ryan's Biggest
LEAD: In Texas, parents reward the straight-A work of their grade-schoolers with tickets to see Nolan Ryan pitch.
He has been praised by editorial writers and political columnists, courted by advertisers and Republican Party officials attracted to his wholesome country-boy image, exploited by makers of baseball memorabilia, who spot a sure thing, and idolized by thousands of wide-eyed youngsters whom he has met in autograph sessions for Texas charities.

LEAD: Two members of the radical environmental group Earth First will not be charged with transporting the bomb that exploded in their car and injured them in May, lawyers for the two said today.

Review/Pop;   At the Palladium, 3 Groups From Spain
LEAD: Though it seemed as if the mix-and-match pop music esthetic that began in the early 1980's might lumber to a stop in the 1990's, it hasn't.
African, American and European pop music all greedily suck in cultures, easily available by travel and record collections.
The result is a party where the old mingles with the new, where a sense of cultural movement, always exciting, momentarily blinds an audience to its differences, uniting it.

2 GERMANYS VOW TO RETAIN BORDER WITH THE POLES
LEAD: East and West Germany agreed today to resolve Polish anxieties by promising to guarantee the postwar German-Polish frontier, and in doing so, the Germans all but guaranteed international endorsement of their own reunification by the end of the year.


Bosworth Is Waived After Failing Physical
LEAD: Brian Bosworth, the brash but talented linebacker who signed an $11 million, 10-year contract with Seattle after he was chosen out of the University of Oklahoma in the 1987 supplemental draft, was waived by the Seahawks yesterday after failing a physical on the injured right shoulder that kept him out most of last season.


Wells Fargo Is Acquiring 130 Branches
LEAD: The Great American Bank, a San Diego-based savings and loan that has had heavy losses, agreed today to sell its California branch network and other assets to Wells Fargo &amp; Company.


Wondering if Sanders Will Stay? So Is He.
LEAD: They were never rivals, Deion Sanders said last night.
That was simply a creation of the news media, something to stir competition.
He always liked and respected Bo Jackson, he said.
He even told Jackson that he admired him when the two of them were interviewed on a radio show in Kansas City two weeks ago.


Midland Montagu Is Closing Government Securities Unit
LEAD: The beleaguered Government securities business lost another primary dealer yesterday, as Midland Montagu, the international and investment banking arm of Britain's Midland Bank P.L.C., announced that it would close Midland Montagu Securities Inc. after an orderly winding down of business.

Kill New Weapons for a Peace Dividend
LEAD: Led by Sam Nunn, the Senate Armed Services Committee has sensibly trimmed $18 billion from the excessive $306 billion originally requested by the Bush Administration for defense in 1991.
That's a lot better than Defense Secretary Cheney's proposed cut of $8 billion.
But even the Nunn proposal falls far short of what's necessary now to reduce military spending by a reasonable 25 percent five years hence.


100,000 Must Leave Fez
LEAD: Morocco said today that the ancient city of Fez was falling into decay through overcrowding and that 100,000 residents would have to leave.
The normal population of 120,000 has swollen to over 300,000 without any new houses being built, Moulay Ahmed Alaoui, minister of State without portfolio, told a news conference.

Review/Pop;   A Triple Bill Takes Rock Back Toward Its Roots
LEAD: Rock roots have grown twisted over the last decade.
Before the 1980's, musicians who tried to hold onto roots were the conservative mainstream, battling newcomers who didn't respect old methods.
But with the arrival of computerized music, mainstream rock developed amnesia, leaving it to cranks and fringe elements to reclaim handmade sounds and traditional formats.

LEAD: A day after winning Soviet agreement to drop its objections to German unification, Chancellor Helmut Kohl extended the hand of conciliation and cooperation today and offered a vision of the first united German nation of the 20th century on good terms with all its neighbors.

Eastern Europeans Lack Money to Study in West
LEAD: Thousands of Eastern European students, eager to sample the educational offerings of the West, are seeking to matriculate at American universities, according to the United States Information Agency.


It's Only Money
LEAD: ''Hot dog!
That's where my money goes!'' is the refrain of an old drinking song celebrating some curious expenditures.
Here is where money goes nowadays: LAWYERS STRIKE AGAIN ''Effectively out of cash.'' That's The New York Times's report on the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust.
It was set up in 1988 to pay workers' claims for illness caused by inhaling asbestos fibers.


Prostitute in Article Is Ordered Released
LEAD: An Oakland prostitute was ordered released today from jail where she was detained as the police sought to charge her with attempted murder.
She had been arrested after Newsweek magazine quoted her as saying she continued to work despite being infected with the AIDS virus.


Three Drug Companies Post Strong Profits
LEAD: Eli Lilly &amp; Company, Pfizer Inc. and the Upjohn Company said yesterday that they had double-digit gains in profits and sales of drug and health-care products in the three months ended June 30.


Rose in Court Tomorrow For Tax-Case Sentencing
LEAD: Having been banished from baseball for the rest of his life, Pete Rose will learn tomorrow if he has to spend part of that life in prison.


Subsidies for Artists: Is Denying a Grant Really Censorship?
LEAD: Visitors to the benefit performance staged the other night for the Franklin Furnace, an avant-garde performance space in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan, heard angry protesters warn against what they perceived as Government censorship of the arts.


Chronicle
LEAD: JOE COCKER has scheduled a benefit concert for his neighbors in Santa Barbara, Calif., whose homes were ravaged by fire last month.
The rock-and-roll singer lives less than a mile from the area where more than 524 structures, mostly homes, were burned.


Valentin Pikul Is Dead; Historical Novelist, 62
LEAD: Valentin Pikul, a popular historical novelist whose books focused on Russia's sweeping upheavals, has died, the news agency Tass reported today.
He was 62 years old.


F.D.A. Critical Of Drug Lab
LEAD: Eleven of 13 studies conducted for generic drug manufacturers by a Pittsburgh laboratory violated regulations of the Food and Drug Administration or standards of good laboratory practice, according to an F.D.A. inspection, the agency has said.


Sharon Plan for Immigrants Derailed
LEAD: An Israeli Cabinet minister and the Supreme Court both dealt blows today to Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's emergency program to provide housing for the huge influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants.


Bridge
LEAD: There are times at the bridge table when virtue has to be its own reward.
The diagramed deal, played July 2 in a Pan-American Pairs in Washington, is an extreme example.
Brad Moss and Michael Radin, both of Manhattan, bid superbly to reach the perfect contract, but emerged with the same score as those whose efforts were pedestrian.


Laura Perls, 84, Dies in Germany; Founder of Gestalt Psychotherapy
LEAD: Laura Perls, a founder of the Gestalt school of psychotherapy, died Friday in Pforzheim, West Germany.
She was 84 years old.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD: The Economy


Nynex Denies 1988 Actions Raised Rates
LEAD: The chairman of the Nynex Corporation said yesterday that the company had dismissed two purchasing employees and disciplined six others in the summer of 1988 for improper business activities, but he insisted that their actions had not resulted in higher telephone rates for New York residents.


Synagogue Accord Is Reached To Allow Services in a House
LEAD: Village officials and a group of Jews in Westhampton Beach agreed today to allow religious services at a house here, a lawyer said.


Soviets Report New Clashes In Central Asian City of Osh
LEAD: New ethnic clashes have broken out in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, injuring 27 people, the Tass press agency said today.
It said the police fired warning shots to break up the fighting.


Red Sox Hit Into Two Triple Plays But Win
LEAD: Minnesota became the first team in major league history to get two triple plays in one game last night, but it wasn't enough to overcome eight shutout innings by Tom Bolton as the Boston Red Sox beat the Twins, 1-0.


Bond Sells Assets To Lower Its Debt
LEAD: Bond Corporation Holdings, the Australian-based conglomerate, said it had sold more assets to cut its debt of $6.67 billion (Australian), about $5.3 billion (United States).
It said that in April it had sold its Observation City seaside resort in northern Perth to Pakwell Pty. for $77.34 million (Australian).


Steinbrenner Reportedly Cited Fear of Spira
LEAD: George Steinbrenner told Commissioner Fay Vincent that he paid $40,000 to Howard Spira because he feared Spira would harm him or his family, The National reported today.


Lawrence Zirinsky, 72, Real-Estate Developer
LEAD: Lawrence Zirinsky, a real-estate developer, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Details Are Given In Addidas Deal
LEAD: Bernard Tapie, the French businessman who announced on July 7 that he would take over Addidas A.G., the West German sporting goods manufacturer, said here Monday that he would pay $290 million for an 80 percent stake and receive financing from eight French, German and Japanese banks.
Mr.
Tapie, a soccer team owner and Socialist member of Parliament, had not given details when he made his annoucement in Rome before the finals of the World


Rig Count Falls in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States fell by 10 last week, to 1,001, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday.
It was the third consecutive week of decline.
A year ago the count stood at 820.


Manslaughter Is New Charge In Vento Case
LEAD: A grand jury filed superseding indictments yesterday adding manslaughter charges to earlier charges against John S. Vento and four other defendants in the Bensonhurst murder case, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced.


Citicorp Posts 37% Drop in Net
LEAD: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that its earnings fell 37 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, despite continued growth in its highly profitable consumer banking businesses.


New Reactor Designs Are Criticized in Report
LEAD: Manufacturers designing a new generation of nuclear reactors overstate the safety benefits of new features, and their changes would leave the plants more vulnerable than current designs to certain kinds of accidents, according to a 200-page study released yesterday by a nuclear watchdog group.

LEAD: The North Hempstead Town Council cleared the way today for Nassau County's first permanent housing for the homeless when one Council member, after changing his mind several times, finally said he would support the plan for the six-family building.

Results Plus
LEAD:
TENNIS
McEnroe Defeats Chamberlin
John McEnroe, making his first tournament appearance since an opening-round loss at Wimbledon, defeated Paul Chamberlin, 6-2, 6-3, last night in a second-round match of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington.
McEnroe, seeded third, did not face a break point until the last game of the match and he broke Chamberlin in the sixth game of each set.

LEAD: As the Bush Administration and Congressional Democrats sought to narrow their differences over taxes, restive House Republicans made plain today that they would vigorously oppose any tax increase.


5 POWERS REPORT GAINS ON CAMBODIA
LEAD: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council announced today that they had advanced toward agreement on a peace formula for Cambodia, but they gave no hint that the warring factions were any closer to settling their differences.


Supermarkets Reach Out To Hispanic Customers
LEAD: FROM the tortilleria of the Tianguis supermarket here comes the slap, slap, slap of women making tortillas by hand.
On a Saturday afternoon, the market is in perpetual motion: women mix, shape and bake tortillas almost nonstop.
The result is corn tortillas, flour tortillas (with or without lard), corn chips and tostados.

LEAD: President Bush sought today to dispel any suggestion that Germany and the Soviet Union had reached an independent agreement on German unification, saying the United States ''has been in the forefront'' on the issue since before the Berlin wall was opened.


Coach Is Suspended
LEAD: Chuck DeBus of Santa Monica, Calif., the longtime coach of the Los Angeles Track Club and a former coach at U.C.L.A., has been suspended from track and field for life, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.

Trade Deficit Increases Modestly
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit rose modestly in May, to $7.73 billion, fueled by the economy's heavy reliance on oil imports and foreign automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today.

Sell Cars, Not Racism
LEAD: American auto dealers are running ads that attack the Japanese, with slighting references to samurai warriors and physical stature.

Disputing the cost or quality of Japanese cars is fair game; attacking their makers is not.

East German Job Data
LEAD: East German unemployment soared by 60 percent in the first two weeks of July to reach 224,000, Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt said today.
She told the A.D.N. news agency that between 30,000 and 40,000 people were joining the unemployment lines weekly.
Another 500,000 have applied for short-time work - a Government-sponsored halfway stage between employment and joblessness - since East and West Germany merged their economies along free market lines July 1, she said.

Scientists Say Gene On Y Chromosome Makes a Man a Man
LEAD: The mystery of what makes a man a man may never be solved, but scientists now think they know what makes a male masculine.
They have found a key gene on the Y chromosome that seems to act as a master switch for maleness, transforming a growing human fetus that otherwise would become a girl into a baby boy.


For Some, 'No Beards' Is Painful Job Rule
LEAD: For millions of men with coarse, curly hair there is no such thing as a smooth clean shave.
For these men, shaving is painful because they develop razor bumps on the face and neck from the closely cut ends of hairs that imbed themselves to irritate and scar the skin.


Taped Confession Played at Jogger Trial
LEAD: A Manhattan jury viewed in silence yesterday a videotape in which one defendant in the Central Park jogger case detailed the rape and beating of the victim.

LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the nation's largest airline company, said yesterday that its earnings fell 27.4 percent in the second quarter because of weaker traffic than expected and higher operating expenses.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices sagged and long-term interest rates rose fairly sharply yesterday in response to disappointing inflation news and badly received testimony from the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan.

Shiite Fighting Rages in South Lebanon
LEAD: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen fought fierce battles in southern Lebanon today for the third day in a row, and the police said 21 people were killed and 40 wounded.


Iraq Speaks of Acts of War
LEAD: Iraq warned fellow OPEC members today that it viewed violations of the cartel's production quotas as virtual acts of war, and accused neighboring Kuwait of stealing its oil over the last decade.


Polaroid's Profit Drops 23%
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation reported Tuesday that weak demand for its instant-picture products pulled second-quarter earnings down 23 percent.

U.S. Imports Record 49.9% of Oil
LEAD: The United States imported a record 49.9 percent of its oil destined for its homes, autos and factories in the first half of this year, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
The half-year statistics confirm a trend that has been evident in fits and starts for months: the decline of the


Evolution in Europe;   4 Killed and 100 Are Injured In Unrest in Soviet Republic
LEAD: Ethnic protesters burned buildings and attacked a police officer in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia overnight, leaving four people dead, the official Tass press agency said today.


Profits Rise At 4 Large Drug Makers
LEAD: Merck &amp; Company, the world's largest drug company, said yesterday that its profits rose by 18.6 percent in the second quarter, which was in line with the company's forecasts of a slower growth in earnings after a 24 percent increase in all of 1989.
Merck's sales in the quarter increased by 19.8 percent, surpassing analysts' predictions.

LEAD: Lately, preoccupied with the summit meetings of NATO in London and the industrial democracies in Houston, the Administration has downplayed the Middle East.
Understandable as this diversion of attention may be, events may not permit the luxury of delay.


Omen for Young: Low Black Turnout
LEAD: In his bid to become Georgia's first black governor, Andrew Young may have won a place on the runoff ballot Tuesday in the state's Democratic gubernatorial primary, but many of his campaign aides and other political observers said today that he had failed to generate the enthusiasm among black voters needed to win the nomination.

General Dynamics Loss Tied to Cost Overruns
LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation said today that it had a $240 million loss in the second quarter after setting aside $450 million to account for cost overruns on a new combat plane for the Navy.
But the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, General Dynamics' partner in building the Navy plane, decided not to take a financial charge on the program and reported a profit of $57 million for the period.

LEAD: Its circulation is small, its stance conservative.
Its editor is Dominic Lawson, the son of a prominent Tory.
So when The Spectator became the magazine that brought down a senior Cabinet member in the Conservative Thatcher Government last week, some saw it as paradoxical.

LEAD: Two Soviet astronauts walking in space were trapped outside the Mir space station on Tuesday when an airlock door failed to close, forcing them to use an emergency re-entry procedure as their air supplies ran dangerously low, Soviet press reports and American experts said yesterday.

Price Index Surged 0.5% Last Month
LEAD: Surges in the prices of food, housing and gasoline led to a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices in June, the Labor Department said today.
The unexpectedly sharp rise followed two months of more modest advances and moved the annual rate of inflation up to 5.9 percent so far this year.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Agassi Struggles to Victory
Top-seeded Andre Agassi, playing for the first time since his loss in the French Open final, struggled through a first-set tie breaker before defeating Brad Pearce, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington.
Agassi, ranked fourth in the world, trailed, 4-2, in the first set and faced a set point in the tie breaker before winning it, 9-7.


G.E. Unit Buys British Concern
LEAD: The GE Capital Corporation, the financial services subsidiary of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that it had acquired Burton Group Financial Services P.L.C. of Britain, which manages credit-card accounts and provides other services to retailers, for $329 million in cash.

LEAD: In Greek mythology, the Elysian Fields are the haven at the ends of the earth where the most exalted heroes go after death.
At the Old Course, they are the sanctuaries of fairway between the hellish bunkers on the 567-yard 14th hole.

Shad Quits as Chairman In Shake-Up at Drexel
LEAD: John S. R. Shad resigned yesterday as the chairman of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, as the firm moved to put more outsiders on its board.

Shad as chairman.

LEAD: Just 90 minutes into his new job, an automobile salesman was accosted at knifepoint by his first customers, 19-year-old twins who proceeded to steal the car they wanted to test drive, the police said.

Manley Still Banned
LEAD: Dexter Manley has been told by the National Football League that his reinstatement will not be considered until November, when he will have served one year of his drug suspension.
Manley, a Washington Redskins defensive end, was permanently banned from the N.F.L. on Nov. 18 for his third violation of the league's substance-abuse policy.

Extra Patrols To Be Added For 7 Precincts
LEAD: Stung by a steep rise in murders and robberies across New York City, the Dinkins administration announced yesterday that it would pay 200 police officers overtime wages each day to work extra shifts walking beats in seven of the most crime-ridden precincts.


Art, and My First Dirty Word
LEAD: When I was a little boy, my father spanked me when I was bad.
It was my mother's duty to teach me to distinguish between right and wrong.
When I stepped over the boundaries she had set for me, I knew I had him to answer to.
She taught, he punished and I grew up.

LEAD: In a textbook tale of politics and personalities, a developer's embattled effort to build a luxury apartment tower on the site of a landmark tenement complex in Manhattan took a twist yesterday that combined a debate, a delay and a hand from one of Mayor David N. Dinkins's closest supporters.


Who Says A Factory Must Look Like One?
LEAD: THE British designer David Mellor believes that Britain's post-World War II town planners made a ''major strategic mistake'' when they segregated the places where people worked from the places where they lived. ''I've always thought that manufacturing should be integrated with living and with the countryside,'' he said.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: RITA KLIMOVA, the popular, ebullient Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States, says she plans to work as long as possible while being treated for malignant leukemia in this country.
Mrs.
Klimova's cancer was diagnosed at Walter Reed Army Hospital three weeks ago.


80 SCHOOLS CHOSEN FOR NEW YORK TEST OF POWER SHARING
LEAD: Eighty New York City schools have been chosen to begin Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's trademark experiment in power sharing among teachers, parents and principals, but scores of other schools have signaled a stiffening resistance to the Chancellor by staying out of the process.

LEAD: The State of Washington offered a total of $195 million in general obligation bonds in the tax-exempt municipal bond market yesterday.


Oil Leaks Into Arthur Kill After 2 Barges Collide
LEAD: A barge leaving Exxon's Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., slammed into a sister barge that was docked there yesterday, dumping 37,000 gallons of home heating oil into the Arthur Kill.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace referred incorrectly in some editions to the outcome of the Alger Hiss case.


New Sonoco President Plans Worldwide Focus
LEAD: The Sonoco Products Company is not well known but it has been around for a while.
It declared its 263d consecutive quarterly dividend yesterday and it also announced a new president and chief operating officer, Russell C. King Jr.
Mr.
King, 55, has worked for the manufacturer of paper and plastic products, which is the largest producer of plastic grocery sacks, since he got out of Wofford College, in Spartanburg, S.C., in 1956.

LEAD: *
New York Pride has chosen Fred/ Alan Inc. to create an anti-litter campaign, which will begin in the late summer or early fall.
New York Pride has also worked with Burkhardt &amp; Christy Advertising on a campaign to encourage New Yorkers to be nicer.

The papers were served yesterday to her bedside at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.

LEAD: For lovers of antiques, the setting could not be better.

And on to the main ballroom, to find pieces of blue and white china from the 1700's to the present.

Home Builders See Recession And Blame the Savings Crisis
LEAD: For the first time since the recession of the early 1980's, the rate of new housing construction has dropped for five consecutive months, providing further proof, home builders say, that the economic and regulatory fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled one of the country's biggest industries into a recession.

Organizers: Chip vs. Paper
LEAD: THE computers I have been using are the size of small paperback books.
They contain as much memory as desk-top computers did 10 years ago.
Each can store over 1,000 telephone numbers and addresses, calculate spread sheets, keep my daily schedule and tell the time in over 200 cities.


The Cambodian Ordeal: A Country Bleeds for 15 Years
LEAD: Aril 1975 Communist guerrillas of the Khmer Rouge seize the capital, Phnom Penh, defeating the non-Communist Government of Marshal Lon Nol.
Under the leadership of Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge impose a brutal reorganization of society in which more than a million people die.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, their virtual prisoner, is named head of state.

Review/Television;   New Entry in the Late-Night Stakes
LEAD: Like everyone else in television, ABC is struggling to squeeze a bit more profit out of every hour in every day.
The late-night schedule is one obvious target area, with its captive audience of insomniacs.
ABC has done very nicely indeed with Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' at 11:30 P.M.
Now, deciding to follow that think-tank format with some comic relief, the network is opening up its midnight slot Monday through Friday to ''Into the Night Starring Rick Dees.

LEAD: John Pike, the space specialist of the Federation of American Scientists, has observed fatalistically that recent troubling events at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration mostly reflect Murphy's Law in orbit: Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the savings and loan crisis misstated the percentage of respondents in a Gallup poll who believed that neither the Republicans nor the Democrats were to blame.
It was 10 percent, not 81 percent.
Over all, 35 percent said the Republicans were more to blame, 19 percent said the Democrats, 16 percent blamed both and 20 percent said they did not know.


Arbitrator Finds 3d Case of Baseball Collusion
LEAD: Major league baseball players completed a sweep of the collusion cases yesterday when an independent arbitrator ruled that club owners willfully acted against free agents by using a salary-offer databank in 1987 even though they had just been found guilty in the initial collusion case.

No Headline
LEAD: AIR-CONDITIONERS that don't cool correctly often need new thermostats, control switches or fan motors, or perhaps just a thorough cleaning, said Ellen Elias, a vice president of Elgot, a family business that has been repairing air-conditioners for 45 years.
She added that excessive noise might be caused by a manufacturing defect or improper installation.

INSIDE
LEAD:
Senate Passes Civil Rights Bill
The Senate passed a major civil rights bill in a form that President Bush has threatened to veto.
The vote on the sweeping measure to bar job discrimination was 65 to 34.
A White House spokesman said Mr.
Bush would work with the House to seek a bill he could sign.

LEAD: FOR years, people have been asking Mary Ellisor Emmerling when the American Country style will run its course. ''Never,'' she answers. ''It's just getting better and better.
It's not a fad, it's a life style.''


Review/Music;   Perlman And Ax
LEAD: Though it may not rank up there with weighty issues like performance practice, the matter of who gets top billing in a concert program is not wholly negligible, since it can affect the way in which music is perceived.
These days - perhaps always - billing has more to do with celebrity than with historical or musical sense, so it was altogether predictable that the violinist Itzhak Perlman would outrank the pianist Emanuel Ax in their joint recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.


Finnish Scientists to Study Gravity in Eclipse
LEAD: When the Moon eclipses the Sun this weekend, scientists in Finland plan to conduct a wide variety of experiments to test whether the gravity of one massive body can partly shield that of another.


Talking Deals;   Sour Investment By Pension Funds
LEAD: A $425 MILLION deal that was widely heralded last year as the entry of American pension funds into Europe's real estate markets has been hammered recently by high interest rates in Britain, and the investors that took part in the deal have watched the value of the properties drop sharply in the last few months.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE ECONOMY
Housing construction has declined for five months in a row, the first time that has happened since the recession of the early 1980's.
Home builders say the fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled their industry into a recession. [Page A1.]
Greenspan suggested that rates would not come down soon, to offset unusually restrictive bank lending practices.

Rolls-Royce Cuts
LEAD: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the aircraft engine maker, said it would eliminate up to 800 jobs at its Bristol, England, plant.
The cuts will be over the next two years, a company spokesman said.
The plant, which employs about 8,000 people, makes military aircraft engines.
The spokesman said the cuts were required because of the British Government's recent cancellation of an order for 33 Tornado aircraft.


Loss Reported At HomeFed
LEAD: The HomeFed Corporation, the parent of HomeFed Bank, a San Diego-based savings institution, today reported a second-quarter loss of $108.2 million after setting up a loss provision of $234 million to cover a rise in problem real estate loans.


San Francisco Treating Ex-Squatters as Guests
LEAD: Most of the indigent men evicted from their sour-smelling bedrolls in a downtown park here the other day are now enjoying clean towels, catered meals, free telephones and the advice and comfort of caseworkers at two new shelters, where the homeless are invariably referred to as guests.


A Sure Way to Beat the Heat, and a Great Excuse to Do So

Butler T. Henderson, Educator, 71
LEAD: Butler T. Henderson, an official of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund for the last 18 years, died at St.
Luke's Hospital on Monday.
He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Corning to Sell Most of Iwaki Stake
LEAD: Corning Inc. agreed to sell most of its 33.4 percent stake in the Iwaki Glass Company, a Tokyo-based manufacturer of industrial, consumer and laboratory products, to its partner in the concern, the Asahi Glass Company.
Corning would not disclose the amount, but said the deal would result in a one-time gain after taxes of $18 million against its third-quarter earnings.


British Plea to Workers
LEAD: The British Government urged workers today to hold down demands for higher wages as the country's unemployment rate increased for the third straight month.
The number of people out of work in June rose by 5,600, to a seasonally adjusted 1.62 million, or 5.7 percent of the work force, unchanged from May's revised figure, the Department of Employment said.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $3.67 billion, to $389.91 billion, for the week ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 160 institutional funds increased by $2.99 billion, to $94.81 billion.
The assets of the 251 general-purpose funds were up by $313.30 million, to $134.70 billion.


2 Brothers Admit Fraud Scheme; Judge Orders Fines of $1.2 Million
LEAD: Two brothers who operate an electrical contracting company pleaded guilty yesterday to fraudulently billing the City of New York and agreed to pay fines of as much as $1.2 million, city investigators said.


Slain Woman 'Loved Her TV' and Baseball
LEAD: At 91 years of age, Susie White still did her own shopping, attended church on most Sundays, and enjoyed going on trips with the Senior Citizens Center of the James Monroe Houses in the Soundview section of the Bronx.


Tiozzo to Make Title Defense
LEAD: Christophe Tiozzo of France makes the first defense of his World Boxing Association supermiddleweight title Friday night against Paul Whittaker of Kenner, La.


Youth Drowns in a Brooklyn Creek


Patchogue Clamming Is Back
LEAD: Six years after a 750-acre area of Patchogue Bay was found too polluted for shellfishing, the state has declared the clams clean and reopened the waters.
The pollution had stemmed from Patchogue's sewage plant, which was upgraded in 1985.
The town of Brookhaven and Suffolk County tested the water and the shellfish for three years, and the State Environmental Conservation Department said Wednesday that shellfishing could resume.

Navistar May Bid For Mack Trucks
LEAD: The Navistar International Transportation Corporation may top the French car maker Renault S.A.'s $100 million offer for Mack Trucks Inc., the ailing truck maker said.
Renault, which is owned by the French Government, controls 44.5 percent of Mack and is bidding $6 a share, or $100 million, for the remaining shares.

Review/Theater;   Gotta Sing! (But Only if the Song's in a Failed Show.)
LEAD: ''Ed Linderman's Broadway Jukebox'' has a nifty concept.
On entering the John Houseman Theater, patrons are handed a list of 85 songs chosen mostly from unsuccessful shows of the last three decades and given slips of paper on which to vote for the ones they would like to hear.


Man With Shotgun Killed by Police Had a Record
LEAD: The man who was killed in a fusillade of police bullets on Wednesday as he walked down a Brooklyn street waving a sawed-off shotgun and asking to see his wife was a house painter with a history of arrests, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: The former chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas pleaded not guilty today to bank-fraud charges stemming from his efforts to finance a $700 million real estate deal in California.

LEAD: The Archbishop of Newfoundland has resigned after charges that the Roman Catholic Church's hierarchy ignored or failed to deal effectively with three years of scandal involving allegations of sexual abuse against altar boys, orphaned youths and others by Roman Catholic priests and church laymen.


75 Percent of Oil Spill Is Out of Arthur Kill
LEAD: More than 75 percent of a 40,000-gallon oil spill in the Arthur Kill had been recovered or evaporated and the shipping channel was open to all traffic this afternoon, the United States Coast Guard said.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers.
At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers.

Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 2.8% on Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest for the period ended July 13 decreased by 2.8 percent from a record level for the period ended a month ago.
The decline amounted to 18.6 million shares.
Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

New European Telescope Called Equal to Hubble
LEAD: While the space agency tries to overcome a crippling flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope, European scientists have developed a new type of ground-based telescope that promises to work as well as a perfectly functioning space-based instrument at a small fraction of the Hubble's cost.

LEAD: D. George Harris &amp; Associates, an investment group, said it had agreed to acquire the soda products division of the Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation, an energy and chemical company based in Oklahoma City, for $210 million.
The division has 1,100 employees.
The deal includes three chemical-processing plants in Trona, Calif.

Lotus Shares Fall On Income Report
LEAD: A day after saying that its third-quarter net income would be lower than the previous year's, the shares of the Lotus Development Corporation fell $6.125 each yesterday, to $25.125, in over-the-counter trading.
Scott Smith of the Donaldson, Lufkin &amp; Jenrette Securities Corporation said he had downgraded Lotus to an unattractive rating, from a neutral, based on the announcement.

The men who fight Middle Eastern terrorists in this new action film are a mere step away from the adolescent Turtles in maturity and complexity of character, though they are not likely to come near them in box-office grosses.

LEAD: Pollution problems at properties the Government has taken from failed savings institutions will add billions of dollars to the cost of the savings and loan bailout, Government officials and environmental experts said today.

LEAD: Carl (the Truth) Williams twice said he had back problems and pulled out of a scheduled heavyweight bout with Tyrell Biggs, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist.
The match was rescheduled for a third time, next Tuesday in Atlantic City.
But this time Biggs came up with an aching back and withdrew.

The college said he died of lung cancer.

J.R. Carroll, 85, Dies; Philadelphia Architect
LEAD: J. Roy Carroll Jr., a Philadelphia architect who was a former president of the American Institute of Architects, died on Tuesday at Crozer Hospital in Chester, Pa.
He was 85 years old and lived in Swarthmore, Pa.
He died after a short illness, his family said.
Among Mr.
Carroll's best-known designs were two Philadelphia landmarks, Prentiss House of the Presbyterian Board of Pensions and the headquarters of the American Society for Testing and Materials.

The Big Plunge on School Reform
LEAD: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, has long promoted the idea that principals, teachers and parents in individual schools ought to share power.
Now 117 of the city's 984 schools are ready to take up the challenge.
In a system that already divides authority between a central board and 32 community boards, giving more power to individual schools is the ultimate decentralization plan, and it's off to a reasonable start.

LEAD: MCA Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings increased 6.7 percent, to $44.8 million, or 54 cents a share, from $42 million, or 58 cents a share, on fewer shares in the period a year ago.

LEAD: Soccer officials from East and West Germany agreed today to merge their leagues and form a joint national team next year.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of editing errors, an article on Monday about the Richard Nixon Library, and a resulting correction in this space yesterday, referred incorrectly to the outcome of the Alger Hiss case in 1950.
The charge on which Mr.
Hiss was convicted was perjury, arising from his denial of having provided secret State Department documents to a confessed former Communist spy, Whittaker Chambers.


Dr. David Decker, Cancer Researcher, 72
LEAD: Dr.
David Decker, who developed two important drugs in the treatment of ovarian cancer, died of bone cancer Tuesday at his home here.
He was 72 years old.
Dr.
Decker joined the Mayo Clinic in 1947 as a graduate fellow and became a consultant in 1950.
He was chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology from 1969 to 1977.

Georges Dargaud, 79; Published Tintin Books
LEAD: Georges Dargaud, who first published the popular Tintin books and the Asterix comic-book series, died Wednesday after a long illness, his publishing house said today.
He was 79 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed.
Mr.
Dargaud founded Dargaud Editeur in 1936 and took an active role in operating the publishing house until selling it to the Media Participation group in January 1989.

Outdoors, Concert Fare That's Serious And Rare
LEAD: MANY concertgoers consider hearing music out of doors an inherently less focused undertaking than listening to a performance in a concert hall.
That view is not groundless: outdoor concerts are often built on decidedly ''lite'' fare, and encourage the notion that the performances, like Baroque Tafelmusik, are being offered as pleasantly innocuous dinner music.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Rostagno Stops McEnroe Again
Derrick Rostagno yesterday defeated John McEnroe for the second time in a month, duplicating his Wimbledon upset with a 6-3, 1-6, 6-1 victory in the third round of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington.
Rostagno, ranked 113th in the world, lost his serve only twice - when he dropped the second set - and charged through the third set by breaking McEnroe twice.

Bloch was to appear at a hearing to protest efforts to dismiss him as a national security threat, the department said.

Prostitute Was Paid For Newsweek Article
LEAD: Newsweek has acknowledged paying an Oakland prostitute $60 after she posed for a photograph and told the magazine's reporter that she was continuing to work the streets despite being infected with the AIDS virus.


Leary Wins and Righetti Sets a Record
LEAD: At a time in Yankee history when the avoidance of ignominy can be considered a sign of progress, Tim Leary made progress tonight.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Won some, lost some, all interesting.''
- Former President Richard M. Nixon, reviewing his political career. [A1:2.]


Magazines' Ad Prospects Look Bleak
LEAD: AS magazine publishers start negotiating with advertisers this month for advertising contracts for 1991, the publishers are faced with a bleak prospect.
It is beginning to look as if some important advertisers are not very interested in magazines, and the downturn in advertising that began this year may pick up momentum next year.


Hasbro Net Off Sharply
LEAD: Sharply lower sales during the last three months cut Hasbro Inc.'s second-quarter profits nearly 52 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, the company said today.
The toy maker earned $8.7 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $18.1 million, or 31 cents a share.
The results stem from dismal revenues of about $277.2 million during this year's second quarter, down 7.9 percent from $301.3 million.

Remi


Review/Film;   Marlon Brando as Importer, Or Whatever It Is He Does
LEAD: Daybreak.
A cornfield.
Two men in evening clothes.
And a seven-foot lizard on a leash.
These components of the final scene of ''The Freshman,'' a witty and enchanted comedy written and directed by Andrew Bergman, will not reveal anything worthwhile about how the film's mad plot finally resolves itself.

Gallimard's President Wins Control
LEAD: A bitter family battle for control of Editions Gallimard ended today with a victory for its president, Antoine Gallimard.


Textron Has 21.6% Gain
LEAD: Textron Inc. reported today that its net income in the second quarter was up 21.6 percent, to $72.1 million.
The company said the earnings, which amounted to 80 cents a share, had improved from the $59.3 million, or 67 cents a share, it earned from April through June 1989.

He was 84 years old and lived in Flower Hill, L.I.

Jerusalem Journal;   The Uprising Finds Its Way Into Art
LEAD: For years Palestinians have walked down a dirt alley between two dilapidated office buildings to reach the Arab Cultural Center, only to find that works with nationalist themes have been condemned or banned by the Israelis.


Mongolia Votes Tomorrow
LEAD: Mongolia holds its first free elections on Sunday.
The governing Communist Party is expected to win, although its grip on power might be loosened.
Mongolians are joining the demands for freedom and democracy that have swept across the Soviet bloc.
In March, Parliament gave up the Communists' constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power.


Midtown Spree Of 20 Robberies Linked to Trio
LEAD: Three men arrested on Thursday after a drugstore holdup were responsible for at least 20 robberies - and possibly as many as 40 - of small businesses and food stores in midtown Manhattan in the last two months, the police said yesterday.

Evolution in Europe;   Ousted but Unrepentant, Jakes Keeps the Faith in a Prague Villa
LEAD: Secluded, idle and unrepentant, Milos Jakes sat in the villa that is his sole remaining perquisite from the days only eight months back when he ruled Czechoslovakia.
He ruminated about the collapse of a system and professed his unaltered faith in Communism.

Now a New Europe
LEAD: Now comes the long, intricate process of reorganizing Europe.
The last couple of weeks - the NATO summit meeting, the Kohl-Gorbachev accord, the Paris talks on Germany - have removed all important barriers that kept Germany and the Continent divided since World War II.


Walter Davis Stays Put
LEAD: Walter Davis, who is 35 years old and a 13-year veteran in the National Basketball Association, has signed a two-year contract with the Nuggets, choosing to remain in Denver because he has a daughter about to enter grade school there and a wife who loves the Rocky Mountains.

In Drug Case, Mayor's Brother Is Sent to Jail
LEAD: The brother of Mayor John Daniels of New Haven was sentenced today to four years in prison for drug dealing after telling the judge he was happy he was caught because otherwise ''I'd probably still be out there doing drugs.''


Washington Culture Center Delayed Over High Costs
LEAD: Plans for the construction of a $738 million International Cultural and Trade Center on Pennsylvania Avenue were suspended this week when the Government agency that was to lease the building refused to sign the contract.


Review/Dance;   Recalling the Critters of Wave Hill's Past
LEAD: The setting was idyllic. But the dance was prosaic.


An Assault on Police Discipline
LEAD: Ask New York City cops why they join the force and they'll tell you: helping people, steady work and the pension.
The threat of losing the generous pension benefit has long given administrators a way to enforce discipline.
A bill on Gov.
Mario Cuomo's desk would weaken that discipline; it would guarantee pensions even for officers who turn brutal or corrupt.

Universal Health
LEAD: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth raised its stake in Universal Health Services Inc. to the equivalent of 11.4 percent of the company's class B stock, from 10.3 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it had held, and expected to continue having, discussions with Universal's managers about its investment in the company.

Some Good Things Grow With a Little Neglect
LEAD: To the Editor:


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TRACK AND FIELD
Javelin Thrower Regains Mark
Steve Backley regained his world record in the men's javelin throw yesterday with a heave of 298 feet 6 inches in an International Amateur Athletic Federation Grand Prix meet at Crystal Palace in London.
Opposing Jan Zelezny of Czechoslovakia, the man who took the mark from him at Oslo, Norway, a week ago, Backley became the first man to throw the javelin more than 90 meters (295-3).

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about an advanced new European telescope misstated its resolving power in some copies.
It is 0.17 arc seconds, not 1.7 arc seconds. (An arc second is an angle equivalent to one-3,600th of a degree.) A diagram referred incorrectly to the type of telescope with a resolving power of 0.25 arc seconds.

LEAD: Nolan Ryan, with his fastball crackling, his curve and changeup behaving themselves nicely, moved along at an easy and rapid clip at Arlington Stadium tonight and was clearly on the way to the 299th victory of his remarkable 24-year major league career.

LEAD: The odyssey of Neil Bush and the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association began at a neighborhood dinner party in the spring of 1985, when he sat a few seats away from Michael Wise, said James E. Nesland, Mr.
Bush's lawyer.


Police Cleared In the Death Of a Suspect
LEAD: The Bronx District Attorney's office yesterday cleared nine police officers of responsibility for the death last September of an unarmed mugging suspect who died in police custody.


Bus Terminal Curbs Hosing
LEAD: For years the Port Authority has used water hoses to clean the sidewalks outside its midtown Manhattan bus terminal, washing away the trash and debris left by the 200,000 commuters who pass there each day.

The Hands That Caught Ryan's Heat
LEAD: Jeff Torborg talked about his left hand, the hand that caught most of Nolan Ryan's booming fastballs in 1973 when the two players were with the California Angels.
It was the year that Ryan, with his 100-mile-per-hour heater (give or take a mile or two per hour of smoke on a given outing), established the major league record for strikeouts in a season, 383.

Jim Florio pushed through the Legislature.

Houston Journal;   Seeking Some Relief, She Stepped Out of Line
LEAD: By LISA BELKIN


Corrections
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a leader of student protests at Wesleyan University, Nicholas B. Haddad, misstated his relationship to two men.
Mr.
Haddad knew, but was not related to, Kumar Viswanathan, who is accused in his killing, and Sudhama Ranganathan, who is accused of having fire-bombed the office of Wesleyan's president.

LEAD: The Minnesota Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a newspaper's promise to conceal the identity of a news source was not an enforceable oral contract.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The strenuous demands of Court work and its related duties required or expected of a Justice appear at this time to be incompatible with my advancing age and medical condition.
I, therefore, retire effective immediately as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.''
- Supreme Court Justice William J.





Furor Over Call to Sell Organs of Poor People
LEAD: A politician's proposal that the county government sell the organs of dead welfare recipients has prompted such outrage here that some experts fear it will undermine efforts to solve a serious shortage of organ donors.


Pledge for Arts Grants Is Modified
LEAD: Recipients of joint grants from the Rockefeller Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts may modify the pledge they are now required to make, according to instructions mailed to them by the foundation yesterday.


No Time for RICO 'Reform'
LEAD: Just as the savings and loan scandal awakens the public to the costs of fraud, some members of Congress propose undercutting the country's most sweeping civil fraud law.
The 1970 law is called ''Civil RICO,'' short for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations.
It enables private citizens as well as government to seek triple damages for all kinds of commercial fraud.

Jets Joined by 2 More
LEAD: Two more Jets joined the fold yesterday when Dale Dawkins, a ninth-round draft pick out of Miami, signed a contract and Curt Singer of Tennessee, a reserve free-agent tackle acquired last year, agreed to terms.
All players are required to report to camp by 6 P.M. tomorrow.
The signings brought the list of Jets draft choices signed to 8 of 15 taken.

Folk Museum Homeward Bound
LEAD: The Museum of American Folk Art's gypsy days are numbered.
Three years from now, the museum is to reopen in new quarters - four floors at the base of a new 28-story office tower - at its old address, 49 West 53d Street.
Construction of the building, designed by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings &amp; Merrill, is to begin next spring.

Some Good Things Grow With a Little Neglect;   A Corporate Effort
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about second-quarter earnings at Philip Morris Companies Inc. misstated the operating profit and volume gain of two units of its Kraft General Foods division.
Only the Kraft international operations, not Kraft domestic, posted a 50 percent increase in operating earnings and a 5 percent volume gain.


Giving Immunity Presents Hurdle for Conviction
LEAD: The ruling by a Federal appeals panel today ordering new hearings in Oliver L. North's case demonstrates the enormous difficulties in bringing to trial a public official who has previously been forced to testify in a high-visibility case before Congress.

Alaska Pipeline Reaches Accord
LEAD: The operator of the trans-Alaska pipeline, which carries a quarter of the nation's domestically produced oil, has reached an agreement with state officials on measures to cut air pollution, ending a threat that the pipeline would be shut down. the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the consortium of seven oil companies that operates the 800-mile pipeline, had threatened to cut off an important source of oil as a deadline approached for compliance with an Environmental Protection Agency order.


ISRAELI SAYS U.S. BACKS NEW MISSILE
LEAD: The United States will continue to back Israel's $160 million Arrow missile project, billed as the answer to the short-range weapons of neighboring Arab countries, Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel said today after meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

About New York;   They Are Gay, And Asking God To Save Them
LEAD: Here we are at Glad Tidings Tabernacle on West 33d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. ''Prayer is the Key,'' proclaims a banner. ''Praise the Lord!'' goes the hymn's refrain.
A single ceiling fan barely moves the stale air in a basement chapel.
Arms reach for heaven. ''Amens'' provide prayerful punctuation.

Mexico Asks U.S. to Arrest 2 Men Accused in Abduction of Doctor
LEAD: The Mexican Government, angered by the seizure in Guadalajara of a doctor accused in the torture and killing of an American drug agent, has asked the United States to arrest two men accused of involvement in the abduction.


Trottier Signs Contract To Join the Penguins
LEAD: For Bryan Trottier, the ride may not be over yet; he is just changing horses.
The Pittsburgh Penguins signed the former Islander center yesterday, just two and a half weeks after Trottier was released by a team he starred with for 15 seasons and helped lead to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships.


Ahmanson Sells Its Headquarters
LEAD: H. F. Ahmanson &amp; Company, a savings and loan holding company based here, sold its downtown headquarters building to a partnership between Kawasaki Enterprises Inc. of Japan and Takenaka &amp; Company in Los Angeles.
Ahmanson declined to disclose the sale price, but said it would record a $12 million pretax gain.

LEAD: The rock 'n' roll performer CHUCK BERRY has been charged with child abuse and possession of marijuana based on evidence seized in a raid on his home last month, according to the authorities in St.

Detective Asked About Handling Of Jogger Case
LEAD: A lawyer for a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial suggested yesterday that his client had been cowed and goaded into confessing by veiled threats of torture and lurid questions that challenged his masculinity.

Showdown Looms for Leaders
LEAD: The showdown between Greg LeMond of the United States and Claudio Chiappucci of Italy has come down to 28.5 miles on the next-to-last day instead of 15 miles on the final day.
And it will be in the rolling green hills and forests of central France instead of the shuttered buildings around Paris.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Government's sale of savings and loan assets referred incorrectly to a mandate to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the industry bailout.
The maximum number of years for which it is allowed to lend up to 85 percent of the purchase price to buyers of large asset portfolios is 5, not 15.


On the Defensive, Republicans Name a Spokesman
LEAD: Faced with rising partisan warfare around issues like taxes and the savings and loan scandal, the Republican National Committee moved to shore up its political operation today, announcing that Charles Black would serve as official spokesman during the illness of Lee Atwater, the party's national chairman.

Yankees Come Close But Not Close Enough
LEAD: The frustrations of a last-place team are not always humiliating.
More often, they result from the small opportunities that slip away, the decisive moments that form a pattern, and the long deep breath from a manager whose team has just lost a game that easily could have been won.


Steinbrenner Loses in Bid for More Witnesses
LEAD: Lawyers for George Steinbrenner failed yesterday in their effort to have Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner; Dave Winfield, the former Yankee outfielder, and Howard Spira heard as witnesses in Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation of the Yankees' principal owner.


Liberian Guerrillas Capture Monrovia's Northern Sector
LEAD: Rebels captured much of the northern part of Liberia's capital today after fighting pitched battles with the few hundred remaining soldiers defending President Samuel K. Doe.

LEAD: A $30 million lawsuit filed against GERALDO RIVERA by a woman who was arrested during a drug raid carried live on national television has been settled out of court in Houston for an undisclosed amount, lawyers for the two sides said yesterday.

Ford Gets Offers For Subsidiary
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has received three bids for its aerospace subsidiary and may accept one within a week, a company spokesman, Thomas Rhoades, said.
The bids were made by the Loral Corporation; a consortium including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the Carlyle Group, an investment firm, and Aerospatiale, the French aerospace company, and a joint offer by Alcatel N.V.


Joan Whitney Kramer, Singer and Songwriter, 76
LEAD: Joan Whitney Kramer, a singer and the co-author of many hit songs, died on July 12 in Westport, Conn.
She was 76 years old and lived in Westport.

Gary Carter Sidelined
LEAD: The San Francisco Giants yesterday placed Gary Carter, the former Mets catcher, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to July 9 because of a bruised right shoulder.
Kirt Manwaring, a catcher, was recalled from Phoenix of the Class AAA Pacific Coast League.(AP)


Seabrook at Full Power
LEAD: The Seabrook nuclear power plant, for years the focus of the nation's debate over whether atomic energy is safe, reached full power for the first time Thursday night.
New Hampshire Yankee, the operator of the $6.6 billion plant, said full power was reached at 9:52 P.M., the culmination of a series of power step-ups that had been under way since the Nuclear Regulatory Commission granted Seabrook a commercial operating license in March.

Beliefs

Disputed Lockheed Contract Is Canceled by Navy
LEAD: The Navy today dealt a major blow to the Lockheed Corporation, canceling a contract for the company to build a new generation of submarine-fighting aircraft because of what the Navy said was Lockheed's inadequate performance.


Arteries Are Unblocked Without Drugs in Study
LEAD: People with blocked coronary arteries who adhere to a strict vegetarian diet, engage in mild daily exercise and practice stress-reduction techniques can reverse the blockage, according to a study being published today.

Rethink Space
LEAD: In the wake of the Hubble Space Telescope catastrophe and the grounding of the space shuttle fleet, Vice President Quayle has set up a review of NASA's direction and goals.
A review is surely needed.
Both NASA's hardware and the goals the White House has set for it are still pointed to the needs of a different era.

LEAD: Connecticut's Republican Party, buoyant but still stung by the defection of former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., filled the Civic Center here tonight to start a two-day convention that is expected to culminate on Saturday with the nomination of Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury for governor.

LEAD: Montreal's starting catcher, Nelson Santovenia, will undergo surgery for torn cartilage in his left knee today and will be lost to the Expos for at least six weeks.
Santovenia, who is batting .191, was placed on the disabled list on Thursday.(AP)

Philip Leacock, 72, Director of Movies And Dramas for TV
LEAD: Philip Leacock, a film and television director, died on July 14 while on holiday in London with his family.
He was 72 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.
No cause of death was given.
The British-born Mr.
Leacock, who made documentaries before taking on feature-length movies, had his first hit in 1950 with ''The Kidnappers,'' a family movie set in Nova Scotia.


Morihiko Hasegawa, Toy Marketer, 62
LEAD: Morihiko Hasegawa, president of Play-Jour International, a toy marketing company based in Tokyo, died on July 13 at St.
Mariana Hospital in Kawasaki, Japan.
He was 62 years old and lived in Yokohama.
A Play-Jour spokesman said he died of cancer.


BRENNAN, KEY LIBERAL, QUITS SUPREME COURT; BATTLE FOR SEAT LIKELY
LEAD: Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the Supreme Court's senior member, resigned from the Court tonight, effective immediately.

LEAD: The nation's savings institutions lost net deposits of $19.9 billion in the first two months of 1990, nearly matching the record outflows of a year earlier, the Government said today.

LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh declared today that his Government would not yield to separatist groups seeking independence in the state of Kashmir.

LEAD: A senior State Department official told Congress today that China had agreed to stop arms shipments to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and to support a disarming of all military forces in Cambodia as part of an arrangement leading to elections there.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
THE STATIONS OF SOLITUDE.
By Alice Koller. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this account of her struggles with self-imposed solitude, the essayist Alice Koller discloses her most intimate secrets with startling nonchalance.
She can get away with this because she stands as far away from us as possible and because her voice is strong and carries, not only from the New England and Virginia country houses where she has spent the past 28 years, but from the place just beyond the pale of human contact where she lives.


Wave Hill Forced to Disband Cultural Programs
LEAD: Wave Hill, the park and cultural center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, will eliminate its concerts, dance series and art exhibitions and cut its staff by 20 percent during the next year.


Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
LEAD: It is true that Strawberry has been scalding for the last six weeks, but his track record shows him to have had such spurts before.
It is also admirable that he has chosen to change his life, becoming consistently more alert and determined.

LEAD: Elizabeth Dorsey Weber and Karl-Erik Leopoldo Gude were married yesterday at the Scarborough (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev.
George A. Van Arnam, a United Methodist minister who is an uncle of the bride.


So Close To 3,000 - And Then So Far
LEAD: Just when everyone knew the program traders were going to bail them out by buying stocks, they didn't.
That may be the simplest summary of a week when the Dow Jones industrial average first failed to close over 3,000 by the smallest margin possible, and then saw prices crumble in the final moments Friday.

Charles O. Milford, a Baptist minister, and Rabbi Alvin Roth officiated.

'A Deed of Death'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Furious About Cable
LEAD: The Cable Act of 1984 freed cable television companies to gouge customers.
And gouge is just what many of them did - with wretched service and unconscionable rates.
One company had to be forced by law just to answer telephone calls from an army of irate customers.
In the cable business, one Congressman gibed, ''customer service is an oxymoron.


Dandelions and Rabbits Need Space, Too
LEAD: IT did not start out as a contest.
The catbird was just singing from a branch of the pine tree with a long happy series of chortles, trills and burbles that made up a happy tune.
The song sounded very much like the endless cheer of the purple finch, until the catbird was spotted from below.


Lip-Synching Can Make Music Sweeter
LEAD: The recent fuss over canned music at live concerts assumes there's a con going on.
The argument, put forth by rock critics and legislators, holds that real music must have real live musicians playing it.
Anything else is aural Naugahyde.


Sergei Paradzhanov, Armenian Director, 66
LEAD: Sergei Paradzhanov, an Armenian film director, has died after a long illness, the official press agency Tass said today.
He was 66 years old.


Evolution in Europe;   Immigrants for South Africa
LEAD: More than 48,000 residents of Eastern Europe have inquired about immigrating to South Africa this year, the Government-run radio said today.
A total of 375 immigrants from Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary and the Soviet Union arrived in the first five months of 1990, the South African Broadcasting Corporation said.

LEAD: ON the gouged, crumbling road from Phnom Penh to the southern Cambodian port of Kampot, a man weaves a bicycle awkwardly among the potholes.
