CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:
NUTMEG STATE GAMES


Colts Sign Morgan
LEAD: HE has caught more passes (534) for more yards (10,352) and more touchdowns (67) than anyone else in the history of the New England Patriots franchise, but the way the Patriots figured it when they released him this year, after 13 arduous seasons and at the age of 35, Stanley Morgan had simply outlived his usefulness as a wide receiver.

LEAD: Janet Linda Guss and Charles Brian LaChaussee were married last evening at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Neil Borovitz.
Mrs.
LaChaussee is a research assistant at the Obesity Research Center at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
Her husband is a legal assistant at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York and a student at New York Law School.

LEAD: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring.
This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter.
I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles.

Returning Workers Trained for Real Jobs
LEAD: A SIMPLE premise lies behind the Re-entry Program of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce: people who have been out of the work force a long time need training that prepares them for available jobs.
Since its inception in 1986, the program has trained 400 people, placed more than 90 percent of them in jobs and earned the trust of employers in Middletown and neighboring communities in Middlesex County.

Poland's Black Madonna

Painted on wood - legend has it by the brush of St.
Luke - the doleful four-foot-high icon is the focus of the nation's spiritual life.

Salads to Take on a Picnic
LEAD: PICNICS are fun for the host because there are no last-minute pressures.
All the food is prepared beforehand.
Ideally, I like to have a simple central dish such as cold roast chicken, ham or pork loin or even a poached salmon - around which various salads can be organized.
These are chosen to provide contrasting textures and flavors.

Stevenson should travel across the United States in a bus and see that gender relations are mired in medieval times, no matter where you are.


BUSINESS DIARY/July 15-20
LEAD:
Home Builders' Lament: Fewer New Houses, Fewer New Buyers
Everyone's favorite leveraged investment is going sour.
Housing starts have fallen five months in a row, the Commerce Department reported last week - down 15.7 percent in a year to an annual rate of 1.18 million in June.
Home builders blame their old friends, the savings institutions, who are now unwilling or unable to back them.

Wall Street;   The Zero-Coupon Twist to the Old Convertible Bond
LEAD: THE market got news last week of two new pending issues of LYONS, one of the trademarked borrowing gimmicks from Merrill Lynch.
A LYON, or Liquid Yield Option Note, is Merrill's zero-coupon twist on the old-fashioned convertible bond.
Issued at a big discount from its value at maturity, a corporation's LYON gives the buyer the right to convert the bond into a fixed number of the company's shares, or an equal sum of cash, at the company's option.

LEAD:
BEHIND THE MASK: My Double Life in Baseball.
By Dave Pallone with Alan Steinberg. (Viking, $18.95.) Every baseball umpire dons a mask to work behind home plate, but the former National League umpire Dave Pallone wore one off the field as well.
The reason, Mr.
Pallone reveals in his emotional memoir, written with the freelance writer Alan Steinberg, is that he is gay.

Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
LEAD: Yes.
Strawberry's performance during the remainder of the season and pennant race should be indicia of what we can expect from him during the course of the long-term contract that he seeks.
And if his performance would be adversely affected by the pressure that is brought about by the uncertainty of his future with the Mets, the organization should give second thought to whether this is the type of player it wants on its team.

Time for Colleges to Take Back the Field
LEAD: THE word is out: big-time college sport, which had been moving rather impressively toward a new rectitude under the whip of a born-again leadership (mostly college presidents fed up with being truant officers), is about to go off the wagon again.
Thanks once more to the willingness of television to sponsor debauchery, and the eagerness of college athletic departments to sucker in, half - or so it seems - of the major college programs in the country are said to be preparing to throw caution - and tradition, and common sense - to the winds in a wholesale realignment of who-plays-whom.


It's Real, All Right, And It's Choice
LEAD: To the Editor:


Brennan's Liberal Legacy to a Divided Supreme Court
LEAD: IN his nearly 34 years as a United States Supreme Court Justice, William J. Brennan Jr. weathered the ideological conflicts that occurred as the Warren Court was transformed into the Burger and Rehnquist Courts.
During eight Presidential Administrations, his role changed from that of a cornerstone of the Court's liberal majority to the author of some of its most stirring dissents.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: The coins of Corsica are few.
The island has never been truly independent.
Since Roman times, it has been possessed by the Byzantine Empire, the kingdom of Lombardy, Charlemagne, Pisa, Genoa, the kingdom of Aragon, two successive Genoese banks and France.

Correction
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about museums in Connecticut misstated the ranking of the Old State House in Hartford, by number of visitors.

Her subject is pain, rage, love, lovelessness, need, fear, dehumanization, oppression, brutality and consolation.
But obscenity is what will be on everyone's mind tonight, at Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival, when she performs her now notorious piece ''We Keep Our Victims Ready.

LEAD: A whole world of modern dance lies beyond this country's borders.
The American Dance Festival is to be congratulated, therefore, for establishing the International Choreographers Workshop, which, with financing from the United States Information Agency and the Rockefeller Foundation, enables choreographers from overseas to gather each summer on the campus of Duke University to take classes, observe festival performances and exchange ideas.

Salads to Take on a Picnic
LEAD: PICNICS are fun for the host because there are no last-minute pressures.
All the food is prepared beforehand.
Ideally, I like to have a simple central dish such as cold roast chicken, ham or pork loin or even a poached salmon - around which various salads can be organized.
These are chosen to provide contrasting textures and flavors.

Borrowing?
To build roads?
Yes.

Public Ownership Is Good for Politicians
LEAD: Richard Kessel's article (''Power Authority Is Necessary to Oversee Lilco,'' June 24) emphasizes the $5.5 billion cost of Shoreham.
Let us examine the facts: Both Federal and State governments actively encouraged the building of a nuclear plant at Shoreham.
After construction was well along, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission began to order hundreds of changes in design, and many completed and started structures had to be destroyed and new ones installed, beginning from scratch.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on June 24 about travelers' safety in Athens referred incorrectly to a Greek restriction on visitors.
Only passengers on charter flights from Europe are required to show proof of prepaid accommodation; the requirement has not been applied to Americans.

Design;   A Soft Touch
LEAD: The sequence of pale rooms is devoid of pattern and color.
The architectural details are subtle and correct.
In each room, antiques are placed sparingly.
The look is slightly unfinished - a brand of romantic modernism that is the unmistakable signature of Boston-based designer William Hodgins.
In many ways, the style recalls the work of two great designers from earlier in this century: Billy Baldwin and Syrie Maugham.

Technology;   Delving Into the Consumer Unconscious
LEAD: BASICALLY it looks like a desk lamp with a chunky smoked-glass body.
In fact, it is Lee Weinblatt's People Reader, a device designed to surreptitiously monitor the way people react to magazine advertising.
Behind the smoked glass are two tiny, remote-controlled video cameras, one that tracks eye movements and another that monitors which page is being perused.

HEALTHY INDULGENCE
LEAD: In ''Healthy Indulgence'' (Food, June 24), Jacques Pepin does an admirable job of delivering savory and attractive low-fat fare.
However, in the future, I hope Pepin's nutritional profiles for servings will be expressed in whole numbers, rather than counts extended to two decimal places. (One recipe, for example, estimated a lime cookie's calories at 59.63.) At best, a recipe analysis is an estimate of nutrient content, with considerable margin for error in either direction.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Keep after insect-disease problems before they overwhelm the plants.
Transplanting and dividing continues.
Finish pruning, especially spring-flowering species.
Last call to apply fertilizer to ornamentals so the new growth has time to develop and harden before cold weather.
Keep up fruit tree spray and rose spray as protective measures against disease problems.

Randall W. Hoffman, College Administrator, 77
LEAD: Randall Walrath Hoffmann, a professor of English who had been an administrator at several colleges, died on Tuesday at St.
Luke's Hospital in Tryon, N.C.
He was 77 years old and had recently moved to Tryon from Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.
He died of heart failure, his wife said.
Mr.
Hoffmann was the dean of students at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., from 1951 to 1966.


The Ant Man
LEAD: E.O.
Wilson doesn't make a lot of headway hiking through the Panamanian rain forest.
Invertebrates distract him.
He stops to poke.
A wasp is acting strangely - he must see why.
A bee clamps its mandibles onto his hand - no problem.
He'll just observe it for a while.
He snaps off epiphytes - plants that grow in the lower forest canopy - looking for nesting ants.

LEAD: Almost everywhere he went in the last decade, Justice William J. Brennan Jr. was importuned by liberals not to retire from the Supreme Court despite his advancing age, lest they lose a champion and conservatives gain a majority.


Taking a Pratfall on the Nastiness Threshold
LEAD: Popular entertainment does, after all, have a revulsion threshold.
Andrew Dice Clay should know.
He stepped over it and is now desperately trying to salvage his career as a stand-up comic.
At the beginning of this year, Mr.
Clay was playing to standing-room-only at Madison Square Garden.
A week and a half ago, he was restraining sobs on ''The Arsenio Hall Show,'' after whining that ''whenever somebody is on top, they try to bring him down - that's the way it is.


Streetscapes: The 1914 Stewart Building;   A Delicate Work of Ceramic in the Path of a Tower
LEAD: ''I call it the Wedgwood Building,'' said Susan Tunick, president of the Friends of Terra Cotta, a preservation organization. ''There's nothing like it in New York.'' Indeed, the blue-and-white, terra-cotta building at the southwest corner of 37th Street and Fifth Avenue, built in 1914, is a striking example of the ceramic arts.


Q and A
LEAD:
The Red House
Question: I have always been curious about the building known as Red House on the south side of West 85th Street just off off Riverside Drive.
What can you tell me about it? . . .
S.
L., Manhattan
Answer: The six-story, 50-unit apartment building at 350 West 85th Street was completed in 1904.


In Eastern Europe's Churches, Triumph Leads to Uncertainty
LEAD: FOR four decades, religious believers in Eastern Europe lived under seige.
Their buildings were confiscated, their ceremonies regulated, their publications censored, their youth groups outlawed, their seminaries closed, their professional careers blocked, their leaders spied upon, jailed, harassed, intimidated, bribed or even killed.


Maura Moynihan, a Comic, Is Married To John F. Avedon, a Writer, on L.I.
LEAD: Maura Russell Moynihan, a partner in the comedy team of Moynihan and Green, was married yesterday in Montauk, L.I., to John Franklin Avedon, a writer.
The Rev.
Ernest Campbell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs.


H.U.D. Scandal's Lesson: It's a Long Road From Revelation to Resolution
LEAD: IN the fall of 1989, when the scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development were one of the biggest stories in America, David Burns, a senior staff member in the department's New York office, asked his superiors in Washington for permission to talk with the press about past wrongdoing at the agency.


A Fine Scottish Hand
LEAD: Next to lunching on goat cheese and gelignite, one of the more dangerous things you can do in London is to mess with the National Gallery.
Not only is it, inch for inch, as great a picture gallery as the world can show; it is midmost, inmost England.
Gloriously situated at the north end of Trafalgar Square, it is the sanctuary of a specific sensibility and the stronghold for 150 years of a heroic view of art.


Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Off the Tourist Track, An Area Full of History
LEAD: The one-traffic-light village of Red Hook sits inconspicuously in the northwest corner of Dutchess County, near the Hudson River, off the beaten track of the tourist trail that takes thousands of visitors each year to more popular attractions in Rhinebeck and Hyde Park to the south.


No Auditions, No Charge, Just Happy Music
LEAD: IT was a quintessential Connecticut summer scene: the evening band concert in the gazebo on Fairfield's Sherman Green.
Revelers of all ages listened to the band and watched the antics of the local children.
Mothers chased errant toddlers through the maze of lawn chairs and blankets, and two little boys with their hands over their ears dared each other to ascend the steps of the gazebo, where the band played ''The Georgia Cakewalk.


A Return to Jazz Standards, and a Bit Beyond
LEAD: The neoclassic temper of 1980's jazz, exemplified by Wynton Marsalis's polished playing and his back-to-blues-and-swing philosophy, has lately taken shape as more than a one-man movement.
Tireless proselytizing by the 29-year-old trumpet player against jazz's associating too closely with other types of music has instilled a revivalist spirit in an even younger generation.


THE POPPERS AND THE PLAINS
LEAD: Frank and Deborah Popper's plan for a Buffalo Commons in the Great Plains has great romantic appeal (''The Poppers and the Plains,'' by Anne Matthews, June 24).
As a lawyer and conservationist, I spent considerable time several years ago on a similar proposal for eastern Montana - the Big Open - researching the practicalities of implementing such a scheme.


The People Who Are Putting Taste Back on the Table
LEAD: THE Quaker Oats Company saw boundless potential in the $7 million a year rice-cake business when it bought a small producer in 1985.
Supported by the Quaker name and advertising budget, rice-cake sales took off as health-conscious consumers sampled the filling, 35-calorie, fat-free snacks.
But then consumers discovered another thing about rice cakes: their taste value was about on a par with styrofoam.


I-80's Exits To History In Nebraska
LEAD: A lot of people drive across Nebraska; few linger.
They get a bad case of lead foot as they barrel west on Interstate 80 trying to get the 450 miles of Nebraska behind them as quickly as possible.
This is a shame.
Nebraska is a place of clear light and calming vistas, of architectural landmarks, both majestic and humble, and many quirky little museums.

Measles' Risks Found Reduced by Vitamin A
LEAD: Vitamin A supplements can significantly reduce the risk of death and serious complications in children with severe measles, a new study has found.


Bohemian Dumplings: Plebeian but Tasty
LEAD: Dumpling dough must be beaten until it talks to the bowl, my mother used to advise as the thickening, sticky mass hit the side with a thwop.


Looking Ahead
LEAD: MONDAY: Treasury Department's budget deficit report for June.
Negotiators from 105 countries take part in trade talks in Geneva, through Friday.


Relocation, an Idea As Old as Moses
LEAD: To the Editor:


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring.
This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter.
I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles.
The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly.
Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

LEAD: Justice William J. Brennan Jr.'s departure from the Supreme Court brings to an end not only a remarkable judicial career but also an era in the Court's history.


David's Island Impasse Linked to Public Access
LEAD: THE failure of the developers of David's Island in New Rochelle to grant meaningful public access to the exclusive residential community they planned was a major factor in the decision by state officials last week to reject the project.

The Book That Wouldn't Die: A Writer's Last and Longest Voyage
LEAD: By nature, our friend was a searcher.
He had traveled through Africa and Asia and the Lowlands of Scotland, but his longest, most intricate journey was in the world of publishing.
It was a journey that lasted almost nine years and began with a voyage on the Regina Maris, an early 20th-century sailing vessel on which our friend traveled from Boston Harbor to Newfoundland, then on to Greenland to chart the migratory patterns of whales.

Sink It, and Link It
LEAD: To the Editor:


If We Don't Give Gorbachev Help, Europe Will;   Everyone Gains
LEAD: To the Editor:


Beyond the Loom
LEAD: For more than three decades Lenore Tawney has been a revolutionary figure in fiber art.
In the 1950's she was credited with freeing weaving from the confines of the loom.
She was one of the first to juxtapose areas of plain weave with areas of unwoven warp, to incorporate knots, braids, shells and feathers into her pieces and to create weavings intended to be hung away from a wall, adding a sculptural dimension to what traditionally had been a flat art.


Tech Notes;   Thwarting a Nuclear Tap Root
LEAD: RESEARCHERS at the Batelle Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratory in Richland, Wash., have developed a way to inhibit the growth of plant roots for as long as 100 years.


Steinlen Wins Handicap
LEAD: Steinlen, last year's champion American grass horse, went over the $3 million mark in career earnings yesterday when he led all the way to win the $500,000 Caesars International Handicap at Atlantic City Race Course in New Jersey.


Carmella Welch Weds
LEAD: Carmella Welch, a daughter of Carol Welch of Astoria, Queens, and the late William Welch, was married last evening to Michael Keyles, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Jerry Keyles of Sayreville, N.J.
The Rev.
James Covington and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.


U.S.O.C. Watches Steinbrenner Case
LEAD: Robert Helmick, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, said today that it ''seemed inappropriate'' to discuss any possible change in George Steinbrenner's relationship with the U.S.O.C. until the Yankee owner's problems stemming from a $40,000 payment to Howard Spira, a self-described gambler, had been resolved.


Siegfried Who? The Limits of Fame
LEAD: Siegfried Matthus counts as East Germany's most successful opera composer, with his works performed throughout Eastern Europe and, increasingly, West Germany.
Up to now, however, apart from the ministrations of a few champions of his orchestral music, he has remained largely unknown in the United States.

Fresh Air Fund Youths Get Connecticut Respite
LEAD: There are 7,500 different stories that inner-city children tell of their Fresh Air Fund summers with a host family that takes them in for a two-week repreive from the summer streets.
The stories take place in the woods or in a classroom, at a pool or a beach, during a rainstorm or in sunshine.


Fashion;   Herald of Autumn: Catalogue in Mailbox
LEAD: Free mail-order catalogues for fall are jamming mailboxes.
The fashion stories they tell are midsummer's patio reading, filled with rich colors in fabrics and designs that evoke distant times and latitudes.


Ms. Peterson Wed To Jan K. Elsbach
LEAD: Kimberly Dee Peterson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs.
Finley Marshall of Vermillion, S.D., was married yesterday in Sheffield, Mass., to Dr.
Jan Kees Elsbach, a son of Dr. and Mrs.
Peter Elsbach of New York.
Betsy Holtzinger, the Town Justice of Stockbridge, Mass., performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bridegroom's parents.


Cuba Blocks More Embassies
LEAD: The Cuban police sealed off the Canadian and West German Embassies today and tightened a security cordon around the Spanish Embassy after nine more Cubans slipped through during the night and broke in.
The latest arrivals brought to 18 the number of Cubans staying at the Spanish Embassy, further complicating a diplomatic quarrel that has strained relations between Madrid and Havana.


Telephone Update
LEAD: New York City has 8,100 sidewalk pay phones.
That should be plenty, if they all worked, and if long-winded talkers didn't monopolize the ones that do.


Review/Concert;   Norfolk Festival: The Happy Outcome of a Musical Learning Experience
LEAD: Like the Music Center at Tanglewood some 40 miles to the north, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in northwestern Connecticut is celebrating a half-century of summer schooling for young musicians.

Off Base
LEAD: A Federal judge in Cincinnati said he saw two people in front of him last week: Pete Rose the living legend and Pete Rose the tax cheat.
He sent them both to jail for five months.
Rose, who batted his way on to base more times than anybody else in baseball, pleaded guilty to two felony counts of filing false income tax returns.


'Anarchy' of Cheating Hits Palestinian Schools
LEAD: Palestinian high-school seniors took final exams this week.
But at many schools the examinations turned out to be tests of how blatantly they could cheat.


Investigation of Vote Buying Shakes S. Carolina Capital
LEAD: A Federal grand jury's investigation into the possibility of vast corruption in the South Carolina Legislature appears to be expanding rapidly and has left this capital city shaken.


'86 and '87 Mazdas Recalled
LEAD: The Mazda Motor Corporation on Friday recalled 102,548 of its 1985 and 1986 model 626 cars because of potentially faulty ignition switches.
The company said the switch could wear out after extended use and affect the operation of the windshield wipers and washers, engine cooling fan, heater blower and air-conditioner compressor.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Tennis
Agassi Routs Chang: Top-seeded Andre Agassi overpowered Michael Chang, 6-3, 6-1, last night to join Jim Grabb in the finals of the Sovran Bank Classic tournament in Washington.
Agassi jumped on Chang's serve and used a strong baseline game to beat the him for the fourth time without a defeat in matches between the two young American stars.


Beachgoers Warned of Buried Ammunition
LEAD: VISITORS to Connecticut's largest beach do not have to worry about raw sewage and hypodermic needles littering their beach.
Instead, they are are being warned of live mortar rounds that may be buried deep in the sand.

LEAD: IN Congress, regulators and prosecutors have found a welcome ally in the aftermath of the troubles of the savings and banking industries, getting more than they have sought in resources and legislation.


Universal's Harvey Stake
LEAD: Universal Pictures said last week that it had acquired a minority interest in Harvey Comics Entertainment, a Santa Monica, Calif., publisher of cartoon and comic characters like Casper, the Friendly Ghost; Richie Rich, and Baby Huey.
Terms were not disclosed.
The agreement, announced by Thomas Pollock, the chairman of Universal Pictures, focuses on the use of the Harvey characters in such areas as motion pictures, television, home video and theme parks.

Note to Readers
LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.
If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

PAYOUTS IN BHOPAL ARE GOING SLOWLY
LEAD: More than five years after deadly gas leaked from a pesticide plant here, causing the world's worst industrial disaster, relief payments are reaching many of the surviving victims.
But the distribution of assistance is so uneven that more than 400,000 eligible people have received nothing, and benefits have been small even for the recipients.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article on Thursday about abortion laws in East and West Germany referred incorrectly to the West's law.
If two doctors certify that the pregnancy resulted from rape or causes great physical or emotional distress to the mother, abortion is permitted through the 12th week of pregnancy, not the 22d.

Question Box
LEAD:
Rose the All-Star
Q.
How successful was the National League team in All-Star Games in which Pete Rose played for it and how successful was Rose as an all-star?
A.
The team was wildly successful, but the player was mildly so.
During the 16 All-Star Games Rose appeared in between 1965 and 1985 as a member of the Cincinnati Reds or the Philadelphia Phillies, his side came away with the victory 15 times.

LEAD: R. H. Macy &amp; Company has asked at least three investment banks to suggest ways for the department store chain to reduce its debt and raise money, Crain's New York Business reports in this week's issue.

Topics of The Times;   Dial F for Friend
LEAD: A colleague who knows about computers has a hard time getting off the phone.
Now that one friend after another has bought a home computer, they call her.
Urgently.
They may be accomplished professionals but when confronted by their first DOS (disk operating system) prompt and a 10-pound instruction book in techno-jargon, they panic.

Women Are Giving Triathlons a Run
LEAD: THOSE athletes competing in the Danskin sprint-distance triathlon in White Plains on Sunday are testimony to the growing popularity of the sport among women.
The second (and only East Coast) race of the Danskin Women's Triathlon Series is an 800-meter swim across Lake Isle, followed by a 20-kilometer bike race down the Bronx River Parkway, followed by a 5-kilometer run on the parkway to the Kensico Dam.

Benefit Plan for N.B.A.
LEAD: An agreement on a benefit plan that would provide retired National Basketball Association players with pre-pension financial and medical security was announced yesterday by the league and the National Basketball Players Association.
David Stern, the league's commissioner, said the program would be submitted for approval to the Federal District Court in New Jersey that oversees an antitrust agreement between the players and the league.


Campeau Granted Assets Extension
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation said in Toronto that the Edward J. DeBartolo Company, a major American shopping-mall developer, has extended until Aug. 6 a stand-still agreement under which DeBartolo will not seize any Campeau assets without first providing nine days' notice.
Campeau, a Canadian developer, owns the Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corporation, two American retail chains.

LEAD: Tournament competitors may be divided into two types: the front runners, who must have everything go right from the beginning if they are to triumph, and the resilient ones, who win despite an early setback.
The 21-year-old Soviet grandmaster Vassily Ivanchuk belongs to the second group.

Undersea Uranium
LEAD: Uranium buried in ocean sediments through natural processes moves downward through the sediments rather than upward toward the water, and then is immobilized when a new layer of sediments is deposited, scientists have found.

John R. Bond; Magazine Publisher, 77
LEAD: John R. Bond, publisher of Road &amp; Track magazine from 1949 to 1972, died Friday at his home here.
He was 77 years old.
He died of emphysema, family members said.
Mr.
Bond bought Road &amp; Track, an automobile magazine, with his second wife, Elaine, said his son, John Jr.
As publisher, Mr.
Bond instituted staples of automotive journalism like the technical road test.

Judean Cave City Yields Trove of Ancient Secrets
LEAD: THOUSANDS of people moved to this boulder-strewn meadow between the eighth and first centuries B.C. partly because of its proximity to trade routes.
But the Biblical town of Maresha had another attraction, too: as much as anything else, it flourished because of its caves, hundreds of elaborate caverns forming an underground city that generations of dwellers carved out of the soft limestone just a foot or two beneath the surface.

Time Warner Reports A Loss of $189 Million
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $189 million for the second quarter.
If Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. had been merged at this time last year, the company would have reported a comparable loss.
The company's revenues for the quarter rose by 4.4 percent, to $2.58 billion, from $2.47 billion in the previous quarter.

LEAD:
GOLF
Daniel Wins in Sudden Death
Beth Daniel overcame a two-stroke deficit on the final three holes, then rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff yesterday to beat Patty Sheehan in the rain-delayed Phar-Mor Youngstown Classic in Vienna, Ohio.
Daniel earned a $60,000 first prize in the Ladies Professional Golf Assocation event plus a $50,000 bonus for being the leading money-winner in the two events sponsored by Phar-Mor drugstores.

LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation and Wendy's International Inc. said yesterday that they would start cooking their french fries and hash brown potatoes in 100 percent vegetable oil, abandoning a blend of vegetable oil and beef tallow that had made them targets of anti-cholesterol campaigners.

Reviews/Ballet;   Departures Of Style In Bolshoi 'Highlights'
LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet presented a disappointing afternoon of dance in its ''Highlights'' program on Saturday at the New York State Theater.

But in general the dancers looked unduly second-rate.

Paris Heat: Versace and Lacroix Open the Fall Shows
LEAD: The haute couture shows opened with a blast of prints and color over the weekend.
Gianni Versace set the stage for a sizzling display of fall fashions with minuscule outfits in fiery prints that barely covered the torso.
Skirts that reached finger-tip level were on the long side.
Except for the fairly elaborate swags and jewels, the ball gowns could have passed as swimsuits.

LEAD: In a move that is rare among utilities, the Kansas City Power and Light Company made a hostile tender offer yesterday for the shares of a neighboring utility, the Kansas Gas and Electric Company.
Kansas City Power said the bid was worth $857 million.

Compaq Offering 2 New Computers
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced two high-end personal computers, the Compaq Deskpro 486/ 33L and Compaq Deskpro 386/33L, priced between $9,999 and $19,499 depending on configuration.
It also announced a 486-based version of its Systempro line priced between $20,999 and $29,999.
The computers, which approach the performance levels of engineering work stations and minicomputers, may be difficult for personal computer retailers to sell effectively, analysts said.

BRIEFS
LEAD:
Debt


Los Angeles Trolley Derails
LEAD: A train on the new Southern California trolley line derailed Sunday when a four-inch-long metal wire became wedged between tracks, preventing the train from switching smoothly.
There were no injuries.
The Pico Station, at the downtown end of the 22-mile Long Beach-to-Los Angeles line, was closed for three hours.


Gasoline Prices Steady
LEAD: Gasoline prices, which normally go up this time of the year as more people take to the road on vacations, remained unusually steady during the last two weeks, an industry analyst said Sunday.
The average national price for a gallon of gas, including all taxes, was 117.72 cents, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of nearly 13,000 service stations, completed Friday.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Health Policy Is Outlined
The Health Secretary denounced calls for a radical revamping of the health-care system, but said ways were being sought to protect those lacking insurance.
Page A10.
Forging a New Poland
Poland's chances for prosperity rest with people like Zygmunt Borek, a private manager hired to transform a huge state-run steel mill.


Mr. Justice Brennan
LEAD: It was only gradually, in the 1960's, that observers of the Supreme Court came to understand the influence of William J. Brennan Jr.
When he retired last week, everyone knew.
One student of the Court put it: ''He is the great expositor of modern constitutional law.''


Review/Theater;   Finley Mocks Her Critics In Her Art
LEAD: Early in her powerful one-woman show, ''We Keep Our Victims Ready,'' Karen Finley mocks conservative critics who have denounced her work as obscene by offering her own satirical portrait of an American cultural landscape stripped bare by arts censorship.


Nature Switches Roles For the Mating Game
LEAD: STEREOTYPED though the behavior may seem, in most species it is the female animal who is the finicky one, and the males who vie with each other to attract her favors.
Now researchers have found that, among katydids and crickets, nature's normal gender roles are sometimes reversed, with the male standing by as two or more female suitors rear up in a pitched battle for his affection.

Scientists and Planners Consider New Limits To Coastal Development
LEAD: GROWING evidence that coastal erosion occurs continuously, not just in calamitous bursts like Hurricane Hugo, has led scientists, planners and some Federal disaster officials to urge a stringent new approach to limiting development along the nation's shoreline.
Their campaign is opposed by many builders, property owners and others with a financial or political stake on the coast.

Brooklyn Landlord, To Keep Racial Mix, Looks to Soviet Jews
LEAD: As part of a plan to maintain racial and ethnic balance at the Starrett City housing complex in southeast Brooklyn, the owners are considering making apartments available to Soviet Jews who come to the United States.

The Mount Vernon neighborhood is a working-class-to-poor area, mainly black.
There are vacant lots, boarded-up houses, drug dealers nearby.

LEAD: Nominations to the Supreme Court are different.

He believes that the public and the Senate will be impressed by the intellect, credentials and judicious fairness of David Souter.

Man Charged in Shooting Hoped to Join Police Force
LEAD: The 22-year-old man charged in the shooting of a 9-year-old Brooklyn girl on Sunday is a former professional baseball player who had returned to his Brooklyn home hoping to become a police officer like his older sister, friends of the man said yesterday.


House Votes to Bolster Enforcement by S.E.C.
LEAD: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a measure today to broaden and strengthen the enforcement powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.


Bankers Trust Profit Is Flat
LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were flat compared with the comparable period of 1989, reflecting continued write-offs of loans to third-world nations.


Now for the Deeds
LEAD: Everybody is complaining about leadership these days.
Anyone who seems to be standing tall is across the border.


Count of Oil Rigs Rises
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States increased by 21 this week to 1,022, according to Baker Hughes Inc., a maker of oil drilling equipment.
This week's increase reversed a series of declines, including a drop of 10 rigs last week.
A year ago, the count was 830.
New Mexico's rig count was down by six, Louisiana lost four rigs and North Dakota dropped one rig.


Detective Says He Tricked Jogger Suspect
LEAD: A New York City police detective testified yesterday that he tricked one of the defendants in the Central Park jogger trial into confessing.

3 Going to Trial Accused of Flying Jetliner Under Alcohol's Influence
LEAD: In a case that is being watched closely by aviation experts and safety groups, three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying a commercial jet while under the influence of alcohol go on trial in Federal District Court in Minneapolis today.
It is the first time that criminal charges have been brought against airline pilots for drunken flying, and the aviation industry is eager to see what precedent the court sets.

Sewage Plant Pump Repaired
LEAD: Engineers restored a damaged pump at the city's second-largest sewage-treatment plant yesterday afternoon, two days after an electrical fire shut down the plant and caused a major sewage spill into the East and Harlem Rivers.
Four of five pumps are now available for use at the plant on Wards Island, said Tina Casey, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: CHICKEN livers are not only among the most inexpensive meats, but they also are one of the most versatile.
They can be used in stuffings, sauces, pates, terrines, in rice dishes and in scores of main courses.
One of my favorite preparations calls for simply dipping the livers in seasoned flour and then cooking them in oil until crisp and browned.

Bell South to Test Wireless Phones
LEAD: The Bell South Corporation applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to test tiny wireless telephones in Atlanta over the next two years.
Bell South said the test, which would involve up to 300 handsets, would use as much existing cellular telephone technology as possible.
Some experts say that such a system, known as a personal communications network, could prove cheaper than current cellular telephone service.

LEAD: FRESH from their triumphs in Eastern Europe, free-market economists are pushing market solutions for problems closer to home.
Markets are being touted as the most efficient way to save wildlife, improve public education and reduce acid rain.
Could they also be used to tame the scourge of America's city-sprawls: the rush-hour traffic jam?

The Slimming Of Fat Fast Food
LEAD: WHEN McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's announced in recent days that they would fry their potatoes in all vegetable oil instead of a mixture of beef tallow and vegetable oil, it was just one more sign that fast-food chains have learned a lesson: to survive in today's health-conscious society, they must provide more nutritious alternatives to double cheeseburgers and fried chicken.

LEAD: Denying charges by New York Attorney General Robert Abrams and others, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday that its review of purchasing practices from 1984 to 1988 had found no evidence of financial improprieties.

LEAD: Harry Spilman was agitated, and got Nolan Ryan on the phone. ''Nolan, how come I'm not on the list?'' he asked one day last summer to his neighbor in Alvin, Tex., and former opponent and teammate, Nolan Ryan. ''What list?'' asked Ryan. ''The list of every guy you ever struck out in the major leagues,'' said Spilman.

LEAD: A day after President Bush announced his choice of David H. Souter for the Supreme Court, a sharp dispute broke out today in Congress and among interest groups over how far the Senate should go in eliciting his position on abortion.


Bid to Curb Aid On Sugar Fails
LEAD: The House and Senate easily defeated a proposal today to trim the United States sugar program, sidestepping charges that the subsidies hurt sugar-exporting nations and inflated domestic food prices.


Food Notes
LEAD:
A Bit of Texas Downtown Looking more like a truck stop than a cafe, the new Texas Tortilla Bakery, 36 Water Street (near Coenties Slip) in Manhattan easily satisfies a hunger for warm, fresh tortillas, mellow beans, lightly charred chicken or beef fajitas and salsa with a gentle kick.
The bakery and cafe is open for dining in or taking out.

LEAD: Shares of the Woolworth Corporation fell $1.125, to $32.625, yesterday in New York Stock Exchange trading after Harold Sells, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that he expected record sales in 1990, but that it was too soon to tell whether second-quarter 1990 profits would top the record set in the comparable period last year.

Judging Barney Frank
LEAD: Barney Frank, a bright, articulate and productive Congressman, has committed serious indiscretions in his personal dealings with a male prostitute.

Chrysler Offering
LEAD: The Chrysler Auto Receivables Company offered $1 billion worth of securities backed by retail installment contracts on new or used autos and light trucks through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 8 3/4 percent securities, which have a final maturity of Aug. 15, 1995, were priced at $99.718, to yield 8.856 percent, which is 77 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the when-issued two-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of the Ford Motor Company's aerospace unit referred incorrectly to the involvement of Shearson Lehman Hutton.
Merchant banking partnerships managed by Shearson (but not Shearson itself) will contribute $150 million of equity in a joint venture with the Loral Corporation to purchase the unit.

LEAD: Facing mounting pressure to conclude a budget deal before Congress adjourns for its August recess, President Bush and top Congressional leaders agreed today to cool their political oratory in hopes of spurring stalled negotiations on a $50 billion deficit-cutting package.

LEAD: Dr.
Louis M. Hellman, a physician who as a Federal health official advocated public financing of birth control, abortion and voluntary sterilization for the poor, died Sunday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington.
He was 82 years old and lived in Hydes, Md.

Tandy Introducing Home Computer
LEAD: The Tandy Corporation will introduce a home computer today that the company said would be less expensive than the model introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation last month.
I.B.M. introduced the PCjr in late 1983, but withdrew the product in 1985 after disappointing sales.
Tandy, which was one of the first personal computer makers, has continued to sell to the home market and is now considered the leading maker of home computers by market researchers.


Group Urges Limits On Outside Earnings Of Council Members
LEAD: To eliminate potential conflicts of interest, sharp restrictions should be placed on the outside income members of the newly empowered New York City Council can earn in addition to their official salaries, a civic group said yesterday.


Thruway Agency to Examine All of Its Bridges for Erosion
LEAD: The Thruway Authority announced today that it had begun a $4.6 million two-year study of erosion under its bridges.


Uncovered Short Sales of Active Nasdaq Issues Up 1%
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported an increase of slightly more than 1 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-July.

LEAD: Fans in the New York area who want to watch Nolan Ryan go for his 300th victory when his Texas Rangers take on the Yankees in Texas at 8:30 tonight are out of luck if they don't have cable or an accommodating friend or a handy bar that does.


4 Traders Are Charged
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission charged today that four traders on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange engaged in a conspiracy to use their advance knowledge of customer orders to make illegal profits.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines has failed to reach a plea-bargaining agreement in a Federal investigation of past maintenance practices, and a grand jury is expected to indict the carrier this week on criminal charges, Eastern's court-appointed trustee and Federal officials said yesterday.

Sold! For $2.9 Million
LEAD: A half-brother to Summer Squall, the 1990 Preakness Stakes winner, brought a top price of $2.9 million yesterday at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale at Lexington, Ky.
The bay colt by Seattle Slew out of Weekend Surprise was purchased by BBA (Ireland) for Tomonori Tsurumaki of Japan.
The colt, consigned by Lane's End Farm near Versailles, will stay in America to race, said Noel O'Callaghan, a BBA director who signed for the colt.

3 Studios Pursue One Tale: Robin Hood's
LEAD: Hungry for material for its stars, Hollywood has decided to revive the legend of Robin Hood.
No fewer than three different companies have been jockeying for months to bring the hero of Sherwood Forest back to the screen in separate productions next year, well aware that at least one of those projects is bound to fall by the wayside.


Curb on Some Program Trades to Be Tried
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved a one-year trial of a New York Stock Exchange rule that would curtail a type of computerized trading on days when the stock market swings widely up or down.

LEAD: The nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court has reopened with particular ferocity a debate that has been going on for nearly two centuries over how far the Senate may go in exploring a nominee's views on the most profound public questions of the day.

LEAD: Researchers have discovered a number of new clues to the cause of a baffling hereditary disease, Marfan syndrome, best known for its role in the deaths of the Olympic volleyball player Flo Hyman and the University of Maryland basketball star Chris Patten.

LEAD: Children are not the only ones who go on holiday when the school year ends.

Review/Dance;   Cast Changes in Australian 'Giselle'
LEAD: In Maina Gielgud's production of ''Giselle'' for the Australian Ballet, the wilis (ghosts of jilted maidens) are seen for the first time as shrouded white figures, faces covered by huge bridal veils.
They rise up from a horizon of mist, not from the usual stage wings, and surge toward the audience.

Twenty years ago Stewart Ross started collecting these evocative American paintings, which date from the 20's to the 50's.


Making Glassware Whole Again
LEAD: A SCRATCHED Art Nouveau Lalique plaque with a nymph face is in need of repair and a chipped chandelier prism needs grinding.
Then there is the Baccarat lion with a severed tail, the cordial glass with a broken stem and the Steuben eagle with a broken wing. ''After it is polished, it will look like it was never damaged,'' said Augustine Jochec (pronounced JOE-check).

LEAD: Scientists have devised an experimental treatment that dramatically stops scarring from a kidney disease in animals and holds promise for preventing the same problem in humans.

LEAD: Marilyn Quayle was released from Bethesda Naval Hospital today, four days after undergoing a hysterectomy, the Vice President's press office said.

LEAD: Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it was joining Eric Gleacher, former head of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, to form a firm to be called Gleacher Morgan Grenfell Inc. that will do merger and acquisition work in the United States and abroad.


Colts Sign Zendejas
LEAD: Max Zendejas, a place-kicker who has played for the Washington Redskins and the Green Bay Packers, signed a two-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts on Tuesday.


Britain to Cut Force in Germany by a Half
LEAD: Britain said today that it planned by the mid-1990's to withdraw half of the more than 66,000 troops it has stationed in West Germany and to cut the nation's overall regular forces by 18 percent.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker's statement on Cambodia, while constructive, has produced more confusion than clarity on U.S. policy toward Southeast Asia.


Shuttle to Be Taken Off Pad After Work on Leak Fails
LEAD: In spite of attempts to seal off leaks, hydrogen fuel seeped from the space shuttle Atlantis in tests today, and the craft will be removed from its Florida launching pad for more extensive repairs, space agency officials said.


2 Steelmakers' Profits Decline
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a 74 percent drop in second-quarter earnings while the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation posted a 38 percent plunge.
Both steelmakers blamed lower steel prices for part of the deterioration.


GE Aircraft
LEAD: GE Aircraft Engines, a unit of the General Electric Company, said Air Afrique had placed a $150 million order for its CF6-80C2 high-bypass turbofan engine for eight Airbus Industrie aircraft.
GE Aircraft said Air Afrique, an African consortium, is the largest operator of GE CF6 engines in Africa.
With this order, Air Afrique will introduce the first A310-300 aircraft into the regional market in 1991.

Frisson My Timbers
LEAD: What is it that runs down your spine when you see movie scenes like the unforgettable moment in ''Wait Until Dark'' when Alan Arkin, seemingly dead, suddenly leaps across the room at the blind Audrey Hepburn?
A shiver of fear?
No, not if you mean to be, well, au courant.
To judge by current journalistic fashion, you should be experiencing a frisson, a French term for shiver or shudder.

Blind Man Hikes 1,200 Miles
LEAD: A North Carolinian has passed the halfway mark in an attempt to become the first blind man to walk the 2,143-mile Appalachian Trail.
Since he left Georgia on March 9, Bill Irwin has hiked more than 1,200 miles over some of the roughest terrain in the East.
The 49-year-old hiker, who is accompanated by his guide dog Orient, hopes to reach Mount Katahdin in Maine, the northern end of the trail, by October.

LEAD: In an effort to raise badly needly foreign currency for its beleaguered economy, the Soviet Union has agreed to sell its uncut diamonds through the international diamond cartel controlled by De Beers of South Africa.

Bronx Livery Driver Is Slain
LEAD: A 61-year-old livery-cab driver was shot in the head and killed in a robbery in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said.
He was the 19th livery-cab driver and 20th cabdriver of any kind killed in New York City so far this year.
The driver, George Fitzgerald, who worked for the Bessie Cab Company, was shot once in the head in front of 1155 Cromwell Avenue in the Highbridge section at 1:45 A.M.

Textile Bill Advances
LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a textile import quota bill today and sent it to the full House.
The bill would establish United States import quotas for each category of textiles, textile products and nonrubber footwear beginning this year.
Imports from Canada and Israel would be exempt because those countries have free-trade agreements with the United States.

LEAD: As many as 14,000 Liberian visitors find themselves stuck in the United States while a bloody civil war rages in their homeland.
They need a safe haven until things stabilize.

LEAD: Yesterday was a cheerless day for the women's magazine field as Woman magazine announced that it would cease publication and Woman's Day was taken off the auction block because no one would meet its owner's asking price.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: A 45-YEAR-OLD woman, noticing that her mother seemed depressed, asked her if the trouble was sexual problems.
When her mother admitted to the daughter that that was the case, the daughter referred her to places where her parents might get help.
And she gave her mother specific suggestions on how to make herself more sexually attractive.


Label Bill For Albums Is Vetoed In Louisiana
LEAD: Gov.
Buddy Roemer vetoed a bill today that would have required warning stickers on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics.
The bill was the first in the United States ordering the use of warning labels on albums.

LEAD: A commodities brokerage firm headed by the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade is going out of business because the company is unable to pay its debts.

LEAD: The Clorox Company said it would reassign the advertising accounts for Pine-Sol cleaner and Combat insecticide, which it is acquiring from the American Cyanamid Company.

The incumbent agency is Carrafiello Diehl &amp; Associates, Irvington, N.Y.

Turkoman Rugs Tell A Tale Of War
LEAD: JOYCE LOWE, a rug buyer for the carpet-store chain Sandler &amp; Worth, traveled to Pakistan in May and returned with a cache of colorful flat-weave rugs made by Turkoman nomads, refugees from Afghanistan.
But while the techniques and colors are traditional, the designs reflect the experience of a country at war.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: WE did everything right.
When we got there, on Friday night, we took deep breaths of the stock-scented air and said wasn't it wonderful to be out of that hot, sticky city.
Then we strolled the grounds (six-tenths of an acre), disturbing a pair of dandelion-eating rabbits, and marveled at the sky.
Only one or two stars are ever visible in the sky over New York, so we get pretty excited when we see constellations.

Critic's Notebook;   Television Brings Out A Melodramatic Side Of the Legal Process
LEAD: As the first trial in the case of the Central Park jogger comes to a close, the loyal television viewer is again learning that the legal process is a category of melodrama.
Trials that earn the most attention from local news and magazine shows, not to speak of docudramas, have all the elements of the nation's prime-time favorites: sex and violence, conflict and commotion.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: LAYING bricks with plain sand instead of mortar is an easy way to pave areas like patios, walks and driveways.
Bricks are arranged close together on a bed of packed sand surrounded by a border.
After they are in place, more sand is swept into the crevices between them to prevent shifting.

A Big Round Table With a Story to Tell
LEAD: EVEN at first sight, it seemed clear that there must be a story behind the huge, handsome, round table and the graceful mismatched chairs that surround it. Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Dull Counter Top
Q.The finish on the plastic counter top in my kitchen is practically gone.
Is it possible to paint this plastic, and if so, what preparation is needed and what kind of paint should I use?
A.You can paint the counter top, but I'm not sure it would be a good idea.
You risk scratching the paint when you cut or prepare food, and that could mean toxic particles mixed in with the food.

LEAD: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 10.2 percent from a year earlier, when the company had a one-time $13.6 million gain.

LEAD: Bankers are preparing to extend the deadline on the bridge loan that saved Donald J. Trump from bankruptcy as they continue to prepare the documentation for a permanent loan package, bankers involved in the deal said yesterday.

Tenneco Net Rises 14%
LEAD: Tenneco Inc. announced today that its second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent from a year earlier.
Net income totaled $206 million, or $1.61 a share, compared with $180 million, or $1.38 a share, in the 1989 second quarter.
Revenue of $3.64 billion in the latest quarter was down slightly from $3.66 billion in last year's quarter.

CSX Offers Notes
LEAD: The CSX Corporation, a Richmond transportation holding company, offered $250 million worth of 10-year notes yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 9 1/2 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature on Aug. 1, 2000.
They were priced at 99.62 to yield 9.56 percent, 1.08 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes.

Note to Readers
LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.
If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

In the period a year earlier, Coast earned $5.8 million, or 41 cents a share.

Gabbard, 50 years old, has led Telecom USA, based in Atlanta, since its formation in 1988 through the merger of his former company, SouthernNet, and the Teleconnect Company.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $1.93 billion, to $391.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 160 institutional funds rose $366 million, to $95.18 billion.
Those of the 251 general-purpose funds rose $1.21 billion, to $135.91 billion.

LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that warning labels on cigarette packs and advertisements do not protect manufacturers against damage claims filed by smokers or their relatives.


Review/Art;   The State of the City as Sculptors See It
LEAD: EACH year the outdoor sculpture season seems to have more to say about the art and life of New York City.
With some artists seeking exposure, others trying to define for themselves the meanings of public art, still others trying to leave their stamp on a street or square, and with all the artists now trying to wrestle with urban dramas for which it seems no author or director exists, the outdoor sculpture season has become a way of gauging not only the state of the art world but also the state of the city.

Six New Or Recent Orchestral Works
LEAD: Rehearsals are the private struggles by which public performance is made to seem effortless and trouble-free.
There are those who would keep it that way.
Symphonic music is theater too, they say.
It employs its own artifices to bind listeners and music together; one is by hiding from the observer the intervening problems of learning and technique.

LEAD: Since irony seems to be art's most important product lately, appreciating the hyper-romantic sensibility of Victorian-era British photography requires a suspension of disbelief.
True, the sugary tableaux of Henry Peach Robinson and the allegorical portraits by Julia Margaret Cameron may be viewed as precursors of the overtly fabricated art photography of the 1980's.


A Cyprus Solution - Long Overdue
LEAD: A ranking United Nations official familiar with the U.N.-sponsored negotiations on Cyprus's future recently told me that, in his view, of all the world's intractable problems the Cyprus situation is one that is clearly solvable.
He said that progress depended on outside pressure on Turkey, especially by the U.S., to remove its troops from the island nation, and on insuring that the Greek and Turkish Governments fully participate in any agreement on Cyprus's future political structure.

LEAD: David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, failed a medical examination by his draft board while a student at Harvard Law School in 1966 because one leg was found to be an inch shorter than the other, a White House spokeswoman said today.

About New York;   A 'Bum' Gleans The Discarded To Find History
LEAD: Leo Hershkowitz grew up on the streets of the East Bronx, playing stickball, scurrying from the constabulary and thumbing his nose at authority.
By the time he began school, his contrary course was set.
When a teacher assigned a book, he'd read another.
When given an essay topic, he'd write about something else.

CONSUMER'S WORLD:: Guidepost;   Refrigerating Food
LEAD: If food that should be refrigerated is left at room temperature during the summer, it is likely to spoil in about an hour.
And expiration dates on dairy products are less reliable in hot weather.
Spoilage cannot always be detected, because sometimes the problem is in the toxins the food is giving off.

LEAD: Bertram Thorp Blake Jr., a retired paper company executive, died yesterday at his home in Darien, Conn.
He was 71 years old.
Mr.
Blake died of lung cancer, his wife, Margaret, said.
Mr.
Blake was executive vice president of the Paper Corporation of the United States, based in Manhattan, from 1966 to 1981, when he retired.

LEAD: Canada announced today that it had bought a piece of land in an effort to help end a two-week armed standoff between the police and Mohawk Indians.

LEAD: Israel and the Soviet Union agreed today to establish trade ties, Israeli officials said.
The president of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Vladislav Malkevitch, said trade between the countries, which do not have diplomatic relations, could top $1 billion in four years.
Direct trade stands at less than $10 million a year.

Brooklyn Mourns One of 3 Children Lost to Gunfire


Junior Is Frightful, Freckled And the Bane of His Seniors
We aren't all blessed with Wordsworth's sense of childhood as a romantic idyll, but even hack film makers who think a malevolent orphan is raw comic material might show more imagination than they do in ''Problem Child.'' Junior is a red-haired, freckle-faced 7-year-old, a ringer for Opie on television's ''Andy Griffith Show.'' Imagine what would have happened if Andy and Aunt Bea had abandoned Opie at birth, and the unloved boy had turned into a child who writes fan letters to a famous murderer.
That is the totally unfulfilled concept behind the movie.
Despite his strange attachment to a killer, Junior is mischievous in the way only derivative screenwriters and directors conditioned by sit-coms could possibly find amusing.
So Junior is enough to try the patience of a nun? ''Problem Child'' shows him infuriating nuns at an orphanage, sometimes by calling them penguins.
No one ever said he was original.
When he is adopted by a middle-class family, he sets fire to his room and tosses the cat around.
This behavior never seems dangerous, and it never seems funny.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Digital Audio Tape
LEAD: I marvel at the digital audio tape recorder I brought back from Tokyo last year, and at the portable DAT recorder I got there this year.

Religion Notes
LEAD: On Praying for a Son There are few things that connoisseurs of antiquity enjoy more than a modern discovery that confirms the wisdom of the past.
So, in recent weeks several students of the Talmud, the authoritative body of Jewish law completed in the sixth century, took pleasure in a report in the journal Nature about the discovery of a gene that determines maleness.


Senate Votes Farm Supports For $54 Billion Over 5 Years
LEAD: After more than a week of debate, the Senate approved legislation today to set the country's farm policy over the next five years.
The program, which is expected to cost $54 billion, was approved 70 to 21.


Evolution in Europe;   Top West German Anti-Terrorist Is Slightly Wounded in a Bombing
LEAD: West German terrorists set off a bomb by remote control next to a busy highway today just as Bonn's top anti-terrorist official was driving by.
The official was slightly wounded in the neck and arm.


New York City Schools Face $62.3 Million Budget Cut
LEAD: New York City school officials announced plans yesterday to cut $62.3 million in planned spending for the coming school year, a figure that they said is likely to reduce the teaching force in some places and further tighten the central bureaucracy by as many as 350 positions.

LEAD: Every one of those $26 million that Ted Turner is losing on the Goodwill Games was worth it Thursday night at a ball park here.

Fashion;   Children's Wear That Bridges Seasons
LEAD: The children are back from camp or soon will be, trailing worn or outgrown play wear behind them.
Parents are not likely to invest in summer replacements, even if they could find them at this late date.
But among the back-to-school inventory are a lot of bright, lightweight transitional clothes suitable for the hot days and increasingly cooler nights of August and


Surgery for Gubicza
LEAD: If the Kansas City batters and baserunners had been as busy this year as the team physician, Steve Joyce, perhaps the Royals would not be at the bottom of the American League West.


Postings: Boerum Hill Houses;   Dream Made Real
LEAD: Since emigrating from his native Guyana 21 years ago, John Grant has built a thriving residential renovation business in Brooklyn while buying up empty lots in his Boerum Hill neighborhood and dreaming of the day when he could build homes from scratch.


Camp Honors Director's 20 Years of Sharing
LEAD: In her 20 years in Fresh Air Fund camps, Beverly McEntarfer has lived through a hurricane, a multitude of violent storms and a cabin fire.
She has had to retrieve hundreds of lost children, not to mention a few runaways.
And she has endured several broken bones, a nasty bout with a campwide epidemic of food poisoning and, she estimates, no less than 10,000 mosquito bites.


Upscale Ideas for the Summer Picnic Basket
LEAD: AS convenient as sandwiches may be to eat on a picnic, they are better at the beach or for lunch in the park than more refined picnic occasions, like an outdoor supper before a summer concert.
When wine and bottled water are served instead of beer and soft drinks and when linen napkins replace paper, the menu calls for something more stylish than the typical sandwich and potato salad.


'Night, La Guardia
LEAD: All the world loves the tale of a marooned traveler, but alas, those adventures aren't as picturesque as they used to be.
Today, any ordinary vacationer may become stranded in a place like Palau or a Portuguese coastal village, with little money, knowing no one, forced to pass the night in a rental car.


HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.


In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester Developer Fees in Lieu of Open Space
LEAD: A new state law that takes effect on Oct. 1 has broad implications for the acquisition of open space in Connecticut.
It enables communities to charge developers a fee instead of requiring them to donate parcels of land for preservation.


Review of Family Life Education Urged
LEAD: THE 10th anniversary of family life education in New Jersey schools has proved to be a quiet celebration, in stark contrast to the furor with which the program was introduced.
Too quiet, say its advocates, who are urging education policy makers, teachers and parents to take another look at family life programs in the state to see if they can be improved.


Trinidad and Tobago At A Glance
LEAD:
People
The nation has a population of about 1.3 million, all but 45,000 on Trinidad.
Most of the people are of African or East Indian origin.
Trinidadians of mixed race make up slightly more than 16 percent.
Whites make up 1.7 percent.
The two major folk traditions are Creole, a mixture of African elements influenced by Spanish, French and English culture, and East Indian.


Review/Pop;   Byrd and J.B. All-Stars: Funky Rhythm and Blues
LEAD: They go by various aliases: the Pee Wee Ellis Assembly, Maceo Parker and Roots Revisited, the J. B. Horns and, on Wednesday night at S.O.B.'s, Bobby Byrd and the J. B. All-Stars.
While the name and the lead singers change, the band has funk's Holy Grail at its fingertips when it knocks out the lean, punchy syncopations its leaders learned through years as James Brown's backing band.


Jeanette E. Heinz Weds Thomas King
LEAD: Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jeanette Elisabet Heinz and Thomas Mackenzie King, both 1986 graduates of Stanford University.
The Rev.
John Bishop performed the ceremony.
Mrs.
King, 25 years old, is a daughter of Clifford Stanton Heinz of Newport Beach, Calif., and Barbro Engstrom Heinz Rudel of Stockholm and New York.


Lifestyle;   Modern Rapunzels Put Up Their Hair
LEAD: Snake through the crowds on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn on any Saturday, past the Sno-Kone vendors selling winter's taste in summer flavors, past the stores that sell shorts and dresses and blouses at two for $5.
Pass under a hand-painted sign and into a narrow three-story building so unprepossessing it gives no hint that you've arrived at the mecca of hair.


Property Tax
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Man Called Into Action When Election Losers Demand Recounts
LEAD: JOHN L. CARBONE is a practical man; he does not take sides in an election until after it is over.
But, oddly enough, he often sides with the loser.


Review/Cabaret Julius LaRosa Pays Homage To Golden-Age Lyricists
LEAD: ''Words are the most important thing to me in a song,'' declared Julius LaRosa early in the opening-night show on Tuesday of his three-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza).
The singer, who was accompanied by Don Rebic (pianist), Art Koenig (bassist) and Don DiMarco (guitarist), went on to sing astutely chosen homages to the lyrics of Johnny Burke, Sammy Cahn, Mitchell Parish, Yip Harburg and Johnny


Backpacks That Become Luggage
LEAD: There is a new breed of luggage on airport conveyor belts and on the backs of budget travelers in European streets.
This is the ''travel pack'' or ''soft pack,'' which converts from a suitcase with a handle into a medium-sized backpack.
The crucial difference between this luggage and a rucksack or big athletic bag with webbed handles is that travel packs have frames that distribute the load on your back.


On Language;   When Parentheses Are Transgressive
LEAD: Rewriting the (Post)modern: (Post)colonialism / Feminism / Late Capitalism'' read the brochure advertising a conference that I attended at the University of Utah in March.
The program was full of fashionable academic jargon - phrases like ''reified theory,'' ''(post)structuralist tropics'' and ''the racial subject'' - all of it standard lexical fare in the arcane world of literary criticism.


The Last Best Site in Manhattan
LEAD: Call it Lincoln West, call it Trump City or call it the old Penn Central rail yards along the Hudson River.
Those 76 acres between 59th and 72d Streets constitute the finest remaining development site in Manhattan, a site again knotted in confusion and controversy.
It's a Gordian knot that can be cut only by the sword of city and state government.


Adventures in Style;   Have Parka, Will Travel
LEAD: Not so long ago, Justine Strasberg was a hard-working Manhattan art director, with tidy routines and not much time to play.
She liked her shoes polished and her shirts neatly done by the Chinese laundry around the corner.
She had camped out before, but not anything hard-core, not anything like this.


Topics of the Times;   Louisiana's Example
LEAD: Gov.
Buddy Roemer gave the Louisiana Legislature's abortion bill a more careful review than it deserved.
He found it wanting, devoid of minimum humane consideration for women.
He deserves respect for his courage in vetoing the bill in the intimidating climate created by anti-abortion politicians.


Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
LEAD: Pete Rose's sentence was certainly not unfair; in fact, it was rather light.
Didn't Leona Helmsley receive about eight times the sentence that Rose received for committing the same basic crime?
Giving Pete Rose a break in court just because he is a baseball hero is like giving an unqualified secretary a job just because she has a gorgeous body.


Canada Proposes Settlement in Mohawk Standoff
LEAD: After nearly three weeks of armed confrontation between the Quebec police and Mohawk Indians at two locations outside Montreal, the Canadian Government and the Quebec authorities have put forth a series of proposals to end the dispute.


LeMond Is Sore
LEAD: After spending three weeks mostly bent over on a saddle it's not surprising that a fellow might want to spend some time on his feet.
That, it turns out, is more or less what Greg LeMond has been wanting to do since winning his second straight Tour de France last Sunday.


Correction
LEAD: An article on June 17 about Budapest misstated the location of the junction of three subway lines.
A reader has written recently to point out that it is Deak Square, not nearby Vorosmarty Square.


Lou Whitaker, One of the Greats
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Learning Why to Say No to Drugs
LEAD: For the last three years a program has been trying to combat drugs by emphasizing human potential over abuse and devastation, and it appears to be working, its participants say.
Whether the participants are police officrs, teachers, parents or children, many echo the same feeling: hope and patience must conquer the curiosity induced by the drug pusher's outstretched hand.

LEAD: AS convenient as sandwiches may be to eat on a picnic, they are better at the beach or for lunch in the park than more refined picnic occasions, like an outdoor supper before a summer concert.
When wine and bottled water are served instead of beer and soft drinks and when linen napkins replace paper, the menu calls for something more stylish than the typical sandwich and potato salad.

Campus Life: Duke;   University Seeks To Raze a Symbol Of Tobacco Boom
LEAD: Duke University, named for the tobacco family whose wealth started it in the 1920's, is trying to get out from under one of the last reminders of this city's tobacco boom-town days: a building that it fell heir to in 1988 and that the community wishes to retain as a historic treasure.


Water Conservation Begins With Lawns
LEAD: GARDENERS in the Northeast are lucky.
There usually is enough water to go around.
But the Soil Conservation Service says that ''demand for water by humans is expected to double by the year 2000.''

Ornithologist Escapes Harm in Capsizing
LEAD: Roger Tory Peterson, one of the nation's foremost ornithologists, said yesterday that he suffered ''the most critical incident of my life'' Thursday, when his boat capsized in rough waters off Maine.

A Reckoning for the Utility High Rollers
LEAD: The utility industry has never been known as a haven for high rollers.
But in late 1986, when Keith L. Turley agreed to buy a Phoenix savings and loan institution, he was only topping off a buying binge started six years earlier by four of the brashest utility companies in the country, all of them in the Southwest.

LEAD: An Indiana judge has ruled the 2 Live Crew album ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' violates standards of decency and should not be sold to minors, and Dallas prosecutors have filed charges against two store chains for selling the album.


Must the U.S. Give Brazil and Iraq The Bomb?
LEAD: Iraq, with modern armed forces numbering a million and with a leader driven by dangerous ambitions, started a war with Iran, threatens Israel and has rattled its saber against tiny Kuwait.
Its President, Saddam Hussein, may not stop at threats if he can complete plans to build weapons of mass destruction.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Tennis
U.S. and Soviet Union in Final: The United States, behind victories from Zina Garrison and Jennifer Capriati, advanced yesterday to the final of the Federation Cup in Norcross, Ga., but the anticipated rematch of last year's final against Spain will not take place.
That is because Arantxa Sanchez Vicario twisted her left ankle in her singles match, defaulted to her opponent and opened the way for the Soviet Union to win the doubles against Spain and reach today's final against the Americans.

Mutual Funds;   Mr. Smith Goes to Magellan
LEAD: Morris Smith, the new steward of the $14.3 billion Fidelity Magellan Fund, fills his small boxy office like a whirling dervish.
He watches three computer screens, confers with several people and riffles through a pile of papers.
Speaking at a rapidfire pace, he gives orders to the three traders who work exclusively for him.


To Reduce Violence, Decentralize Police;   Real and Deadly


Rival Proposals for Purchase of Jay Land
LEAD: A LONG-AWAITED decision by county legislators over acquisition of the Jay Property in Rye may face yet another delay, political leaders indicated last week, even though two proposals offering a choice of action are now officially before them.


Jasper Johns, Incessant Recycler of Images
LEAD: Writing about Jasper Johns, it is often irresistible to quote, yet again, the artist's famous sketchbook note: ''Take an object.
Do something to it.
Do something else to it.'' Johns has built an influential career on these legendary instructions to himself and they illuminate the basic tenets of his art with increasing accuracy.


Ideas &amp; Trends;   Now the U.S. Asks What Its Radiation Did in the Cold War
LEAD: Against the backdrop of jubilation and expectation following the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, the United States is beginning to measure the painful human costs of the cold war in some American communities.


A Venerable Inn's Nouvelle Ways
LEAD: THE latest reincarnation of the venerable White Hart Inn's restaurant may be the best yet.
The inn, which is more than 100 years old, has recently changed owners and has had an elaborate refurbishing.
Of greater importance to those interested in fine food, the dining room has been overhauled and a new chef, Kevin


When Black Feminism Faces The Music, and the Music Is Rap
LEAD: Like many black feminists, I look on sexism in rap as a necessary evil.
In a society plagued by poverty and illiteracy, where young black men are as likely to be in prison as in college, rap is a welcome articulation of the economic and social frustrations of black youth.


Ideas &amp; Trends;   Science Learns to Catch a Polluting Car in the Act
LEAD: The fight for clean air has produced a new weapon, the environmental equivalent of a highway radar trap, that measures carbon monoxide from passing cars in a fraction of a second.
The original idea was to pick out ''super polluters,'' but some government officials are now thinking about new approaches to pollution control.

The Executive Computer;   Liberating Machines From Keyboards
LEAD: One big obstacle to a wider adoption of computers is the keyboard. ''I had not even touched a computer before I came here, because I never learned how to type,'' confessed a man recently hired as a senior marketing executive by a large computer company.
He has now learned to type - and to use a computer.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A brief report in Tech Notes on June 3 about new propeller designs misattributed the propeller shown in the drawing.
A recent letter from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, for which the prototype was built, points out that the manufacturer is the General Electric Corporation, not Hamilton Standard.

Give the Customer What He Wants
LEAD: When I used to visit suppliers, I generally started by discussing with the chief executive the development of our business together, how it was progressing, what problems they were meeting and how he thought we could improve matters.
I then used to go on the factory floor, and the first place I would ask to see would be the lavatories and washrooms.
