Knicks Won't Match Newman's Hornet Deal
LEAD: It took them to the last minute, but the Knicks finally ended the suspense over the future of Johnny Newman yesterday, by announcing that they had decided not to match the four-year, $5 million offer made by the Charlotte Hornets.


Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program
LEAD: Each year the United States sends so much grain to Egypt that the farmers feed loaves of bread to their cows.


Brooklyn Museum Hours
LEAD: The Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue in the Crown Heights section, will reopen on Mondays starting on Labor Day, Sept. 3.
The hours will be 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. every day except Tuesday, when the museum is closed.

Efforts to Revamp Nation's Schools Spur Dispute at Governors' Meeting

Keeping Safe
LEAD: To the Editor: Further tips for ''Staying on the Safe Side'' (Travel, June 24):


A Voyage to the Scrap Heap
LEAD: The wrecked supertanker Mega Borg has begun a two-month trip to Pakistan, where it will be broken into scrap.
A tugboat towed the vessel from the Gulf of Mexico on Friday afternoon, the Coast Guard said.
The Mega Borg rested about 57 miles offshore since it was rocked by an explosion on June 8.
Four crew members were killed and a fire raged for several days aboard the ship, which spilled 3.9 million gallons of light crude oil into the gulf.


Economic Upheaval: The Toll in Poland; A special report:   EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   For Poles, Road to Capitalism is Rough
LEAD: More than six months after the Government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki imposed Eastern Europe's most ambitious program to create a market economy, Poles are struggling to adjust to a system with new opportunities and new risks.


Barge Aground in East River
LEAD: A barge carrying more than 2 million gallons of gasoline ran aground last night on a small East River island off 96th Street, just north of Gracie Mansion, but was pulled away without any fuel leaking, the authorities reported.
A police spokeswoman, Sgt.
Tima Mohrmann, said the barge was being pushed past Hell Gate by a tug of the Turecamo Coastal Harbor Towing Corp.

LEAD:
CAMPING WITH THE PRINCE AND OTHER TALES OF SCIENCE IN AFRICA
By Thomas A. Bass.
304 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $20.95.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary last Sunday about Arthur Tremain Hertig, an embryologist, misstated the affiliation of a colleague, Dr.
John Rock.
Dr.
Rock, who died in 1984, was clinical professor of gynecology, emeritus, at Harvard University; he was not affiliated with the Carnegie Institution in Washington.


Dodging Hippos on the Zambezi
LEAD: Long after leaving, images of Africa take root in the memory.
For me, some that linger are braking for goats on a dirt road; brush fires that smell like perpetual autumn; driving through towns made up of ubiquitous landmarks - a gas station, a superette, a tearoom and a ''supermodern'' nightclub.
There is also the wonder David Livingstone called ''God's Highway'' - the Zambezi River.


FOCUS: Maine;   Phasing In a Ban on Cottage Conversions
LEAD: When Roger Timmons heard that the State of Maine planned to ban the conversion of summer homes into year-round dwellings in certain environmentally sensitive areas, he was plenty worried.


Trinidad Rebels Threaten to Kill Premier and 11 Other Hostages
LEAD: Representatives of the Government of Trinidad and Tobago were negotiating tonight with Muslim coup plotters who said they had wired the Prime Minister and 11 other hostages with explosives and would blow them up if loyal forces tried to free them.

Kenyan Human-Rights Lawyer Urges Economic Sanctions by U.S.
LEAD: A prominent Kenyan human rights lawyer has called on the United States to press for democratic changes in Kenya by imposing economic sanctions similar to those in effect against South Africa.

Fake Mourners Shoot 5 at Gang Funeral
LEAD: At least five people were shot at a reputed Chinatown gang member's funeral in Linden, N.J., yesterday when men posing as mourners dropped their bouquets and opened fire with machine guns and a shotgun on a crowd of 100 people, the police said.

Smart Street
LEAD:
PARK AVENUE: Street of Dreams.
By James Trager. (Atheneum, $24.95.) It is to James Trager's credit that his detailed account of New York's plushest street breathes more life into the thoroughfare than is visible to the naked eye.
There are several Park Avenues in addition to the rich residential one.

Four Cubans Give Up Refuge
LEAD: Four young Cubans who had taken refuge at the Italian Ambassador's residence in Havana gave up and returned home, the Cuban state television and the Italian Government said today.
Eighteen other Cubans remain at the Spanish Embassy, the only foreign mission still harboring refugees since a rash of requests for asylum began on July 9.

A World Gone POW!
LEAD: Face it, our century's guiding spirit has become the comic strip.
The argot of POW! and ZAP! is an Esperanto available to all levels of society in all countries.
What Orfeo and Euridice were to older civilizations, Mickey and Minnie are to our culture.
It is difficult to sympathize with the hermetic sexual problems of Tristan and Isolde when one considers the grander issues of war, peace and political corruption confronted daily and often on Sunday, too, by Superman and Lois, Batman and Robin, Tracy and Tess.


The Language Thing
LEAD: Yes, the President talks funny.
Yes, he gets tangled in wayward clauses and preppy adverbs, dangling predicates and galloping gerunds.
Yes, he never met a pronoun he liked or a non sequitur he could resist.
And no, they are not saving space for George Bush, between Edmund Burke and Cato the Younger, in future editions of ''The World's Great Speeches.

LEAD: All three of the world's international titles in golf - the Ryder Cup for professional men, the Walker Cup for amateur men and the Curtis Cup for amateur women - are held by Europeans, but the United States took a step toward regaining the Curtis Cup today.

How to Replace Ceiling Tiles
LEAD: ACOUSTICAL ceiling tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used both as new and replacement ceiling material.
Although easy to install and excellent for absorbing sound, such tiles are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean.
Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.

All About/The Shuttles;   Clipped Wings Along the Northeast Corridor
LEAD: It's Friday morning at La Guardia Airport and the shuttle business is even slower than usual.
Richard F. Cozzi, wrapping up his first week as president of the Trump Shuttle, glances about anxiously, as if hunting for more passengers.
A holiday that week has thinned the weekend rush; only a few people straggle into the Trumpterminal, ready to board a Trumpjet, sink into leather Trumpchairs and enjoy Trumpsnacks.

ART VIEW/Edgar Munhall;   Cezanne's Peak Exhibits the Art of Compassion
LEAD: For three days at the end of August last year a forest fire of epic force ravaged what must be the best-known natural totem of modern art - Mont Sainte-Victoire outside Aix-en-Provence, a site made familiar the world over by Paul Cezanne.
The fire destroyed three villages, as well as some 12,000 acres of woods, moors and vineyards.

Buzzing the National Parks
LEAD: It is an early February morning at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in southern Arizona.
Several campers are sitting outside tents, listening to chirping desert birds, when a rumble begins to build and the ground starts to tremble.
A few seconds later, two American fighter planes, perhaps 200 feet off the desert floor, tear over the campground with an earsplitting roar.


Fashion;   Have Parka, Will Sparkle
LEAD: It's a long way from the Arctic to the runways of Europe.
But now the parka has re-emerged as a glamorous evening cover-up.
Parisian and Milanese designers seem to have become enraptured with the parka's shape and have interpreted it in the most lavish of fabrics for their fall collections.
It's an amusing idea - and also one that makes sense, since these new gussied-up versions are also warm and comfortable.

The Right to Buy
Question: I am a tenant in a rent-controlled apartment in Queens.
The building has already been converted to a cooperative but I did not choose to buy my apartment under the original offering plan.
Now I would like to purchase the apartment next to the one that I occupy and perhaps rent it to relatives.

Review/Dance;   Choreography Workshop Lets New Creators Shine
LEAD: The School of American Ballet's commendable New Choreography workshop, which presented its fourth annual program on Thursday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater, gives fledgling choreographers the opportunity to create ballets for young dancers enrolled in the school's summer session.
The project also necessarily forces the choreographers selected each year to work under the kind of conditions that are typical today - giving them just under five weeks to create the ballet, using unfamiliar dancers, though with a full production at the end.

What to wear?
The answer, of course, is a dress.
Nothing fussy or frilly, just a simple dress in a flattering color and a comfortable fabric.


A 5,000th Victory
LEAD: When John Campbell recorded his 5,000th career victory at the Meadowlands on Friday night, he became only the seventh driver in the history of the sport to reach that milestone.
The 35-year-old Campbell is a native of Ailsa Craig, Ontario, with career purse earnings of $85 million, a record.
The career leader in victories is Herve Filion, with more than 12,000, and he is still driving.

Okoskin was a bit tense.
A few miles from the historic Montauk Lighthouse, he was making history of his own.
He was piloting a boat for the first time.

Galicia's Hard-to-Come-by Barnacles
LEAD: Goose barnacles, bane of boatmen and certainly among the most unsightly creatures of the sea, are for all appearances inedible or, at the very least, thoroughly unappetizing.
From a pointy pearly white and hard-as-rock shell, percebes, as these barnacles are called in Spain, extend into blackened leathery necks.

How to Fit In At Princeton
LEAD: Oh, what is so rare as a sensible building that is not too sensible, a lively building that is not too lively, a comfortable building that is not - no, wait a minute.
This building is just as comfortable as it ought to be, and pleasant to look at besides.
It is the new Computer Sciences Building at Princeton University, a campus that is rapidly becoming one of the nation's most ambitious architecturally, and it was designed by the New York firm of Kliment &amp; Halsband.

LEAD: Sentry Bank, one of Cape Cod's largest investors in real estate, has acquired through foreclosure a $20 million 18-hole championship golf course and clubhouse.
It also took possession of 122 residential lots laid out around the fairways as well as 10 unoccupied condominium units and permits to build 23 more.

LEAD: The first hurricane in the Atlantic in the new storm season was born today when a tropical storm's winds strengthened to 75 miles per hour, hurricane forecasters said.

LEAD: For the first time since heavy fighting broke out in southern Lebanon two weeks ago, pro-Iranian fundamentalists lost ground today in fierce gun battles with a rival Shiite Muslim faction, security officials said.

Variations on Ambiguity
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bursts of Solar Energy Endanger Power Lines
LEAD: Bursts of charged particles from the Sun sporadically cause huge surges of electric current through power lines on Earth, destroying transformers or tripping protective devices to take power lines and other equipment out of service and raising the possibility of widespread blackouts, utility experts say.

LEAD: A 71-year-old Queens man wrested a sawed-off shotgun from a 26-year-old armed robber yesterday morning and then caused the intruder to shoot himself with his own pistol, the police said.


THE PRIME OF PAT SCHROEDER
LEAD: Susan Ferraro's fine article ''The Prime of Pat Schroeder'' (July 1) reports that the nine-term Representative from Colorado is known on the Hill as the ''lone wolf'' of Congress.
From the listing of her many accomplishments and her obvious dedication to family issues and cutting of military waste, it would seem that we could use several hundred more such lone wolves in Washington.

Keeping Safe
LEAD: To the Editor: I suggest installing zippers on the inside pockets of jackets as a protection against pickpockets.
If possible, the wallet should be placed in a pocket lengthwise, with the opening at the top; since this is usually a tight fit, one must hold on to the jacket when taking out the wallet, which makes it very difficult for a pickpocket to get it out even without a zipper.


Track and Field: Solutions to the Crisis
LEAD: Make no mistake, track and field is a sport in crisis.
The public's confidence has been shaken by a seemingly never-ending series of controversies.
As it stands now, for instance, only a statistician with an assist from a surveyor and a meteorologist could tell you what the marathon records are today.

Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
LEAD: Pete Rose's sentence was much too short.
It should have been based on the damage he did to baseball's reputation, not on his own baseball records.


WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD:
JAY HOME REFURBISHED


Anything But Cancel
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Sign That Rents Will Go Up?
LEAD: ''Show me a business that hasn't had price increases,'' says Eric Doctorow, senior vice president of Paramount Home Video.
This month Paramount announced the forthcoming release of ''The Hunt for Red October,'' starring Sean Connery.
No retail price has been set (normally rental titles are around $90 to $92), but if there were one, dealers estimate it would be about $99.


Pastimes;   Camera
LEAD: As a wearer of contact lenses, I have a problem.
If I blink too quickly, or if I feel I'm about to get poked in the eye, my contact lenses decide to change positions.
Usually they migrate to the white corners of my eyes, where they don't belong.
This is a painful event that leaves me both teary eyed and temporarily blind.


Currency;   Sinking Against the Mark
LEAD: The dollar moved into new territory last week.
First, it hit a two-and-a-half-year low against the German mark on Monday as the stock market plunged.
Then it fell further on Friday as the report on the American gross national product for the second quarter showed a very sluggish economy, one held above water only by the build-up of inventories.


Headliners;   Adding to the Mix
LEAD: Hong Kong has long been a mixture of Chinese and British styles and traditions but Dame Lydia Dunn has added another ingredient to the blend as the territory moves closer to becoming a part of China in 1997.
Dame Lydia, a 50-year-old executive director of a British-run Hong Kong conglomerate, Swire Pacific Ltd., was honored on the Queen's birthday list in June with a life peerage, an honor held by only two other Hong Kong residents, both men.

LEAD: Fred Grillo of Stonington, Conn., has announced September wedding plans for his daughter Kimberly Ann Grillo and David Hal Bernstein, the son of Diane Bernstein and Paul Bernstein, both of New York.


Taking the Measure of Tape Performance
LEAD: In choosing a brand of blank recording tape, viewers have little to guide them aside from each company's advertised claim to be the best.
Independent assessments of tape performance based on stringent laboratory measurements are needed to bring an element of reason to the competitive melee.


The Nation;   Ugly Reminders of the Oil That Went Underground
LEAD: Underground oil spills are difficult to photograph or visualize - no beaches covered with black goo, no sticky birds.
Yet even though they haven't received as much attention as the more dramatic above-ground spills, the subterranean accumulations probably pose as much of a threat to human health and are even tougher to clean up, environmentalists and government officials say.

LEAD: John Whitney Stillman is keenly sensitive to hairline distinctions within New York's upper middle class.

Many Shrines for Worship
LEAD: Pete Rose might not be so worried about being elected to the Hall of Fame if he were a racing driver.
His chances would be better for numerical reasons alone: while major league ballplayers have to limit their aspirations to Cooperstown, racers can aim for any of six different halls of fame.


ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
LEAD: James Nachtwey's photo essay on ''Romania's Lost Children'' (text by Kathleen Hunt, June 24) was striking and very sad, but I hope no one fails to see the relevance of this situation to our own in the United States.
To disallow a woman's right to abortion and to limit the availability of birth control can lead to tragedy, not just for the women forced to bear children or forced to undergo illegal and unsafe abortions, but also for the unwanted children.

Tech Notes;   An Off-Road Rover - Far Off
LEAD: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is testing a new ''off-road vehicle'' - designed for Mars. ''Robby,'' as it's called, has an articulated body, a variety of sensors and stereo television cameras.
The unmanned craft is designed to travel several kilometers a day.
Two navigation strategies are being tested.

Home on the Range
LEAD: In the late 1800's, a wanderer nicknamed Yonkel the Mahzik (Mischief) showed up at Ellis Island wearing the dark coat of an Orthodox Jew, long sideburns and cowboy boots.
An immigration official jostled him and Yonkel slugged the man and swore at him in a Russian-Texan drawl.
When it was discovered that this strange cowboy was a United States citizen who had fought in the Civil War, Yonkel was readmitted into the country.

How to Replace Ceiling Tiles
LEAD: ACOUSTICAL ceiling tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used both as new and replacement ceiling material.
Although easy to install and excellent for absorbing sound, such tiles are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean.
Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.

9 Million Americans Respond to Plight of a Sick Boy

Determining the Cost of Auto Insurance
LEAD: In the June 10 article ''Changes Readied for Auto Insurance,'' the new auto insurance laws were said to create ''objective criteria that will define a good driver'' and thus help determine fair premiums.
The plan calls for 75 percent of the drivers falling into a ''standard'' (good driver) category, 15 percent into a ''nonstandard'' category and 10 percent into an ''assigned risk'' class.

LEAD: Blobby light-show shapes flicker and wobble on a screen.
Musicians, scruffy in blue jeans or gaudy in flower-patterned shirts, play their instruments and shamble around the stage.
Onstage and off, people flail the air in hippie dances.
But amid all the appearances of a festive 1960's revival, the lyrics (if any) are often grim, while the beat is likely to be pumped out by a drum machine.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Coins, like people show the effects of age.
When roughly handled, coins pick up scars.
Exposure to the elements causes tarnishing and even mild acids will pit and erode a coin's surface.
Beware!
Any attempt to improve a coin's features, perhaps with a little scrubbing or buffing, can do more damage than benign neglect.


Business Diary
LEAD:
COMPANIES
The Power of the Pencil at Eastern
For an airline to boast of correcting vital maintenance and repair problems is hardly the path to recovery.
Who on Madison Avenue could craft a campaign around a message like this?
But claims of ''full corrective action'' were the essence of Eastern Airlines' response to an indictment last Wednesday on 60 counts of ignoring upkeep and falsifying records - ''pencil whipping,'' as it was called.

The World;   In Quebec, Yet Another Splintering
LEAD: In English-speaking regions of Canada, many spy an enticing irony in the crisis currently gripping Quebec.
In the midst of the French-speaking province's renewed debate over independence, it has found itself confronted by an angry minority of its own, Mohawk Indians.
Just as Quebecers have claimed to be a ''distinct society'' within Canada, so too are we, the Mohawks have proclaimed from the armed camps they have established across two highways near Montreal.

LEAD: The Exxon Valdez has a new name (Exxon Mediterranean) and a new paint job (bright red), and is back in the water again after a year of repairs.
Her former skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, will remain beached for a while longer.
Last week, an administrative law judge for the Coast Guard suspended his captain's license for nine months for his actions when the tanker ran aground off Alaska in 1989, causing the nation's worst oil spill.

The Tourists Are in Europe and Things Are Looking Up
LEAD: By the year 2000, tourism may well be the world's biggest industry.
Since the monuments travelers want to see are pretty much fixed, tourists are paying more and more for the dubious pleasure of seeing one another.
For the last year, Martin Parr, a British photographer with an eye for the ordinary, has been documenting the thundering herd as homo touristus spreads across Europe.

HOPE AND HEARTBREAK
LEAD: If the maquiladora industry were to triple its Mexican workers' salary (to a breathtaking $1.65 an hour), it would mean that the average savings per worker per year would be reduced from roughly $16,000 to $13,800.
Would the investors who rely on the maquiladora industry settle for that?
Or is it inherent in capitalism that the affluence of some requires that others live in misery?

ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
LEAD: Anti-abortionists arm themselves with photographs of dead fetuses as evidence of the callousness of those who would have an abortion, or perform one.
The photos of unwanted, institutionalized children in Romania are testimony to the far greater inhumanity of bringing children into the world without parents willing or able to care for them.

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: There are some people - call them naive - who honestly believe that when someone greets them with ''how are you?'' that person is truly interested in the state of their health and fortune.
This, of course, is rarely the case.
How a once genuine inquiry has deteriorated into a rote phrase, generally uttered without feeling, meaning or caring, is a sad commentary on life today.

Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: The World Junior Team Championships for players no older than 25 are now played in odd-numbered years.
The first two, in 1987 and 1989, were played in Europe, and European teams were victorious.
The American teams that competed were unable to mount a serious challenge, but matters may be different next year.


The Man Who Would Be Feared
LEAD: Saddam Hussein emerged from last week's OPEC meeting more than ever a figure feared and respected by his Arab brethren.
The Iraqi President's threats against a tiny neighbor, Kuwait, expressed many things about him: his determination to lead the Arab world in what he sees as a just cause, his penchant for intimidating those who challenge him, and his willingness to carry a bluff to the edge of a precipice.

A Romantic Staging For 'As You Like It'
LEAD: The idyllic Forest of Arden, the setting of the pastoral part of ''As You Like It,'' has been variously assumed to be in England or between France and Belgium.
But exactly where, Shakespeare did not say.
Nor did he care, according to Isaac Asimov's ''Guide to Shakespeare.'' Why not, then, transpose the play's romantic entanglements to make-believe Irish woods and set its darker aspects in a nearby timeless town, instead of the 16th-century Usurper's Courts?


The Spin Doctors of Early Music
LEAD: What does early music have to do with history?
In theory, everything.
In fact, very little.
At the beginning, the movement was frankly antiquarian - a matter of reviving forgotten repertories and, with them, forgotten instruments and performing practices.
Nobody objected to that, nor did most musicians even pay much attention to it.

But two other inquiries are continuing, and the Nebraska State Senator who heads one of them has raised questions about the grand jury's conclusions.

Review/Opera;   A Handel Hero Dabbles in Politics
LEAD: Updated operas - those old theatrical bodies dressed up in modern clothes - seem to come in two sizes: large and small.
Handel's ''Tamerlano,'' by the Measured Breaths Theater Company at the Cooper Square Theater on East Seventh Street, measures somewhere between small and medium.
Rather than dragging the director into the present with its compelling relevance, this production assumes newness as a virtue in itself and then searches for ways to justify it.

Managing;   Proper Conduct in the Workplace
LEAD: Several years ago, Borden Inc. asked a dozen or so employees to devise a smoking policy for the company's Columbus, Ohio, headquarters.
The group - comprised of smokers and nonsmokers, men and women, executives and secretaries, oldtimers and newcomers - set rules that were more restrictive than the smokers wanted but also stopped short of the total ban that many nonsmokers had been pushing.


Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
LEAD: No.
Federal judges have life tenure, so they can make decisions with as little pressure on them as possible.
Occasionally, they should be ready, willing, and able to hand down precedent-setting decisions.
In my opinion, the Rose case was one of them.
I would have leaned real hard on Pete, but no jail time.

Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
LEAD: The community-service sentence given to Rose was not fair.
Rose was banned permanently from baseball.
Yet part of his tax-felony sentence will be 1,000 hours of community service teaching baseball to deprived youth.
The art of teaching implies transmitting values and ethical standards to students as well as skills of play.

The World;   Romania Isn't Trusted, Within Or Without
LEAD: After decades of eerily quiet summers under the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Bucharest faces a long hot summer.
Tens of thousands of university students have taken to the streets to demand the release of a leader charged with inciting disorder at protests in June.
Huge lines for meat and cheese stretch from bare-shelved stores onto the scorching streets while consumers grumble about hefty price increases for gasoline and bottled drinking water.

Modern Pantheon Saves History's Words

Today, the Yale collection has expanded to some 500,000 volumes and more than a million manuscripts, which are now housed in a temperature- and light-controlled granite-and-marble building on the campus.

How to Replace Ceiling Tiles
LEAD: ACOUSTICAL ceiling tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used both as new and replacement ceiling material.
Although easy to install and excellent for absorbing sound, such tiles are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean.
Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.


Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. Our toilet takes a long time to flush and sometimes keeps on running.
The problem seems to be the float ball on the end of the float arm not clicking off when it gets to the top, and so the water keeps running into the tank.
What can I do to correct this?

Pastimes;   Stamps
LEAD: Current events evoke the past: the unbundling of the Soviet-dominated Eastern Bloc intersects with the 50th anniversaries of the spread of Nazi domination in Eastern Europe.


World Markets;   The Greek Market Takes Its Turn
LEAD: In the months since the narrow victory last April of the conservative Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, the Athens stock market has soared.
The tiny Greek market is up 200 percent for the year, and it is the leading performer by far this year in the group that analysts class as emerging stock markets.


No-Hitter Eludes Garrelts Of Giants
LEAD: Scott Garrelts, bidding for baseball's record eighth no-hitter of 1990, lost it with two outs in the ninth inning on a single by Paul O'Neill as the San Francisco Giants beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-0, today.


The Wrong Medicine
LEAD: The clear possibility of a recession has been raised by revised Government figures showing that the economy struggled only to a 1.2 percent annual growth rate in the second quarter.
So why are White House and Congressional negotiators urging each other on to a tax increase?


Outdoors: The Kingly Sport of Salmon Fishing
LEAD: FOR the last 20 years, I have never fished for Atlantic salmon more than once or twice a year, and it may be that my relatively rare encounters with that marvelous game and food fish account for the fierce anticipation that precedes each excursion.


Student Loan Move Studied
LEAD: A taxpayer bailout of a troubled guarantor of student loans would not cost more than $100 million, an Education Department official said last week.


Allied Stores' Debt Plan
LEAD: The Allied Stores Corporation has received bankruptcy court approval of an unusual borrowing arrangement to help it continue operations through its Chapter 11 reorganization.


Venezuela Lifts Gasoline Prices
LEAD: After months of wavering, the Venezuelan Government said last week that it would raise domestic gasoline prices.
A similar move last year brought rioting.

Fire Guts 85-Year-Old School
LEAD: An early morning fire today gutted the 85-year-old Cos Cob Elementary school, town officials said.
First Selectman John Marginot said the damage was extensive.
A fire dispatcher said he had seen only one room left standing.
The school, which was built in 1905 and was used for kindergarten through fourth grade, will not be open in September.


Lower Interest Rates Called Likely
LEAD: A strikingly weaker view of the economy than the one that existed just a few short days ago has altered psychology in the credit markets, increasing the chances that interest rates will move lower in the weeks ahead, analysts say.


Urban League Leader Calls Equality Essential to U.S.
LEAD: Citing projections that members of minorities will make up a larger and larger part of the nation's work force, the president of the National Urban League said last night that the United States must grant them equality not merely out of a moral imperative but for ''its own economic self-interest.''

Treasury's Only Sale Will Be of Bills Today
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are limited to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
By late Friday the rate on the Treasury three-month bill was 7.54 percent and, for a six-month bill, it was 7.42 percent.


U.S. and Asian Allies Deadlock Over Boat People
LEAD: Three days of talks between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies have failed to break a deadlock on how to treat thousands of Vietnamese refugees who continue to arrive on foreign shores every year.

LEAD: More than 300 years after the Matinecock Indians traded away much of what is now eastern Queens, dancers in buckskin pants and feather headdresses swayed to the rhythm of drums during the weekend against a backdrop of Little Neck Parkway traffic.

LEAD: For the last four years, the Israeli Foreign Ministry and a Jerusalem radio studio have run a covert program in which radio reporters were hired by the studio and given Government guidance on what they should report to radio stations around the world, participants in the program and other Government officials say.

Watching the Work of Playing Music
LEAD: In 1983, the New York Philharmonic closed its season with a two-week series of Horizons concerts and symposiums, which explored recent scores of a lush, Romantic sort.
In the seasons that followed, neo-Romanticism remained the central focus, with other current styles added for perspective, but in 1987, the orchestra dropped the series.

On Your Own;   A 3-Piece Rowing Shell
LEAD: A boat designer from Noank, Conn., has created a rowing shell that can be split into three pieces so it can be carried and easily stored.
Robert Champlain, the shell's inventor, said his shell took about 10 minutes to put together.
Fully assembled, it is 20 feet 3 inches long.
When the three parts of the hull are put one inside the other, the unit is 7 feet long and 23 inches wide.

British Esquire Planned
LEAD: A British edition of Esquire magazine will make its debut next March, the Hearst Magazine Company said last week.
Lee Eisenberg, Esquire's editor in chief, will be the new magazine's editor.
Esquire, a life-style magazine for men with a monthly circulation of 734,000, is also published under foreign licenses in West Germany, Hong Kong, Japan and Italy.

Business Scene;   So Far, No Shock For Consumers
LEAD: AMERICAN consumers rarely cause a recession.
Even when their incomes are barely rising, which is the case today, they somehow manage to spend enough to keep the economy afloat.
Only a national shock seems to frighten them into cutting back so drastically that a recession becomes unavoidable.
And so far in 1990, that shock has not come.

Nader Brings 'Community TV' to Buffalo
LEAD: When Buffalo's cable-television system agreed this year to carry a local low-power television station, Channel 58, one of the companies that provides the station with syndicated programming raised the rates it charged to reflect the larger audience.


Mortgage Rate Down
LEAD: Interest on fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.98 percent last week, down from 9.99 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released last week by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
It was the second consecutive week that fixed-rate mortgages were below 10 percent.
The last time that occurred was in mid-January.

LEAD: The first hurricane of the 1990 Atlantic storm season, was downgraded to a tropical storm this evening as it headed toward open ocean.
Forecasters said the storm, Hurricane Bertha, could kick up high surf along the Southeast coast.
Born as a tropical depression off northeast Florida, Bertha grew quickly Saturday into a storm with winds of 75 miles an hour.

Mario M. Cuomo signed legislation today that will make it harder for defense lawyers to ask questions about the sexual histories of crime victims like Marla Hanson, the slashed model, or Jennifer Levin, who was slain in Central Park.


Company News;   Guilty Plea On Billing By Ametek
LEAD: Ametek Inc., a military contractor, pleaded guilty today to two criminal charges of making false statements to the Federal Government and agreed to pay $5.2 million in civil and criminal fines to settle accusations that it had overbilled the Government for sonar systems used on Navy submarines.


Wang Has Loss in Quarter
LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc. reported today that it had a quarterly loss of $496.7 million after the final costs of its corporate revamping wiped out earnings.


ACCORD IS STALLED IN TRINIDAD SIEGE
LEAD: Progress toward a peaceful settlement of a coup attempt by Muslim rebels was uncertain tonight after three days of tense negotiations mediated by a Anglican cleric.


White Sox Send Kittle To Orioles for Bradley
LEAD: The Chicago White Sox traded the first baseman Ron Kittle, their leading home-run hitter this season, to the Baltimore Orioles yesterday for the outfielder Phil Bradley.


Souter Is Linked to Anti-Abortion Brief
LEAD: In 1976, while David H. Souter was New Hampshire Attorney General, his office submitted a brief to a Federal appeals court arguing that the state should not provide Medicaid funds to pay for abortions, which the brief called ''the killing of the unborn.''


Herbert Jenkins, 83, Former Police Chief In Atlanta, Is Dead
LEAD: Herbert T. Jenkins Sr., the Atlanta Police Chief in the civil rights protests of the 1960's, died July 20 at his home in Atlanta.
He was 83 years old.


INSIDE
LEAD:
Explosion Is Feared In Atom Waste Tanks
In the most pessimistic study to date, a Government panel warned that an explosion could rupture tanks of radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington.


Evolution in Europe;   Ukraine Asks Moscow To Return Its Recruits
LEAD: The Ukraine, stepping up its defiance of Moscow, called today for the return of all Ukrainians doing compulsory service in the Soviet armed forces.


Astere Claeyssens, 66, Professor of English
LEAD: Astere E. Claeyssens, a professor of English at George Washington University, died Thursday at St.
Joseph's Hospital in Chicago, where he was visiting.
He was 66 years old and lived in Washington.


Debate on Job-Bias Bill Turns to Issue of Damages
LEAD: As the House prepares to vote Wednesday on a bill to combat job discrimination, attention seems to be shifting from the divisive issue of quotas to the equally difficult notion of monetary damages for victims of intentional discrimination.


Rinfret Renews Call for Death Penalty
LEAD: Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, used the killings of young innocent bystanders in New York City to lend some emotional power today to his call for the death penalty.


Kurri to Italian Team
LEAD: Jari Kurri, who helped the Edmonton Oilers win five Stanley Cups and became the most prolific scorer in the National Hockey League among European players, is off to Italy to play hockey.


By Design;   Lace, But Not the No-Frills Kind
LEAD: Even if she is dressed in jeans and a T-shirt, a Parisian woman is probably wearing something lacy underneath.
Lovely lingerie is one thing Frenchwomen consider a must.


Notebook;   Minor Surgery Sets Back Bavaro
LEAD: Mark Bavaro, the Pro Bowl tight end for the Giants who underwent serious surgery on his left knee in January, underwent another operation on that knee this morning.
The latest surgery was minor, and Coach Bill Parcells said Bavaro should be ready to resume practice in a week to 10 days.

Chess
LEAD: There are a number of hurdles to be surmounted to win a tournament, and these days some of them are rather young.
There was a time when almost any opponent under 20 years old could be written off as a threat to a grandmaster, but with the vast improvement in the quality of chess publications and their proliferation among students everywhere, those days are gone forever.

Company News;   Arkla Will Merge With Diversified
LEAD: Arkla Inc., one of the nation's largest natural gas companies, will merge with Diversified Energies Inc., the parent of Minnegasco Inc., a Minneapolis-based natural gas distributor.
Under the agreement, shareholders of Diversified will receive between 1.575 and 1.752 shares of Arkla common stock for each Diversified common share.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline in some copies on Saturday about a study of the health effects of atomic testing in the 1950's referred incorrectly to the results of the study.
As the article stated, the study found a weak link between atomic fallout and leukemia, not a weak leak.

Company News;   Trefoil to Buy Child World
LEAD: Trefoil Capital Investors L.P., a new investment partnership backed by Roy E. Disney, said today that it planned to acquire Child World Inc., the second-largest toy chain, after Toys ''R'' Us, in a deal worth about $157 million.


British Aerospace Deal
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that it had signed a deal with Oman for 16 Hawk jet fighters worth a total $:200 million, or $367.5 million.
The company said it would deliver the jets by 1994.
Oman had said it would buy an unspecified number of the planes but gave no details on the value of the order.


Morley R. Kare, 68, Physiologist Who Researched Taste and Smell
LEAD: Morley R. Kare, director and president of the Monell Chemical Senses Center, a research group in Philadelphia devoted to studying taste and smell, died yesterday at his home in Narberth, Pa.
He was 68 years old.

Famed 'Country Club Prison' Is to House Violent Inmates
LEAD: The nation's most famous minimum-security Federal prison, whose inmates have included Ivan F. Boesky and H. R. Haldeman, is being upgraded to a higher-security one.


Finance/New Issues;   Avco Financial
LEAD: Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The notes are offered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.95 percent, or about 85 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


Yankees, Sanders Have a Parting
LEAD: The brief, controversial and uncertain major league baseball career of Deion Sanders came to an abrupt halt yesterday when the Yankee organization ended contract negotiations that would have extended his commitment to baseball and could have led to a legal struggle.

LEAD: John B. Inglis, a former chairman and senior partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Lake Forest, Ill.
He was 89 years old and had lived in Northbrook, Ill.


Growth in Jobs Shifts to Losses in New York Region
LEAD: After slowing to a crawl for more than two years, the regional economy has shifted into reverse, shedding 8,000 jobs in private industry in New York City and 7,000 such jobs in northeastern New Jersey in the five months ended in May.


After 60 Years, Scientists Return To Fossil 'Paradise' of the Gobi
LEAD: WITH the lowering of another cold war barrier, American paleontologists have roamed the Gobi Desert of Mongolia for the first time in six decades, finding a new reptile species related to the Komodo dragon, identifying promising sites for future excavations and recapturing some of the exotic flavor of the most celebrated fossil-hunting expedition of this century.

Thompson, a former aide to George Bush, says he will not appear Tuesday before a Senate subcommittee that is looking into his role in helping a businessman with a history of legal problems acquire 15 insolvent savings and loan associations from Federal regulators in 1988.

LEAD: IN a revision that has far-reaching implications for the way humans see the natural world and their role in it, many scientists are forsaking one of the most deeply embedded concepts of ecology: the balance of nature.

LEAD: Sustained by conservation measures, the Indian brow-antlered deer, once thought to be extinct, is making a comeback in the humid marshes and unique wetlands of Keibul Lamjao, a small national park in the country's remote northeast.

LEAD: The dollar fell broadly against major foreign currencies yesterday, continuing a decline prompted by the latest signs of a weakening United States economy and the prospect of lower interest rates.

LEAD: The Government will need $100 billion from taxpayers in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to continue its current pace of closing and selling off hundreds of failed savings and loans, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress today.


1.2 Million People See Van Gogh Exhibition
LEAD: The ''Vincent van Gogh Retrospective,'' an exhibition of nearly 140 works by the Dutch artist, drew a record 1.2 million visitors over four months, the show's organizers said today.
People camped out through the weekend in hopes of seeing the show before it closed on Sunday, the 100th anniversary of the artist's death.

LEAD: At an intersection near Times Square, passers-by on either side of Broadway can follow the scent of flowers in every direction.
There are vendors with bouquet-laden shopping carts.
There's a couple who make flower arrangements under an umbrella.
There's a mobile fruit stand with a floral section.
There are arguments.


Governors' Idea Rejected
LEAD: A proposal by Democratic governors for a national commission to investigate the savings and loan crisis was rejected today by the White House. ''We do feel it is unnecessary to create another bureaucratic body,'' Stephen Hart, the White House deputy press secretary, said in Washington.
The governors' proposal expressed concern about the effort to solve the crisis and requested the creation of the panel.

Company News;   Oshkosh Trucks
LEAD: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation said it would lay off 3 percent to 4 percent of its 2,000 employees to increase its competitiveness in the heavy-duty truck market.
The specialty-truck manufacturer reported a third-quarter loss of $2.5 million, compared with a profit of $4.5 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier.

Company News;   Rorer-Rhone Link
LEAD: Shareholders of the Rorer Group Inc. are expected to give approval on Tuesday to Rorer's merger with a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the giant French pharmaceutical concern, to create one of the world's top 10 drug companies.
Approval of the $3.2 billion deal is assured because Rhone-Poulenc already controls 50.1 percent of Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the case of Oliver L. North referred incorrectly to a July 20 decision by a Federal appeals court.
The decision set aside Mr.
North's conviction on three charges in the Iran-contra case and overturned one of the three charges, not an additional charge, outright.

LEAD: Francis J. Little, the director of advertising and public relations for the New York Philharmonic, died early Monday morning at his home in Manhattan.

LEAD: Caribbean scholars and experts on Islam in the West Indies say the militant Muslim group that staged a coup attempt in Trinidad last week is one of many new religious movements that have emerged in the region in recent years, challenging governments and established religious organizations.


Jimmy DeSana Dead; Photographer Was 40
LEAD: Jimmy DeSana, a photographer known for his witty and occasionally gently erotic color images, died on Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 40 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed.
Mr.
DeSana was born in Detroit on Nov. 12, 1949, and moved to New York City in 1973.

LEAD: The Cetus Corporation suffered a setback today when an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said it could not yet recommend that Cetus's flagship drug, interleukin-2, be approved for use.

She was 41 years old and lived in Branford.

LEAD: Six soldiers absent without leave from an intelligence unit at an electronic eavesdropping post in West Germany are not spies for a foreign power and have been discharged, the Army said today.

Now scientists say that such feelings are not just a matter of discomfort, but also of life and death.
Heat, they have found, generally begins killing people at lower temperatures in New York and other Northern cities than in the South and

LEAD: The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a textile bill that would impose a vicious cost on U.S. consumers, violate existing American trade agreements and undermine international trade talks.

LEAD: In Chinatown, once considered an oasis from many kinds of crime, residents and business owners are nervous these days about a recent surge in violence that they blame on Vietnamese gangs.

LEAD: Joan Ganz Cooney, the founder of the Children's Television Workshop, announced yesterday that she would step down in October as the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

Nassau, Sludge Scofflaw, Pays Big Fines
LEAD: Only nine local jurisdictions in the nation, all in the New York region, still dump sewage sludge in the ocean, and eight of them are on their way to complying with a Federal law that makes that illegal at the end of 1991.
All except Nassau County.
Every day that the county violates a compliance agreement it signed last year with the Environmental Protection Agency, it is fined $22,000.
